sentence: Both cinematic and educational: As a college student, this gave me wider perspective not only about Quezon and the other main historical characters of the film, but about election campaigns and politics and the games politicians play
In history, it is a hidden pearl to find a Filipino that is truly clean, without having to compromise or worse manipulate to achieve their goals
That is why we have to thorough and unbiased research and immersion between all candidates or parties whenever we vote

MINOR SPOILERS: Through my favorite device that is film within a film, Quezon exposes the grey areas of politics, and that the historical theme of whether Filipinos truly understands what Independence entails is eye-opening (more so in the tie back ending sequence)

I also love the parallelism between the themes of the obsession of power (Osmeña but more Quezon) and hero complex (Aguinaldo and Wood) somehow disguised as public service

Don't get me wrong, in watching this film, I believe all these men had good intentions during their tenure, but in the end they all had their past and present mistakes that the film highlights for us to be skeptical about those intentions
The film has the staple Bayaniverse cinematography and soundtrack

My only nitpick with the film is (1) the ending kinda villianized Quezon just for dramatization and that (2) in the feminist perspective, there wasnt ample stress or building of the relationship between Quezon, Osmeña, Aguinaldo, Roxas and the women behind them, unlike in Heneral Luna and Goyo
Pulitika lamang, walang personalan
Higher Use of Creative License: Unlike previous installments that were close to real-life events, this movie contained a lot of purely fictional scenes and plot
It is more of a creative social commentary regarding the Filipino political system than a loosely-based historical recollection
Overall, it is very good and creative in conveying the moral of the story but one must be careful in accepting any of the events as fact

Enticing and fiery: By far this is one of the movies in our film making history that actually broke the "Filipino" style of film making, not that it is bad but it can be too predictive especially with the characters
It gave the protagonist a complex personality and background that almost we people relate to
Manuel Quezon in the movie is by far what I declare as THE best Filipino character made in this country's industry
Not to mention the performance made by the cast not just Jericho Rosales but all of them
For the movie's feel everything and I mean everything is greatly beyond my expectation, it felt like it was true to life and it romanticized the vibe of that era
The music matched the personality of Quezon which was a spectacular
And the cinematography was handled by an artist of its craft

Although in the last part (spoilers) as said in one of the reviewer's statement in the review section, they kind of made Quezon a villain in the end, to which I have no problem with as it is a creative liberty of the writer and director to do
Overall this film is breaking barriers and blockades
This might be my favorite movie this year
October 31, 2025 - 1 of 2 general impression: Filipino  films rarely get played here in the US
So as soon as I saw this showing at the AMC app yesterday, I had to watch
*** Note: I was not a good student during my school days - Elementary, Middle, High School years
I graduated with a 1
2 GPA (Grade Point Average) So needless to say, I never had the capacity to retain any information - Science, Math, and History
Both Philippine and US History
This morning, the only perspective I had on Manuel Quezon was, he had a city named after him
Where I was born and raised, Quezon City
My mother worked closely with the former Mayor of Quezon City - Brigido "Jun" Simon, Jr
From 1986 to 1992
Her desk was right outside his office
During those years, on Manuel Quezon's birthday, we would visit his tomb at the Quezon Memorial
My general knowledge was that he obviously is a National hero
Until after I saw this film
Here's a line from the movie, towards the end, a line that was said to Manuel Quezon during his later years, "You are not a King"
I'm pretty sure you all get the hint and tone of the movie
I promise to myself, I will do diligent research to get both sides of his story
And come to a better understanding
Which will come most likely by next year
After the 2026 Academy Awards here in the US
The overall Cinematography and Motion Picture soundtrack - is a 10
Looking forward to watching this film again and downloading it for my personal collection of movies
Currently as of 10/31/2025 count: Films watched (in-person Screener & viewed-on Mobile/at Home combined) - 66 TV series (in-person Screeners) 13
Quezon Made Me Politically Numb: If there's one political drama set in the Philippines that actually feels real, this is it
Watch this film - it's got all the juicy elements of a Filipino political story: power, ego, corruption, and all that messy human stuff
But what's nice is it doesn't feel like a rip-off of some foreign political drama
It's so grounded, so Filipino, that you can almost smell the cigar smoke and hypocrisy
I'm talking about Quezon, the last part of Gerald Tarog's trilogy
And man, classic Gerald Tarog move - he never gives you that simple "good vs evil" setup
Everything's in the gray area
You can't really tell who's the villain and who's supposed to be the "hero
" Sure, the title says Quezon, but don't expect to be rooting for him
This version of Quezon
He's a piece of work - cunning, manipulative, and so Machiavellian it hurts
You kinda admire his brilliance, but at the same time, you can't stand how self-serving he is
What's great is that the film doesn't try to moralize
It doesn't pretend to be righteous or "for the people
" It just shows politics as it really is - dirty, ambitious, full of people pretending to be heroes while chasing power
It's not preachy at all, and that's what makes it hit harder
The vibe
Think The Wolf of Wall Street, but make it political and Filipino
Everyone's selfish, everyone's got an agenda, and no one's clean
You can't fully hate them, but you sure can't love them either - and that's exactly why it feels so real
If you've seen the first two films, you'll appreciate this one more
There are plenty of callbacks that make it feel like a proper closure
What's surprising is how Quezon ends up softening Aguinaldo's image
This time, he's shown as this calm, conservative old man - almost like a fallen sage
After being painted as the villain before, he finally feels human
It's like Tarog's saying, "He wasn't a monster, just a flawed man in a broken system

"

Jericho Rosales gives a bold performance
At first, his Quezon feels a bit exaggerated - the accent, the gestures, the swagger - but the longer you watch, the more it makes sense
We don't have much real footage of the man, so Jericho's take feels like a believable reconstruction
Tarog clearly wanted this Quezon to feel both authentic and uncomfortable - the kind of leader you recognize in today's politics
The script works
The occasional strong language fits perfectly - that's how real politicians talk behind closed doors
The dialogue sounds lived-in, the tension feels raw
Visually, the film looks good, but you can tell there were budget limits
Some big events, like rallies, felt small in scale - more like social gatherings in hotel lobbies than massive political spectacles
Still, the indoor scenes look great and atmospheric
The American characters are forgettable except for Leonard Wood, but maybe that's intentional since they're not the focus anyway
The pacing near the end feels rushed - especially the Corregidor and Malinta Tunnel scenes
The story wraps up fine, but the scale drops suddenly, like the production ran out of steam
You expect something grander, given the World War II backdrop
But even with those limits, Tarog still lands the emotional punch
My only gripe is how the film implies that all our political rot - corruption, nepotism, oligarch control - started with Quezon
Symbolically, it's clever, but it's also unfair
It's not just one man's fault
This isn't about Quezon alone; it's about a system that's been rotten for generations
What Quezon nails, though, is how it mirrors our current politics
The bribery, the PR manipulation, the media playing both sides - it's all there
Watching it feels like watching the evening news
Different names, same game
Tarog even captures the hypocrisy of the press: "attack and collect, defend and collect
" That line alone could describe our political media today
So yeah, Quezon isn't just about Quezon
It's a mirror - of power, greed, and us
And after watching it, I didn't feel angry or inspired - just numb
The first film, Heneral Luna, fired you up
Goyo made you question heroism
But Quezon
It leaves you hollow, politically agnostic, almost hopeless
Maybe that's the point - that in our politics, no one's really clean, and the cycle never ends
If that's what Tarog wanted to show, he absolutely nailed it
A Lack of Critical and Actual Criticism for the Shady Quezon: I think the film has true promise
Quezon has always been quite a controversial figure of the early fight for true Philippine independence
He did as much good and as much bad if you really think deeply about it BUT the film is just presented in such a dense way
In posits there is true good in Politics
Even sections of actual criticism in the film is really hampered by Tarrog's insistence of the right 'governance'
The lack of a real alternative or an actual in depth conversations that does not really fall into this guise of moral grandstanding is prevalent that it was so eyeroll inducing
You can read philosophies and still be the worst person ever - a college with Liberal Arts make you learn that quickly
If Quezon did not win, what does Aguinaldo can offer in the table that he himself had not done too
Rather film, just villainizes Quezon's insistence to lead
One good example of the film's insistence for moralistic bent but lack of actual 'analysis' is the film's villainization of Quezon's use of his connection
That is what connections are for
To create this dynamic give and take but it oh no, that is bad - because he can make so much campaign materials

It never really delivered on the fact on what would become the Nacionalista Party lead to one of the biggest ultra-majority in the Philippine's History, a familiar sight if anyone has lived to tell in the Duterte era Congress
In fact, the film kinda glosses the fact that this same majority lead the changes in the constitution that inadvertently resulted to the Marcos Dictatorship
In fact, I do think the reason there are many rich families interested in Government is because how they were able to really to enter political spaces during this time
Like for a film that prides itself as critical, it always uses these weak arguments to posit the rather double face attitude of Quezon
I was grasping straws, because it uses the worst criticisms (ad hominems) rather than just actually pulling real punches that is still present in the current Philippine political space
It just bats this idea that Quezon wants the presidency is bad (it is not), because he wants it no matter what
His machination is bad since he is not truthful about his intention
It literally facts that Quezon is a problematic and prolific muckraker, that most of what we hate about Aguinaldo is actually rooted towards his campaign against him
It is attested but a lot of actual paper trails sadly has been destroyed by the war of 45
The film posits that is bad
(not necessarily) but the problem here is that the film also plays out the same muckraking as noble against some of his 'enemies' since they were not able to use it openly (hypocritical)
Like come-on now film
That is just plain stupidity at this point
You cannot just make this two sides of the coin when it's practically the same side
Even just picking cabinet members from his ultra-majority is played as if its bad since he is in the end trying to seek the 'faithfuls' of his herd - like that is weak criticism of Quezon's

I also hate how the film hates Quezon for his aggressive approach to independence but loves the American simply because the Americans found that the filipino plebe does not know the word about the word for Independence
Stupidity, THIS SHOULD BE ABOUT THE LEADERS to begin with
Another instance of the film going for the soft analysis over real question of readiness with the leadership
And also, it really gives so much pass for the Americans and how they handled the Philippines, because they are well-meaning apparently
Suddenly, the atrocities is just a side comment here and there
Even Aguinaldo, who could have been more complex as a character himself is just plainly glorified
I just feel there is so much more here that could have been made to make this actually critical in a sense that in actually is talking about things that would still be prevalent in our life and all
On a lighter mode, Good performances though
Echo is effective as Quezon
I personally think certain actors looked closer to the very Hispanized Quezon but he has character for it
He performed really well and the cavalcade of supporting role was a welcome surprise
I personally think the film did well visually and editing wise, which is a lot for a local film, though the costuming though is really bad - a lot of badly fitted suits
I will still recommend this BUT it lacks a deep reading about Quezon's role in PHI history tbh
It is important to look at this with a more critical eyes since this does tackle a lot of true issues about Quezon but in a way that feels misguided tbh
Quezon (2025): "The story & life of Quezon": Quezon feels like a well-crafted film that Jerrold Tarog put a lot of effort into, both in writing and directing
Rosales's performance as the lead really stands out and carries the movie
Visually, it's a treat with a unique old-school style and great production design that captures the early 1900s vibe perfectly
The story also creates a good amount of intrigue, even if some parts aren't perfectly executed
Despite its flaws, it's an interesting watch because of its strong visuals and engaging narrative
Overall, Quezon is a solid film that shows real craftsmanship and is worth a watch
Good message, Bad Film: After watching Quezon
It truly feels like a hit piece for the old president
Arrogant, Megalomaniac, I am the Philippines
The movie constantly states that you must look at things from different perspectives, yet shows that he does not have any redeeming quality
Other than i guess he looks good
Satirical claims are understandable as this film is shot like a satire
Quezon v Osmeña, Quezon v Wood
But idk why its not like that with chapter 3, Quezon v Aguinaldo
You can say that Quezon is already well regarded by many and a good film came out a few years back (Quezon's Game), but that is just careless in this day and age

As movies like this are perceived as truth by those who are not busily reading in-depth filipino history books, by students and others in the Philippines

But to give credit where credit is due
Most criticism in the film of quezon are real: the r**e case, the being two faced, being an arrogant/megalomaniac, back handing Osmeña
One criticism i have is the I am the Philippines scene
I know this film uses fictional elements but pumping up the drama at the end while the truth (more of a rumor) is that he said this in a New York hospital
while looking at refection of him self
Its hard to like this film if you one of those that dont like grand standing and moral messaging being pushed in the forefront
Cause it happens a lot
With joven's uncle and wife
Other than that, its filmed well, dialogues are written well, and great casting
Great way to finish the trilogy

Quezon (2025) Watched Quezon in cinemas last week
It aims for epic, but somewhere between the dramatic speeches and historical gravitas, it loses its spark
Ambitious, yes, but the heavy-handed theatrics and slow pacing make it more exhausting than engaging
A decent attempt at history, but not one I’ll remember fondly

Pinaka maganda sa trilogy ng bayaniverse, Very Good casting lahat walang tapon, hopefully maraming Pinoy Ang makapanood neto, sana maaga mailabas sa Netflix para mas maraming audience, the Philippines need this kind of film, Jerold Tarog is now my favorite Filipino film Director
A few weeks ago Cinemartys reminded all of us the massacre committed by Leonard Wood in Mindanao
But somehow, this movie humanized Leonard Wood
Making him charismatic and only wants to serve the people, at worst, a bureaucrat
But Leonard Wood was racist and an imperialist
His writings about the Philippines, depicting Filipinos as mostly backward and savages, were the reason why the US government did not give us independence immediately
And yet the movie not only gave credence to his racist tirades, it made it into facts
This is wrong in so many levels
I understand that we should unmask our heroes, but making the founding fathers as villains is a slippery and dangerous slope for a nation that easily forgets its own history
At a time that our sovereignity is in peril by outside and even inside forces, a movie questioning our genesis is a bit irresponsible
Not to mention the hypocrisy of a rousing speech against patronage politics then thanking the sister of the sitting president and the daughter of the dictator in the end credits
Admittedly, Quezon is a much better film than Goyo, but it's irrelevant at this point
Crazy in love with this movie
He takes and he takes and he takes, and he keeps winning anyway

i had a chance to watch their block screening on the first day and got to see their amazing actors, mon confiado, benjamin alves, jake macapagal, ana abad santos, and therese malvar, thanks to national university
the concept of making a prequel about the people we call our national heroes is a smart and refreshing move in philippine cinema
the director shows them as normal people with strong political desires, which mirrors the never ending power game we still see today
from emilio aguinaldo to manuel quezon, all the way to the marcos-duterte tandem, i must say they follow the same pattern
we treat these men like mythical figures and grow up with a clean version of them
then the film shows them bargaining, manipulating, and protecting their own interests, and you realize the cycle never stopped
it feels heavy at first because you hope someone in that era stood as the clear hero, but the more the story unfolds, the more you see how power shaped all of them

what i love about this film is that i went inside the cinema thinking I would learn another honest story from our former presidents and understand why they are considered important figures in history, not just because they led the country but because of what they sacrificed during their time

but after watching it, i realized that both emilio aguinaldo and manuel quezon, despite the rivalry and the clear protagonist antagonist framing, never truly cared about the filipino people and were both playing dirty
quezon is a great communicator and strategist
these helped him rise from being a lawyer to becoming the second president of the philippines
we grow up hearing his name and thinking of one of the best presidents we ever had
in the film, all he talks about is independence, but I never actually saw the real reason behind it
was he doing it for the country, for the people, or to validate his own hard work and protect his power and money
it took me almost two months to write this review because the film stayed in my mind longer than i expected
every time I tried to sit down, i ended up thinking about another scene or another line that hinted at something deeper
it’s not the kind of film you watch and forget the next day
it leaves you with questions that don’t settle right away
i kept replaying how the characters moved and how their decisions shaped everything
the more i revisited it in my head, the more i understood why it bothered me in a good way
it challenges the way we grew up seeing these men
it makes you look past the titles and medals and ask who they were when the doors were closed

I’m a Filipino student and we were given a activity, a small film critique for my social studies class worth 20 points for the seatwork and quiz
Ironic enough, this was announced 6 days after I watched the film
When you hear the name Manuel Quezon, what comes to mind is that he was the 2nd most beloved President of the Philippines
A man who fought cases against the poor before as a lawyer, and was able to serve our country, But after watching the film I realized there was a lot more about him
I realized that Quezon wasn’t really much of a good President for his achievements
He is not really effective as a leader or able to accomplish anything for the country
But instead taking the government’s power by maneuvering to get what he wants and to establish what once was a blissful tree to a rotten egg
He was a master of playing dirty tricks to bribe the people creating conflict against his rivals causing them to get in the way of propaganda like Osmena, General Wood, and Aguinaldo
Involving the press questioning their political views on both perspectives
Another thing I noticed is that the Americans were actually trying to help the Filipinos as General Wood realized the people didn’t have proper education just from not knowing what independence means
They were helping us to establish better roads and build a proper government system for our country
The biopic not only showcases Quezon’s rise and downfall but alongside how our government is still the same until now
“I would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos, rather than a country run like heaven by the Americans, because no matter how bad the Filipino government might be, it can still be improved
” To quote Manuel L
Quezon himself, sums up how our government will always run like hell unlike the Americans even though they were also cruel back then
Our independence may never be claimed, but our pride and soul can not be taken for granted
The Filipino government we have today is still running like hell from our corruption, political dynasties, and both parties fighting left and right while the poor are fighting by themselves
No matter how many people vote for a good president, we will always end up in last place as poverty devours us whole
After watching Quezon’s biopic, I realized how important education is for us and our love for everything we have in this country
What I can use from what I learned in this film as a citizen is by being civilly determined and persevering when it is already my duty to vote for the leaders of this country
That I should be a responsible voter in the future by knowing who to vote for and understanding what this stands for
Other factors that I realized to consider are self-dignity and moral values are important to look for in a leader
Patriotism can be as simple as exercising your right to vote and to vote wisely
In conclusion, despite Manuel Quezon’s search for independence and freedom for the Philippines he was unsuccessful
I say that because up to this day, our political system is naive and independence is something we have been fighting for up till this day
Independence not only from other countries colonizing us, but independence from corruption, political agendas, poverty, miseducation and political dynasties

jericho rosales alam lang kita kasi kamukha mo aso ng kaibigan ko (this is a neutral statement, cute naman yung aso) i was so pleasantly surprised by how well you acted, consider me a fan… i had doubts with the casting at first because irl quezon was a whitewashed mestizo, the stuff of envy for self hating transracial losers on discord, but your acting really sold me, wow… 10/10 trapo moves, no wonder nagalit grandbaby ni quezon HAHA…on a more serious note, i like how this film seems to be tarrog’s way of interrogating himself as a creative, especially with the unintended effect heneral luna (2015) had on swaying the public in support of strongman personas (re: duterte in 2016)… in what ways is the filipino artist complicit in propaganda
or i guess more broadly speaking, in what ways can art and narratives be co-opted
i like that this movie invites skepticism kumbaga… may bisa nga ang kwento oo pero bisa para kanino
bisa para saan / hanggang saan
and i think that’s why i have a soft spot for it… i respect movies that encourage the audience to ask questions

timely siya, in fairness, idk kung intended ba o hindi pero ayun, relevant nga, lalo na in this second marcos presidency where historical distortion thrives precisely because the will to question narratives is being stamped out…pero speaking of narratives, i wish the power of the masses was portrayed with more depth  lalo na dahil next movie tungkol kay magsaysay, grandfather of filipino populism… i was disappointed by the scene where woods asked farmers and peasants if they were in favor of independence because it was such a shallow (and quite homogenous
) portrayal of filipino sentiments on US colonization… where are the sakdals

it’s historically inaccurate to suggest that all filipinos were passive about independence

and speaking of pkp… SIGHHH i really don’t have high hopes for the magsaysay movie… basic details pa nga lang sa pkp di inaayos, huks pa kaya… fact check: the movie’s english subs are wrong, pkp cannot be translated as cpp, those are two different groups… second fact check: nabong was definitely affiliated with pkp but the aglipay-nabong duo did not run under the party name pkp… they were republicans… important distinction because since when tf was pkp ever allowed on the same playing field as quezon’s nacionalistas

After   and :   , TBA Studios and director Jerrold Tarog closes the BayaniVerse trilogy with '' — a film that trades the sound of gunfire for the noise of politics, but still burns with the same intensity
It’s not a war of soldiers this time, but a war of ideals, egos, and ambitions — fought in meetings, elections, and through the public eye
Jericho Rosales gives a career-defining performance as Manuel L
You can tell he studied Quezon’s mannerisms down to the smallest gesture — the posture, the pauses, even the rhythm of his voice
His portrayal balances elegance with cunning charm, showing us both the gentleman, the strategist, the patriot, and the politician

The film’s structure is bold and stylish — divided into four chapters, each framed like a “V” (versus) battle, pitting Quezon against different political and historical figures of his time, accompanied by a subtitle based on dialogues in each chapter
It feels very Snyder Cut in its presentation — grand, deliberate, and unapologetically significant
The fourth chapter, the longest one, brings everything to a dramatic and climactic close that feels inevitable and tragic
Mon Confiado returns as Emilio Aguinaldo, and once again, he commands attention
His portrayal of a president haunted by legacy and resentment is one of his best performances yet
His dialogues, essentially saying that he did everything he could for the Filipinos, echo with pride and regret
It’s still surreal to see Game of Thrones veteran Iain Glen as Governor-General Leonard Wood, but even in his few minutes onscreen, he leaves a strong impression with his performance
Romnick Sarmenta also deserves praise for his controlled and weighty take on Sergio Osmeña, grounding every scene he’s in
The film cleverly incorporates black-and-white silent film sequences, serving as historical vignettes and mirrors of Quezon’s inner world
They show us the contrast between the public image and private intentions
Even more playful are Benjamin Alves and Aaron Villaflor playing not only as the younger versions of Quezon and Joven Hernando in flashbacks but also as actors in those silent films
Karylle shines as Aurora Quezon, bringing class, grace, and quiet strength to her role as a partner who understands the weight of her husband’s ambition
Meanwhile, Joross Gamboa may be new to the BayaniVerse, stepping into the role of the recast Eduardo Rusca
But he still feels right at home in this trilogy, proving his versatility in dramatic territory
'' is, without a doubt, the most political film in the trilogy

While its predecessors dealt with wars and heroism through action and tragedy, this movie unfolds during the Commonwealth election era, where battles are fought through speeches, alliances, and betrayals
Tarog turns politics into theater, and every act has consequences

If I were to rank all three BayaniVerse films:Heneral LunaQuezonGoyo: Ang Batang HeneralAnd yeah, this movie may have lacked action compared to its predecessors, and some might find the pacing slow or the dialogue too heavy-structured, but that’s where its strength also lies
The movie challenges us to listen, read between the lines, and confront the truth that leadership often lives in the grey area between heroism and hypocrisy
What makes this linger isn’t a rousing battle cry, but a haunting reflection:       ,          —
Still, '' stands tall as a worthy conclusion to the BayaniVerse, both grand in scope, rich in detail, and haunting in its honesty about power and nationhood
And yes, stay for the end-credit scene — whether it truly closes the saga or hints at something beyond, it’s the vague ending that leaves you proud, curious, and reflective all at once
In the end, Tarog doesn’t just tell us who Manuel L
Quezon was — he shows us the kind of leader widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in Philippine history
With that being said, I’m going to give this movie…8/10

TAWA MUCH
Hell week is over, so I can finally write my recent movie reviews

Let's start with the movie I watched in the cinema this November: Quezon (2025)At first, I had no idea kung paano ang takbo ng kwento, but I've heard and we tackled it with one of our lesson sa ArtApp where we talked about the Art and Society, Art and Politics
Since then, I was curious about how the movie portrayed Quezon, and how his administration affected the Philippines
I'm glad to have a chance to see it in the theater, it was a different experience
This will be long as I did my research a while ago after watching it kasi as someone who is not that literate with the politics, it can be confusing
Pero, it gave me an opportunity to look at the history myself
Quezon Vs
OsmeñaDuring his time, hindi lang Americans ang kalaban ni Quezon
May mga kapwa Pilipino siya na may ibang idea para sa bansa
Hindi na kalaban from outside, but someone beside him
Quezon and Osmeña were both brilliant, but their visions didn’t always match
Their rivalry wasn’t about hatred
It was about direction
Who can lead the nation better
Which path will bring Filipinos closer to independence
Historically, after passing the Jones Law, Quezon became Senate President, pero kasama niya noon si Sergio Osmeña bilang Speaker of the House
May ideology clash sa pagitan nila
Osmeña was more open to gradual transition, maybe compromises
Pero si Quezon gusto ng mas klarong direksyon sa independence
Dumating yung time na naglatag ng Hare–Hawes–Cutting Act, batas na may planong bigyan ang Pilipinas ng independence pero may mga kondisyon tulad nung retention ng US military bases
Si Osmeña sumuporta, pero si Quezon tumutol, gusto niya tunay na kalayaan
Pinamunuan niya yung campaign para i-reject ang HHC at gumawa ng mas maayos na plano
This eventually led to the Tydings–McDuffie Act of 1934, which set up a 10-year transition period toward independence
Nagkaayos sila para sa 1935 election: Quezon bilang President, Osmeña Vice-President
Nanalo sila at nagsimula ang Commonwealth
It is a fact na nag-advance ang pilipinas during his term pero some elites benefited more than the common people, so the effects weren’t evenly felt
Basically, Quezon’s leadership advanced the country on paper and at the top levels, pero hindi lahat nakaramdam ng pagbabago sa araw-araw nilang buhay
Quezon Vs
WoodThere's this Wood’s mission sa Pilipinas, na tinawag na Wood–Forbes Mission, sent by the U
para i-assess kung ready na ba ang bansa for independence
Sila ni Forbes literally inikot ang halos lahat ng provinces, tiningnan yung governance, economy, education, at social conditions
Ang conclusion nila
Marami pang Pilipino hindi pa ready mag-govern on their own
At sa totoo lang, hindi sila totally mali
Marami sa mga pilipino noon lalo na ang mga pilipinong walang access sa edukasyon na hindi talaga alam kung ano ang ibig sabihin ng kalayaan
May scene doon sa movie inikot ni Wood yung mga baryo at tinanong ang mga tao tungkol sa freedom, may isang farmer na sumagot, “Masarap,” kasi akala niya ang kalayaan ay pagkain lang
It is sad but it's true na ang mga tao ay madalas na focus sa araw-araw nilang buhay, lalo na kung paano makakapag-hain ng pagkain sa kanilang hapag-kainan (wow, lalim)
Kaya natural na naging skeptical si Wood sa kakayahan ng mga Pilipino na mag-govern
Kahit sa mga elite, may problema rin
Maraming local leaders yung mas interesado sa sariling kapangyarihan at personal gain na kaysa sa long-term good ng bansa
Madali silang magpadala sa opportunism, kaya minsan hindi sila sumusuporta sa reforms

Dahil don, kahit nakapagtayo si Quezon ng institutions at frameworks, hindi pantay yung epekto sa ordinaryong tao katulad ng mga magsasaka, mas nakinabang ang mga elite, habang karamihan ng masa stuck sa poverty, limitadong edukasyon, at lupa
Quezon Vs
AguinaldoThis part builds the tension gradually
I LOVEEE ITTT
The soundtrack, the camera work, everything
Makikita doon sa 1935 presidential campaign ni Aguinaldo
Kasama niya yung supposed VP niya, pero compared sa massive support ni Quezon, maliit lang yung entourage
Low-budget, few supporters, at sa maliit na pagtitipon lang, Di katulad kay Quezon, nasa sasakyan, maraming supporters, parang festival
Sa isang scene, pinapaalis siya sa lugar (hindi ko matandaan kung saan), tapos sinabi niya na hindi na siya babalik
Eto parang dramatization nalang, pero historical fact na natalo talaga siya ng malaki kasi Quezon got around 68% ng vote, habang Aguinaldo less than 20%
It's a matter of nationalism vs
new governance ni quezon
"Wala kayong utang na loob
"Controversial si Aguinaldo dahil sa mga paratang na involved siya sa deaths ni Andrés Bonifacio at Antonio Luna
After Tejeros Convention noong 1897, na-execute si Bonifacio at yung kapatid niya
Maraming sources ang nagsasabi na in-approve ni Aguinaldo yung order, sabi niya “for the sake of the country
” Later, si Luna naman na-lure sa meeting sa Cabanatuan at pinatay; may mga historians na tinutukoy yung telegram ni Aguinaldo bilang evidence na posibleng siya ang nag-orchestrate
Hindi lahat malinaw, pero malinaw na messy ang Filipino politics noon, halo-halo ang power, loyalty, at personal ambition
Aguinaldo could have humiliated Quezon by bringing up personal matters, pero hindi niya ginawa
Quezon won, became first president of the Commonwealth, and set up the all-Filipino cabinet

He tried reforms like the Rice Share Tenancy Act of 1933, pero marami ang nagsasabi na hindi daw ito effective kasi controlled pa rin ng landlords ang local politics, kaya maraming peasants ang naiwan sa kahirapan
Quezon Vs
JovenFictional siya, I know
Pero, joven served as the eyes ng audience
Sa simula, nung nakita niya si Quezon sa boat, hopeful pa siya, baka this person is really the way to change
Simple pa yung pananaw niya noon, hero si Quezon, clear ang moral compass, he's a good person
Pero habang lumalalim yung kwento, habang mas nalalaman niya yung political struggles, nagbabago rin yung tingin niya
Nakikita niya yung tension kay Osmeña, kay Aguinaldo, pati sa mga pilipino
Kapag titignan mo, mas naiintindihan mo yung history, hindi na pure heroes and villains ang nakikita mo
People have their own agendas, limits, at minsan kailangan gumawa ng “dirty work” para maabot yung goals nila
Nakikita rin natin kung paano yung utang na loob, loyalty, at personal connections gumagawa ng ripple effects sa buong political system, at paano siya nakakaapekto sa mga ordinaryong pilipino
Overall, through technical, I love the cinematography, yung color theory na ginamit nila, yung soundtrack and everything
I love movies like this, and I'm looking forward for the next Bayaniverse ni Tarog, which I think is Magsaysay
Yay, the best president of the Philippines
Throughout the "Bayaniverse" trilogy we see through the eyes of the fictitious journalist Joven Hernando as he witnesses the rise and fall of the national hero, and of himself
We share his naivete in "Heneral Luna", his awakening in "Goyo", and finally his hypocrisy in "Quezon"
The character of Joven stands in as the Filipino people, whose principles waver at the sight of precious opportunity and promise

Joven has never fully let go of his tendency to idolize the man behind the power, his attachment to such figures taught him less to be wary of following their footsteps and taught him more of their machinations and how he could benefit from it all, only to be ultimately discarded after falling victim to the schemes of the "hero" he betrayed his principles for
Like Joven, we are complicit in the ills of our country by our own inaction and tolerance
It is much worse of a sin that we choose to close our eyes even if we have already seen the truth
We have the resources, the history, and the privilege of correcting our mistakes but why do we remain stubborn
We realize our own hypocrisy only when inconvenience has caught up to us

this review shares my sentiments quite well
I get why the Quezon family might not love this
But honestly, that’s exactly what Gerald Tarog has been building toward since Heneral Luna and Goyo
The trilogy isn’t just about flawed heroes; it’s about a nation that has never been fully ready
Heroes rise because the people, the institutions, the country aren’t prepared to carry themselves
And Quezon leans into that idea
The film asks: What does independence even mean when you’re young as a nation and surrounded by bigger geopolitical forces
Here, politics is spectacle
Everyone is performing, maneuvering, managing appearances
It’s less “be angry” like Luna, and less “blind obedience” like Goyo
It simply shows you that everyone—from local elites to foreign powers—is taking us for a ride
And Quezon, in this telling, becomes a product of that pressure
Not a saint, not a villain—just someone doing what the moment required
What fascinated me was how consistent Aguinaldo is across all three films
You didn’t like him before, but here you can finally sympathize
The cast is strong, and the historical texture is rich
My issues are mostly structural
Since this is a biographical piece, the core tension is softer—alam mo na where it ends, alam mo na he becomes a hero, alam mo na we get independence
So the pacing won’t land for everyone
Luna worked because it tapped into a collective anger at a very specific time
Here, the emotional punch is more muted, more contemplative
I get why Tarog didn’t turn this into an activist film per se, but that choice also holds the film back from being as explosive as the first
Still, as a trilogy capstone, it’s thoughtful and well-acted
I admire the ambition, even if this one didn’t hit me as hard as the earlier entries
It was really entertaining however I think it was too prejudiced against Quezon and started to drift away from actual facts about the history of the Philippines during the promise of independence

Jerrold Tarog directs with operatic ambition, closing the Bayaniverse trilogy on a thunderous high note production design flexes hard—every frame is a museum piece, every set a masterclass in period opulence

Pong Ignacio’s cinematography paints history with prestige—wide shots, warm tones, and war-room drama that feels Shakespearean Jericho Rosales commands the screen as Quezon—flawed, fiery, and magnetic, with a performance that lingers

Supporting cast elevates every scene—no weak links, just ensemble excellence the film blurs reality and dramatization with reckless confidence—some scenes feel more myth than memory pacing wobbles in act two, indulging in grandeur over grit—some sequences feel like prestige filler the final act leans hard into legacy-building, sacrificing ambiguity for cinematic sainthoodfavorite scene: the debate was fire—but Quezon’s first wife showing up

That was the plot twist that slappedleast-liked: the transitions between Benjamin Alves and Jericho Rosales as Quezon were jarring—like flipping channels mid-monologueverdict: watch Quezon (2025) for its grand visuals, powerhouse performances, and that debate scene twist that turns history into high drama

Quezon is ambitious, centered on the dramatic rise and political maneuverings of Manuel L
Quezon, bringing into focus both his leadership and the moral complexities that come with power
Directed by Jerrold Tarog and starring Jericho Rosales, the film shows serious craft—period details, strong performances, and a desire to tell a sweeping national story

That said, while the intent is noble and the scale impressive, the film sometimes feels uneven—its pacing can feel heavy with exposition, and certain character arcs or motivations don’t always land with the emotional clarity you'd hope for
It’s a solid historical drama, but it doesn’t always transcend its genre in all moments
The humor of the entire film perfectly depicts Quezon's puppet government
The government of 1920s is just the same with the current one
Philippines is a circus and we never learn from it as we continue to masturbate for the elites
At its core, I found that the movie reflected my frustration in both the spectacle of political power plays, and the intellectual, moral decay of those who now hold the reins of government

Contemporary politicians—our so-called trapos—-have devolved into near-cartoonish figures: one-dimensional villains who plunder public funds, inherit their influence, and contribute little to the nation beyond perpetuating their dynastic entitlement
In comparison to Quezon, whose brilliance was matched by his ambition and corruption in equal measure, today’s leaders lack both vision and complexity
For all his duplicity, Quezon established systems that tangibly benefitted the poor in some ways, and he did grant us some period of independence (though that’s still debated)
One cannot form a fixed opinion of him, for his legacy is both admirable and reprehensible
In this regard, Quezon (2025) mirrors its subject: difficult to pin down, simultaneously compelling and shallow
The film dramatizes power and corruption effectively, and inevitably tugs at the viewer’s frustration given the state of current politics
Yet it often flattens the historical depth of Quezon’s time, reducing the struggle for independence and the weight of colonial subjugation into a tale of political maneuvering

The controversy surrounding Quezon’s grandson’s reaction at the film’s premiere only reinforces the persistence of the Great Man myth, the impulse to sanctify flawed figures rather than confront their contradictions
While the Bayaniverse in general deconstructs this narrative, I think Quezon (2025) only partially succeeds
What emerges instead is a reflection of both the man and the nation: brilliant in flashes, compromised in execution, and perpetually caught between reverence and disillusionment

This movie feels like both an ending and a beginning
For me, Quezon isn’t “bayani enough” to close this trilogy; he’s more like the start of what could be a pangulo-verse
Quezon is a master player in politics
The appointment game scene is one of my favorites because it shows how Quezon skillfully maneuvers people and the government itself
His ambition, driven by greed and power, is disturbing, yet Jericho Rosales portrayed it so convincingly that I couldn’t look away
Quezon is selfish and trapo, and that’s what makes him believable
He mirrors the very kind of politics we see today, shifting how leadership and power are perceived in our system
I also liked how Joven became aware of what was really happening
He refused to be swayed again and stood firm in what he believed in
The two-hour film gave justice to how this trilogy ends
My favorite part is when Quezon said that being a hero is all about perception
That line sums up the whole point of the movie: that history and heroism depend on how we choose to see them and we create heroes in our likeness

10/10 = MASTERPIECE I didn’t expect this film to affect me the way it did
I thought I was ready, that it would simply be another historical piece about a man I’ve always admired
Instead, it left me still and uncertain, as if it reached into what I believed and rearranged it
It has been a long time since a film made me feel this kind of quiet turmoil
I have always seen Quezon as one of the strongest figures in our history
I saw him as a leader who carried both intellect and heart, a man who stood for what the Filipino could be
Watching this version of him felt painful
The film showed a Quezon who was cold, distant, even cruel at times
I disagreed with it deeply
Yet I could not turn away
It felt honest in its discomfort, as if the film was reminding me that greatness is never pure and that power often leaves scars no one else can see
I kept trying to defend him in my mind, to separate the man from the portrayal, but I realized that was the experience the film wanted me to have
It wanted me to struggle with the idea of Quezon himself
It wanted me to feel both admiration and doubt
That inner tension became the most human thing about the entire experience
When the credits rolled, I just sat there
I couldn’t move
I couldn’t even think clearly
It reminded me how rare it is for a film to make me pause, to make me reflect not just on history but on the kind of leaders and ideals I believe in
It left me unsettled, but it also left me grateful
I still believe in Manuel Luis Quezon
I still see him as one of our greatest
Yet this film made me look at him again with clearer eyes
It made me realize that true admiration accepts flaws, questions myths, and still chooses to understand
That realization is what stays with me
Quezon (2025) gave me confusion, pain, and awe all at once
It made me think harder about pride, power, and the weight of building a nation
It is not an easy film to love, but it is a necessary one
And for me, that makes it a masterpiece
All the discomfort, all the challenge, all the awe I felt comes together in one simple truth
The film made me feel something that reminded me why I love history, leadership, politics, and philosophy
Quezon at Osmeña RETRO BLpinayflix finds: "20 pesos at 50 pesos nauwi sa alam niyo na" "Ah, banal-banalan kang burat ka
" isa sa linya ni Quezon sa pelikula, pero sa totoong buhay, ito ang sigaw ng lahat sa mga uhaw sa kapangyarihan pero bulag sa bayan
Pag nanonood ka, akala mo nakikinig ka lang sa mga balita ngayon
Parang bawat eksena sa Quezon, bawat debate, bawat campaign parade — ay hindi na bago sa atin, dahil nangyayari ito sa totoong buhay
Ang mga salita, galaw, at taktika ng mga nasa kapangyarihan ay paulit-ulit, predictably corrupt, at puro palabas lang
Ika nga nila, "Ang magulong bayan ay salamin ng magulong politika
" Hanggang ngayon, hindi naglalaho at patuloy pa rin na umiikot sa ating realidad
Sa palabas na ito, ipinakita kung gaano kadumi ang politika: nakakasuka, nakakagalit, nakakatakot
Pero alam naman nating lahat, it’s just the tip of the iceberg
Mas nakakatakot pa, dahil hanggang ngayon, wala pa ring tunay na pagbabago, at wala pa ring nakukulong
Ang ganda rin ng portrayal ng mga journalist — ipinakita kung paano sila naging mata’t tainga ng bayan
Nakakalungkot lang isipin na may ilan sa panahon ngayon na nagpapadala sa impluwensya, nagpapabayad, o nagpapagamit
Pero naniniwala akong mas marami pa ring tulad ni Joven — mga taong marunong magbago ng paniniwala para sa mas mabuti, marunong mamulat, at may tapang tumindig sa katotohanan
Bukod sa journalists, binigyan din ng pansin ang mga filmmakers
Ang pelikula ni Nadia ay simbolo kung paano naaapektuhan ang opinyon ng publiko sa bisa ng mahusay na kwento
Madaling maimpluwensiyahan ng propaganda, political ads, o social media narratives
Sa trilogy, masasabi kong ito ang paborito ko
May halong sarcasm pero masaya ang paraan ng pagkukwento
Isa sa pinakanagustuhan ko ang campaign scene — maliwanag at parang pista, pero sa kabila, naroon ang lungkot at muted na kulay, na parang isang funeral
Sa huli, napanood natin ang sinasabi ni Quezon na "hindi natin mapanonood" — parang ang tingin niya, habang buhay ay matatago ang baho ng pabango
Marami sa mga politiko ngayon ay ganoon din: puno ng palabas, sakim sa kapangyarihan, at bulag sa pangangailangan ng bayan
Para sa akin, hakbang na ito para mas mamulat at lumawak ang pananaw ng mga Pilipino
Nakakatuwa dahil hindi lang siya pangalan sa history books; nabigyan siya ng boses, ng puso, at ng karakter
Ang pelikulang ito ay magsisilbi bilang paalala ng paulit-ulit na dumi at kasinungalingan
Pero sa huli, nananatili ang katotohanan sa mata ng mga nakasubaybay at mulat

Ang panonood ng "Quezon" ay parehong pakiramdam ng pakikinig sa isang kakilalang naglalarawan sa isang taong nakadaumpalad mo na, ngunit hindi pa lubos na nakikilala
Kaya matapos makinig sa mga kuwento, may responsibilidad na kilalanin pa nang husto ang taong iyon sa kung anumang layuning mahalaga para sa iyo
Ang panganib lang dito ay kung paano tatanggapin ng nakinig: maniniwala agad-agad o aalamin muna ang kabuuang konteksto
Sa Araling Panlipunan/Sibika, limitado ang pagpapakilala kay Quezon
Kaya kung gagamitin itong pangunahing materyal ng DepEd at literal na bibigyang-interpretasyon, mayroong tendensiyang matuon sa "sensationalism" ang talakayan
Ngunit gayundin, magandang ipinakita ang kabuuang karakterisasyon ni Quezon at kung paano siya naging biktima rin ng sistema ng politika sa panahon ng pananakop ng mga Amerikano
Gayunpaman, sa personal kong opinyon, nakulangan ako sa pagpapakita kung paano tinawid ni Quezon ang grey areas--sa pelikula, tumatawid lamang si Quezon sa itim o sa puti
Kung maipakikita sana ang bigat ng pagkaipit sa sistema at pagpili na lamang sa "lesser evil", mas naging balanse at nagkaroon ng dagdag na layers ang kaniyang tauhan
Nakakabahala rin ang idea na mula pa noon ay umiiral na ang parehong maruruming taktika sa politika
Na parang ang pelikula ay direktang salamin ng kasalukuyang lagay ng politika sa bansa

Honestly before watching the film I got a bit skeptical, not because of the relative's reaction rather, of how his death is going to be depicted - as most stories of "Bayani" ends with an abrupt bullet or a machete to the body (about 50 times)
I vividly remember reading that he once gave his SONA in a hospital bed in Washington DC because he was fighting TB

While he often had that shiny 20-peso bill image to him, reading books like Nick Joaquin's A Question of Heroes (which this film takes inspiration) suggests a more open to interpretation viewpoint of the politician-statesman

You can write a persuasive essay about it, honestly, and your highschool AP teacher would probably applaud you by choosing either depictions and look at the complexities of the human character and the political environment he had to deal with
Going back to the ending though, you can very much understand the backlash because it really leaned into the creative side of the narrative
But I kinda like it because its a fun thought to have; if MLQ didnt get sick, what would he have done more as his legacy

Depicted as the savvy, charming, trickster of a politician playing "the game of politics" and always trying to get the upper hand on people, I'd like to think that he would've been similar to how Lee Kuan Yew did for Singapore
Similar in character in a lot of ways and tickling his way to almost authoritarian (competitive authoritarianism, that is)
At least with the way how the film depicted it
"I am the Philippines" is definitely a bold line to say, but probably not too far off
And the line about "Quezon may not have invented the game, but he sure damn played it well" describes the character perfectly
The film is actually the commentary of Jerold Tarog, the director
He questions Manolo's morality and character because that's how we all should look at historical figures
I remember when Luna came out, everyone was preaching his machismo, especially at the height of Dutertismo
But Tarog probably saw the bad effects of the film and tell us: "Hey, don't worship our heroes

" Funny how the film mocks the audience for incorporating the silent film-slide show scenes at points, as if they're trying to tell you "this is how most people probably would've made this film: prim, proper, textbook-like, 'here's all the key highlights of his life and the good he's done, and then he died
" Rather, they chose to depict that complex, imperfect, flawed character that I would've been more interested in watching
He's never meant to be seen as a martyr
He's a historical figure, a real person
Is it 100% accurate
I don't know, ask your history teacher
Was it fun to watch
Was the acting great
More importantly, was the film good
All points to: Yes
Yes it was
Last note: MLQ III is right
The film is a horror story about corruption of power, the state of politics today, and the trajectory of Philippine politics from that point on

Instead of picking up from where Goyo and Heneral Luna left off, Quezon abandons the tragic hero's tale of its predecessors and instead explores, for lack of a better word, its titular character's descent into madness and depravity
It's less a biopic and more of a character study that relishes in the drama of its narrative without needing to wink and nudge at the viewer
There's a lot of standout performances here, but Iain Glen, Romnick Sarmiento, and Jericho Rosales really stand head and shoulders above the rest in a very talented cast
Glen and Sarmiento especially bring a lot to their characters' tables with microexpressions that elevate already stellar performances
Sarmiento's facial expressions by themselves are strong enough to constitute dialogue

Rosales, meanwhile, really puts the larger-than-life aspects of the titular character at the forefront of his performance and just exudes the kind of charisma you would expect a man like Quezon to have
As much as I would've liked to see what TJ Trinidad would've done with the role had he not been replaced, it's hard to see how anyone other than Rosales was the best choice
On top of that, the movie pulls very little back in the way of punches
Very few characters are portrayed in a positive manner and it's the clashes between these strong personalities that make this picture so interesting to me
The film also uses these clashes as a Trojan horse for some scathing social commentary that, while on-the-nose, hardly ever crosses the line of being egregious or preachy
The visual and stylistic homages to Fritz Lang's works, especially, were the cherry on top for me

It’s been a big year for Philippine cinema, and what could make it even bigger than a film about politics and power
Quezon dives deep into Manuel L
Quezon — his legacy, his triumphs, and all his mess and contradictions
The film portrays him as charming and eloquent, a political game player, and manipulative at times — without ever romanticizing him
It’s insane how the political landscape back then mirrors so much of what we still see today
The film serves as a fascinating tribute to one of the country’s most dominant and complex figures
The cinematography and editing are stunning
It's an ambitious step forward for Philippine cinema and a huge achievement in craft
The script, dialogue, and even the incorporation of silent film techniques beautifully capture the era
The acting is top-notch
Jericho Rosales, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado delivered powerful performances
Overall, Quezon offers a sharp, compelling glimpse into the man behind the myth while holding a mirror to our present-day politics
It’s timely, daring, and deeply resonant
People really need to see this
What a great film

This film for me is such a refresher because unlike the previous films about MLQ, it challenges the pedestal that he has been put on, which I believe is essential when we discuss important figures in our history
I think a lot of us (myself included) often fall into the trap of patronizing our heroes to the point that we romanticize them through the legacies that they have built
This was very much true for me, specifically with Heneral Luna (Naalala ko grabe yung galit ko kay Aguinaldo nung una kong napanood yung Heneral Luna na movie hahaha)
While some may see this film as overtly negative and borderline slanderous against MLQ, I see it as a way to challenge the longstanding beliefs and notions regarding him
It pushes people to rethink our history, to be more critical, and to ask questions about what really happened in the past
And of course, the biggest elephant of them all is the connection between the past and the present
This is not just a historical film; it is also a social commentary about the current political climate we have right now
We can make the analogy of how the things from the past never really changed up to the present day
It merely evolved, adapted, and thrived
It persisted because the people in power willed it so
Going back to the film, we can also see how the concept utang na loob played a big part in ultimately shaping MLQ’s politicking
How it was first used on him and eventually, how he used this to take the reigns of our country
“You either die young as a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain
”In essence, MLQ wouldn’t have survived that long in the landscape of Philippine politics had he not conformed to the games being played on the floors of its administration
His good intentions, as genuine as it might have been when he first started, nevertheless was inevitably consumed by the environment he was in
Truly, it was a world of “eat or be eaten”
Effective in its message that no politician deserves absolute glory

Despite everything I’m lucky to have read three drafts of this and a treatment of what would have been its structure were it a series, and came in to the theater just to marvel at how Jerrold would pull this off
He pulled this off wonderfully, of course, with humor and aplomb
The script wasn’t as funny as it turned out to be on the screen, and kudos to Jerrold for seeing our government for the farce it is
Seeing Jericho play Quezon initially felt put on, but by the end you believe he’s the living, breathing embodiment of the 50 peso bill
Cris Villanueva puts some weight and character into the everpresent Joven
Jorah Mormont is a great Leonard Wood despite the accent
Karylle is always great and is missed on the big screen (follow her on Letterboxd)
I really love Romnick as Roxas
And our dear beloved Mon Confiado, the survivor of the trilogy, plays Emilio Aguinaldo as the same person with the fire behind his eyes fully extinguished
It’s a painful portrayal, and will make you feel bad about all his shenanigans from the prior two films

End of the day I’m just grateful that during this time, what feels like such a low point for Philippine cinema, Jerrold continues to create his films about our flawed history, filled with stories of deluded strongmen, inexperienced boy generals and manipulative power players
He holds a mirror to our society that most people in power, heroes’ grandchildren included, don’t want to see

But when Leonard Wood talks about politicians using diplomatic trips as an excuse for family vacations and Filipinos not ready for independence with their infighting and greed, everything feels so eerily timely
Then you realize that’s the way it’s always been
Me: Question: matatapos na yung trilogy mo
After all is said and done is there an overarching message for the… bayaniverse
Jerrold: *shrugs* Aguinaldo outlived them all
There’s probably something in there
I’ll be thinking about that for a while

Unlike Heneral Luna and Goyo, Quezon did not show any form of physical violence; rather, it portrayed violence through the use of words
Storytelling-wise, it was quite okay for me, but I think there are a lot of areas that could be improved
As someone who doesn’t appreciate slow-paced movies, Quezon felt really boring to me at the beginning

Nadia’s role as a storyteller throughout the film also felt somewhat messy—but then again, it allows the audience to form their own opinions and perspectives on the narratives and realities she presented during Quezon’s term
In both Heneral Luna and Goyo, Joven served as a symbol of youth—the hopeful defender of our country’s future and independence
In Quezon, however, he symbolized how people might abandon their morals because of the selective facts presented to them—facts that politicians carefully curate for their own benefit

Joven still represented hope for the Philippines, because even though he strayed from the beliefs he once fought for, he eventually came to understand how manipulative and power-hungry politicians can be
This idea was further emphasized by Miguel Laureano’s retirement, which symbolized the shift in political climate and the changing perception of the masses
The movie reflected the bitter reality of our current political state—it mirrored how Filipinos tend to be selective about what kinds of change and movement they are willing to support
As we moved on from Quezon’s term, we should have experienced growth and improvement, yet we did not
The film illustrated how our political system remains trapped in a constant loop, where we continue to vote for and campaign for politicians who ultimately serve Western interests rather than our own

I rarely see Jericho Rosales in films but I think he does a good job capturing Quezon and the way people talk back in the late 1920s-30s
Of course I have to applaud the production and costume design
It’s excellent and if I remember my fashion history well, I think they did a good job at depicting the way Filipinos & especially Filipino women dressed back then
I also LOVE the format they chose to tell the story to stay true to the times, thru the silent films and then the 1920s-30s visual aesthetics
That aspect was so fun I love it so much

Anyway, it’s interesting to see how they portrayed Quezon because I vaguely remember how he was portrayed as a good President back in my elementary Philippine History lessons, how we briefly touched upon his “achievements”
But since they say that this depiction was backed by historians, public facts and documents then I think they really did a good job of humanizing him
He wasn’t just a shallow historical figure from the recent past anymore, we get to see his flaws & his motivations
This is great

i remember quezon being one of the many names i had to memorize for some 4th grade exam alongside his contributions to the jones act and the tydings-mcduffie act

it was only until i became invested in historical movies that i decided to watch the bayaniverse, and it was in this trilogy where i started to look back and revisit my perspective on our national heroes
when we look at history, the act of calling someone a hero or a villain is very reductive, as it ignores the nuances of their decisions and their distinct worldviews and beliefs
the philippines is not exempt from this at all

in the context of the bayaniverse, these people (luna, goyo, quezon) are inept and egotistical at best, and downright criminal at worst, but put them in a movement, and you have the spirit of the filipino revolution, proud and waving the flag
and despite their flaws, that does not erase the efforts they've done for an independent republic
tarog, with quezon, aimed to showcase both his flaws and his accomplishments in a way that piques our interest and to go to our local library and read up on our history

we are directly anchored in through joven and his family, and through him, we get to interact with the true nature of quezon, one that, just as tarog intended, is not displayed in bullet text or powerpoint
he is a con man who thrives in confidence and does whatever is necessary, because to him, politics is a game of chess
he anticipates, he strategizes, and takes advantage of weakness
he is thrust into a system that benefits those in power, and considering his eagerness to satiate his thirst for power, he uses that system to gain complete control of his circle and of the country

its use of satire and the bravado of 1920s silent film aesthetic at certain points complements the big personality of quezon, immediately making it the most unique out of the trilogy, where the prior films were conventional war epics, rather showcasing the action of politics than the action of bloodshed, but it remains as violent and intense as the previous films, but what makes quezon stand out is that despite its lens (not borrowed from nepomuceno
), the situations facing the country remain significantly relevant
the constant trips costing filipino taxpayers millions
the fact that we have more politicians than public servants
infighting between two major political players
i forgot who said it, but they mentioned that quezon became the blueprint for modern day trapos, and i can see it
he possesses many of the traits that make up most of our senate, he's a cheat, a liar, and an opportunist
and that's what makes our national heroes so much more interesting
in one way or another, they are not faultless, nor are they necessarily bad people
despite all my shit talk on quezon, the one thing i'll give him credit for was his love for the country, his means justify the ends and he DELIVERS, at the cost of his morality and friendships
the chameleon will always fit in with anyone, but in the end, it will end up with no one, and that is the price one shall pay to become the chameleon

I watched Quezon yesterday in the cinemas
The movie leans heavily on the negative aspects of Manuel L
Quezon’s character—some of which are based on conjecture and lack sufficient historical evidence to be accepted as truth
For example, there is a scene portraying voters booing Emilio Aguinaldo during his presidential campaign, supposedly orchestrated by Quezon
There is no record of this ever happening

The film presents an unbalanced portrayal of the Philippines’ first president, further complicated by a fictional subplot involving made-up characters: journalist Jevon Hernando and his filmmaker daughter, Nadia, who produce campaign videos for Quezon’s presidential run while secretly creating “more honest” versions of each one
I didn’t quite understand the purpose of this subplot, except perhaps to draw parallels with the current political climate
The campaign videos felt like an early version of a “troll farm
” In that sense, the film invites viewers to reflect on the prevalence of “fake news” and how even legitimate journalists can become complicit in the myth-making that surrounds political figures

The film puts forward the idea that “democracy” in the Philippines has never been the real deal because of problematic leaders such as Manuel Quezon, and that the system has always been broken from the start
I think it’s a motivating sentiment; however, the message becomes contrived when retroactively applying it to Quezon’s story
It presents what on the surface appears to be a compelling question: What does it mean when a historical film uses a 21st-century lens to moralize the past
However, I personally disagree with this treatment of history
I believe history should be explored as unfamiliar terrain—something distinct from our present time
Otherwise, how could we genuinely learn anything from it

Imposing a modern framework of social media–driven politics onto the past flattens historical complexity, especially when many Filipinos don’t have access to in-depth historical education or materials outside of school

The story—not just of Manuel Quezon’s life, but of all Filipinos involved in the journey toward Philippine independence, from the formation of the Senate and Congress to the election of the first president—could have offered an inspiring message
Instead, all of this is portrayed as nothing but a sham

The film minimizes the work that Filipino figures did to win our independence by focusing only on the unsavory details of Quezon’s life, such as his love-hate relationship with Osmeña and his ploy to get Governor-General Leonard Wood removed from office
One of the film’s early fictional chapters is titled Quezon vs
Hernando: A Noble Lie, in which Quezon and Hernando debate the concept of “noble lies” using a quote from Plato
Quezon “loses” the argument simply because Hernando can name-drop more philosophers
Many scenes like this follow, reducing Quezon to a caricature—an exaggeratedly naïve and shallow version of himself
Because our history is often told through the lens of our colonizers, mainly Americans, Filipinos have long had a weak sense of the value of freedom and independence
We have been taught to believe that we are not ready to govern ourselves—and perhaps never will be
The film includes Quezon’s famous line: “I would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans
” In a more balanced portrayal, this line could have carried real gravitas
But given the film’s cynical treatment of Quezon, it instead becomes further evidence of his supposed incompetence
This film could have offered audiences a meaningful, alternative way to engage with our history
Instead, it mimicked the very dynamics of social media, reducing historical events into digestible, sensationalized drama

Audiences should ask questions while watching the movie, such as: Is there any genuine historical basis for the scene in which Manuel Quezon asks Vicente Madrigal for a blank check to fund his presidential campaign
What was the purpose of showing a completely fabricated conversation between a drunk Leonard Wood and Manuel Quezon
I also took issue with the portrayal of Emilio Aguinaldo as Quezon’s more “credible” rival

The movie pits Quezon and Aguinaldo against each other, going so far as to fabricate or misrepresent events to exaggerate their rivalry—such as showing Quezon canceling Aguinaldo’s pension during his run against him and framing the loss of Aguinaldo’s farm as a personal attack
Neither of these are based on fact
It is well-documented that Aguinaldo ordered the executions of Andres Bonifacio and Antonio Luna
These are not Quezon’s political inventions—they are part of the historical record
Yet the movie invents an entirely fictional subplot involving Pedro Janolino, who reaches out to Joven Hernando to reveal that Aguinaldo ordered him to kill General Antonio Luna
He is later revealed to be Quezon’s sergeant-at-arms who planted the testimony to sabotage Aguinaldo
In truth, there really was a Pedro Janolino, and he did kill General Luna
He died before Quezon ran for president, and it was Panteleon Garcia who later revealed that Aguinaldo ordered Luna’s murder
Unfortunately, I didn’t find the film well-executed overall
The acting was uneven, with the exception of Jericho Rosales (Quezon) and Mon Confiado (Aguinaldo)
The fictional film-within-a-film subplot featured unlikable, underdeveloped characters, and the “silent movie” aesthetic came across as contrived rather than clever
The production design was also disappointing
The U
colonial period was a stylish era—this is evident from the films and photographs of the time—yet the costumes, especially for the women, lacked both elegance and authenticity
In the end, I couldn’t understand the film’s motive in diminishing Quezon’s legacy

It seemed told through a distinctly pro-American lens: the Filipino masses are depicted as naïve and gullible, unable to grasp what “independence” truly means, while figures like Sergio Osmeña and Manuel Roxas are reduced to mere sidekicks without agency or depth—an unfair portrayal of these important historical figures
Ultimately, the film misses an important opportunity

Instead of offering a richer understanding of our nation’s early struggles for independence, it relies on cynicism, convenient narratives, and present-day parallels that oversimplify history—a treatment that is both disrespectful to Quezon and his descendants and intellectually irresponsible
That half the movie’s plot rests on a fabricated premise should be a sign for audiences to approach it critically
Quezon’s story deserves a more nuanced, intelligent retelling—one that trusts its audience to think deeply, not one that panders to the fleeting attention span of social media

UYY SI CONG TVV
I can see why people would criticize this film for not representing the historical figures for all the actions they've done no matter how good or bad
But pieces of art, which this film is (regardless of quality), are meant to tell a thematic story
For what it is, a film and not a documentary, it uses historical figures as symbols to tell a story of political games and showmanship
They are not who they were in history but are instead used as a backdrop for the inner workings of politics still prevalent to this day

The addition of Joven Hernando as a fictional character, other than being a narrative device, is a clear intention of the story being fictional, not historical, even if his existence being too fantastical at times
Yes, it can be dangerous to represent a historical event/s and handwave all inaccuracies as necessary for drama
You can even call this film straight up propaganda since it aims to tell a certain message with regards to politics, but it still functions as a piece of art
There is a risk of audiences viewing this dramatization as historical fact
A risk that no amount of "fictionalized" disclaimers can make people believe it to be otherwise
Do I believe this film shouldn't have been made for the lack of historical context it portrays
Without this film, I don't think a lot of Filipinos would know who Leonard Wood is
It ignites interests about the historical figures and leads people to seek out the facts themselves
Not a lot of people, me included, were aware of all the shit Wood did as Governor-General prior to this film
I didn't rate this film 3
5/5 for its accuracy, but instead for its pacing and tendency to read between the lines for you
Otherwise, it has great cinematography and a huge improvement in production value compared to Jerrold Tarog's previous films

This is very much a Bayaniverse entry without a single gunshot fired and the blood staining the chests of military men, its framework based on the idea of the camera being the real militant weapon of the times, and the truth is in the edit, despite Tarog rendering the device no weight

There is simply no richness to be dug from ur-text of Quezon—its notions on the gamification of governance blowing cobwebs off a tired and worn out thesis as its attempts to doll up the friction within his praxis end up flat (why the hell is Aguinaldo suddenly so scared of placards)

And so it becomes all the more revealing when Tarog stayed silent during the meltdown of a Quezon descendant at their Powerplant Q&A: a silence that reveals a spinelessness unbecoming of a filmmaker who has made the Definitive Trilogy on behalf of the Filipino People™
A funny nugget of irony now when Quezon clocks Joven as a hypocrite: the witness who records, but never intervenes
I did not care for the caricature of a caricature acting of Jericho and Romnick
I am not sold that that is good acting
I did not care for the kind of simplistic depiction of political backroom talks
Although it’s a scathing recounting of Quezon as a flawed man, it felt like they did not go deeper as to the extent of corruption, its cover up and the real intentions
I wonder now if my opinion on the acting would change if I were satisfied with how the story of Quezon was tackled
Jerrold Tarrog has the magic of making you question history while still allowing you to remain enjoying the film
It makes you want to seek more information about it
It makes you see this people who we have always known since youth, in a new light
But having said that, I still think that Goyo, among the three is his best

Politics in the Philippines has always been a cycle of promises, lies, and abuse of power
This movie shows that Filipino politicians of the past are no different from those we have today
It shows us how we are deceived by lies, how we often choose the worst option when making decisions, and how “utang na loob” continues to shape our choices
The film’s pacing feels unique, almost like an American movie
It focuses on exposing Quezon’s wrongdoings, which explains why his grandson reacted strongly, but as they say, history doesn’t lie
I did find it hard to separate fact from fiction, especially since the place where Emilio was cornered in the movie wasn’t the same as in real life
That can be misleading for viewers, especially students
Nonetheless, I really enjoyed the film; I didn’t even notice how quickly time passed while watching it

It’s a pretty straightforward historical drama, chronicling the rise of a political leader and charting the path for independence for The Philippines

I’ll acknowledge that it doesn’t seem to be a shameless puff piece, and it acknowledges Quezon as a sort of leader without much personal integrity who focuses more on pragmatism, which perhaps may have been important for his goals, even if he was driven largely by ego
There is some interesting artistic flair with the silent film interpretations, which honestly should have been the entire film
Jericho Rosales is excellent at giving that Charlie Sheen vibe

It’s a solid film overall even if it does kind of drag with a bunch of political bullshit that’s admittedly all the same thing of constant backstabbing and alliances, which does sound cool, but it’s a pretty normal historical drama
Just don’t compare Quezon to the first two films in the trilogy and you’ll find something to admire
It stands on its own as a portrait of power and pride, though at times unsure of which face to show
Jericho Rosales walks a tightrope between conviction and caricature, brilliant one moment, baffling the next
The production looks rich and patriotic, but the story doesn’t quite know what it’s fighting for
It wants to build a hero, but forgets to give him a clear battle
Still, if you let it be its own story, you’ll enjoy the echoes of history and the weight of what it tries to say
