"QUEZON" isn't particularly the film that one may expect from writer-director Jerrold Tarog's "Bayaniverse"
The titular hero isn't glorified but examined - with all his strengths and imperfections
History, as rich as it gets, immortalizes the gripping and controversial facets of the beloved statesman that unsurprisingly still echo up to this day

Exceptionally played by Urian winner Jericho Rosales, we get to see the might, influence, charisma, narcissism, lies, and betrayals of Philippines' second president through his acting force and vulnerability
The penchant to roll the classic 4:3 movie aspect ratio in its short films and the interesting camera pans during the Congress election strategies a la chess moves are some of its strong suits
Art and production designs, although a good addition, can be improved to perfectly embody its era

Bearing its creative license, it dramatizes the calculated games and internal conflicts through (at times confusing) non-linear storytelling with hefty dialogues and politicking narratives that can be cut down in exchange for more warranted depictions of political effects to the society under the eight-year regime, apart from showcasing people's ignorance of the very notion of independence
Now that would be more compelling and cathartic

Rosales truly leads the pack but it's indubitable that every featured artist (Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Cris Villanueva, Benjamin Alves, Karylle, and even its import Iain Glen to name a few) pours their heart to the material
A call to action in these trying times, may this push us to demand for a better nation

Casey and the Philippines
Heroes are still humans

This realism makes the film even powerful

an aguinaldo propaganda in the guise of a quezon biopic
this film is really all about perception
how quezon weaponized perception
and most importantly on how this film presents aguinaldo in stark contrast to how he was presented in heneral luna
i hated that aguinaldo presented in the past film but i can’t help but sympathize with him in this one
but this is what this film wants it to be and that “aguinaldo propaganda” concludes not only the movie, but the franchise altogether

i kept thinking that maybe there remains in aguinaldo a semblance of heroism especially in that one specific scene where he chose not to introduce quezon’s alleged first wife and just use her as a pawn
or maybe it was the emphasis on how his candidacy for presidency was a mere heed of duty and not out of lust for power
or maybe i felt bad because he was gradually yet loudly stripped of power
or maybe just the culmination of every vengeful act of quezon against him
or maybe it’s just easier to accept him as a lesser evil
the idea of resonating and accepting someone merely because they are a lesser evil is just plain foolishness in theory
even the idea of a “lesser evil” just seems to transcend all bounds of rationality
did we bring that idea into conception as a cry for help
a cry for hope
it’s really easier to side with someone
as a country who remains deep in suffering, misery loves company i guess
but is this really all that we deserve

'The Noble Lie'
This is one of the lines that resonated with me after watching the film
The mere fact that these traditional politicians boil everything that they do down to this idea of doing questionable means towards a 'good end' is not only narcissistic but also dangerous at best
These people genuinely believe that a lie could be considered 'noble'
Meaning, what is ethically right for them is already skewed, and that conscience no longer plays a role in the crux of their actions

Rosales' Quezon, even at the very end of the film, embodied this rotten mentality, thoroughly absorbed in the idea of being the 'Great Savior' that the Philippines needed for its independence--even at the expense of losing the true meaning of the word
Truly a magnificent end to the 'bayaniverse' trilogy, showcasing a 'war' that is not fought in the front (compared to 'Heneral Luna' and 'Goyo')
A war that is played behind cunning speeches and charming smiles, but is dangerous all the same
Not gonna lie, I thoroughly enjoyed Quezon and Osmena's dynamics (iykyk)
Will definitely be watching again

Isa sa mga huli sa bayani trilogy ni Jerrold Tarog sums everything up
Imahe ni Quezon na akala natin na perpektong tao siya, ay malayo sa katotohanan
Ang mga itinuturing nating bayani ay meron at merong mga kamalian
Pakita sa pelikulang ito na ang pulitiko ay laro lamang ng mga ilan para sa sarili at di para sa tao, di para sa bayan
Ang satirang mapapaisip ka kung and independensya ay tunay o nakatanikala pa tayo sa mga banyaga
Ano nga ba ang independensya sa kasalukuyang panahon ngayon
Kung independensya ay di kalayaan, di tayo malaya
Isang kakaibang pelikula na dapat tuloy pa na pag-usapan ng tao at di lamang ipagbawalan dahil lamang sa pamilyang nakinabang sa imahe na ibinigay sa kanilang ninunong Quezon
Kahit nga si Quezon ay biktima dahil sa pananaw na sumabay at makilaro sa sistema upang sana matupad ang kalayaan
Ngunit nilubog siya hanggang hindi na siya kailangan ng mga banyaga
Patuloy sana ang mga pelikulang ganito

weakest in the trilogy but still good
Sometimes the film doesn't know if it wants to be a political satire or a historical biographical film
I think the film has true promise
Quezon has always been quite a controversial figure of the early fight for true Philippine independence
He did as much good and as much bad if you really think deeply about it BUT the film is just presented in such a dense way
In posits there is true good in Politics
Even sections of actual criticism in the film is really hampered by Tarrog's insistence of the right 'governance'
The lack of a real alternative or an actual in depth conversations that does not really fall into this guise of moral grandstanding is prevalent that it was so eyeroll inducing
You can read philosophies and still be the worst person ever - a college with Liberal Arts make you learn that quickly
If Quezon did not win, what does Aguinaldo can offer in the table that he himself had not done too
Rather film, just villainizes Quezon's insistence to lead
One good example of the film's insistence for moralistic bent but lack of actual 'analysis' is the film's villainization of Quezon's use of his connection
That is what connections are for
To create this dynamic give and take but it oh no, that is bad - because he can make so much campaign materials

It never really delivered on the fact on what would become the Nacionalista Party lead to one of the biggest ultra-majority in the Philippine's History, a familiar sight if anyone has lived to tell in the Duterte era Congress
In fact, the film kinda glosses the fact that this same majority lead the changes in the constitution that inadvertently resulted to the Marcos Dictatorship
In fact, I do think the reason there are many rich families interested in Government is because how they were able to really to enter political spaces during this time
Like for a film that prides itself as critical, it always uses these weak arguments to posit the rather double face attitude of Quezon
I was grasping straws, because it uses the worst criticisms (ad hominems) rather than just actually pulling real punches that is still present in the current Philippine political space
It just bats this idea that Quezon wants the presidency is bad (not really bad), because he wants it no matter what
His machination is bad since he is not truthful about his intention
It literally is true facts
Quezon is a problematic and prolific muckraker, that most of what we hate about Aguinaldo is actually rooted towards his campaign against him
That is attested but a lot of actual paper trails sadly has been destroyed by the war of 45
The film posits that is bad
(not necessarily) but the problem here is that the film also plays out the same muckraking as noble against some of his 'enemies' since they it's not out there
Like come-on now film
That is just plain stupidity at this point
You cannot just make this two sides of the coin when it's practically the same side

I also hate how the film hates Quezon since he is sly about his approach on things but equally loves the American because of their you ready sine clearly the average filipino does not know the word for Independence
THIS SHOULD BE ABOUT THE LEADERS to begin with
Another instance of the film going for the soft analysis over real question of readiness with the leadership
And also, it really gives so much pass for the Americans and how they handled the Philippines, because they are well-meaning apparently
Suddenly, the atrocities is just a side comment here and there
Even Aguinaldo, who could have been more complex as a character himself is just plainly glorified
I just feel there is so much more here that could have been made to make this actually critical in a sense that in actually is talking about things that would still be prevalent in our life and all
On a lighter mode, Good performances though
Echo does well
I personally think certain actors looked closer to the very Hispanized Quezon but has character for it
He kinda performed really well and the cavalcade of supporting role was a welcome surprise
I personally think the film did well visually and editing wise, which is a lot for a local film
The costuming though is really bad - a lot of badly fitted suits
I will still recommend this BUT with a deep reading about Quezon's role in PHI history tbh
It is important to look at this with a more critical eyes since this takes a lot of true issues about Quezon but in a way that feels misguided tbh

Glad TBA had the budget to export Iain Glen to give an Off-Broadway theatre performance that only serves as a functional foil for a domineering Filipino icon
Speaking of, Rosales thankfully did not rely on the heroic gravitas of John Arcilla's General Luna and playful charm of Paulo Avelino's Goyo
Instead, he leans on the spiteful energy and conniving instincts of a Peter Sellers character, which fits on the pseudo-satirical bite that this Bayaniverse entry tries to achieve
It is not the best of the three
(In fact, it is the most eyebrow-raising but liberating of them
) Yet, if it spawns discussion of what is truth or fiction, satire or reality, heroism or populism, and identity or heritage, then it more than succeeds its intentions or un-intentions

The third installment of the Bayani-verse franchise yet again provides a compelling portrayal of another pivotal figure in Philippine history
Jericho and Karylle really stood out in their roles as President Manuel L
Quezon and First Lady Aurora Quezon
I particularly enjoyed the unraveling of the Aguinaldo vs
Quezon showdown in 1935, a satisfying karmic payback for the atrocities Aguinaldo did in the past
Understandably, the movie was not as action packed as its predecessors given that its events occurred post-Philippine revolution

But I found the movie’s exposition of the political drama at that time to have sufficiently made up for the lack of gunshots and wars as a backdropWhile the movie is set in the ‘20s-‘30s, “Quezon” poignantly mirrors the patronage and personality politics that continue to fester our country today
It ultimately makes one realize that our nation’s forefathers are as equally to be blamed, if not more, for the sorry state of our government today
Note: There is a post-credit scene
Made me realize that even now we are still being played by the same machineries and tricks, how those in power can bend politics around their fingers and still call it leadership
At the same time, leaves me confused about which side holds the truth

I'm confident in the production's handling of historical accuracy, and one can only wish the production team well, hoping the highest sense of responsibility was employed to achieve that benchmark
Technically, this film is no joke—it's genuinely strong
Pulling off the production requirements for historical films is incredibly difficult, but what amazes me about director Jerrold Tarog is his profound sense of vision
It is creative, yet direct enough to clearly tell the narrative to a broad audience
Narrative-wise, the "film within a film" trope is a good idea, though it needs some polishing to make the 'buddy and soul' arc more impactful
Despite needing that refinement, it remains a highly creative approach to the story
While I struggle to engage during the very first few minutes, from my lens, this is a great film
It is strong enough to celebrate the Bayaniverse's impact and secure its future

Quezon, despite having good intentions for the growth and development of the Phillipines, did not hold back from getting his hands dirty in playing the game of politics

The quote “Being a hero is all about perception” really summarizes Quezon’s rise to power
A brilliant film nonetheless

This movie, contrary to the extreme reactions of some of Quezon’s descendants, actually deepens the former president’s characterization beyond merely being the ‘Commonwealth president’ and the ‘Father of the national language
’ The era Quezon lived in was unlike any other, and its politicians were complex, multifaceted characters navigating personal ambitions along with the demands of governing a fledgling nation
Jerrold Tarog must be commended for his continued examination of the nation’s founding fathers - and this is a fitting, albeit unofficial, conclusion to his ‘Bayaniverse’ trilogy
All that for what, shits and giggles
I honestly am very disappointed by this movie
How was this movie PG, there were swear words every five seconds and smoking in every room
Film makers that continue to fumble when they have a book, a short story, a myth, or literally HISTORY, as reference material continues to baffle me
What a waste of resources and potential
These events happened already
Why the need to add fictional elements for thematic purposes
Was adding fictional character/s necessary, if their goal was to educate our generation of who Quezon really was
And why include flashbacks inside the movie, when we are already looking back into the past
It adds confusion as to where we are in the plot
I did not like the ugly art deco designs in the flashback scenes and as part of the office design
The over contoured faces
Using “Hallelujah Chorus” as background music during the signing of the Tydings-McDuffie Act was tasteless
Please try to be more imaginative next time
American characters (like Wood) being portrayed as morally upright in contrast with Quezon’s portrayal of character should be talked about more
It implies white supremacy and colonial mentality
Let’s not do that all over again :)There was a scene where they brought out Quezon’s first wife for five seconds, for what
Was the goal to empower women or to further impose traditional gender roles where women are pushed to the sidelines
She was dismissed, shrugged from the plot
Please do better next time
This movie had the potential to call out the dirty elections, spoils system, traditional politics, systematic corruption, and imperialism
The very same issues they faced (or should I say reinforced
) before that we still face today
While I do commend the morally stained portrayal of Quezon as it serves as a lesson to not idolize individuals (especially government officials)
However, the public may be misled to believe this fictional plot points that are conveniently dramatic
We should not tolerate or promote historical distortion in media
It would be so much better to simply provide the public a historical film that adheres to historical documents and facts
These are just my opinions

HAHAHAHAH as far as mainstream pinoy cinema goes, this is a pretty great takedown of the idea of the "great man" as told in the history textbooks that we grew up with

the act of framing manuel quezon's shenanigans in his rise to power as one of the seeds that bore our nation's problems in the present is a pretty brave and bold move for a big budget, mainstream studio film to take, especially in the context of our local cinema

what i think makes quezon work so well is how, unlike the previous two films, it still plots out a clear narrative without losing sight of its unifying thread despite chronicling more than decade's worth of history

the unfortunate caveat to all of this is, of course, the loss of focus on other significant political and social players during this time, such as the sakdalista movement, as well as the downplaying of the strength and significance of the presidential campaign of gregorio aglipay, who himself won two provinces, despite the insignificance that the film portrays him with

despite all that, for what it is, jerrold tarog's quezon is still one of the most exciting filipino releases in recent memory, and the inevitable role it will play in the further reassessment of the way we've learned our history and the eventual reckoning with it will be one that i will be watching out for
Out of all the films in this trilogy, I think Quezon captures the thesis Tarog's take on the filipino hero the best
Comparing it to Luna and especially Goyo, Quezon seems to be more overt with its critique on filipino politics and the filipino people as spectators of what goes on in our society

Though, seemingly with the other films in this trilogy, its message is served to its audience on a silver platter (some would say very preachy) but I guess it's a hard responsibility to take as a directior especially with how a lot of people took Luna's messaging
So in a way that proves the message of the movie
How could the filipino understand freedom if they are deprived of learning about it

also the performances were so good, Jericho Rosales' charisma and his ability to look so scary and eerie in the most tense situations *chefs kiss* in another note, teasing magsaysay in a post credit scene like the next solo movie in the marvel cinematic universe is so funny

While Quezon definitely has less action compared to Heneral Luna and Goyo, the other films in the “Bayaniverse,” I was not bored at all
The pacing might be gentler, but the storytelling and performances more than make up for it
The cast delivered strong portrayals that captured both the humanity and complexity of the historical figures, and the musical score complemented the drama beautifully
The production values were impressive as well
They may not be Hollywood-level in terms of scale, but they are undeniably Filipino in spirit and craftsmanship
You can really feel the trademark quality of TBA Studios throughout
As someone who’s a Filipino history nerd, I really appreciated how this film shed light on another side of Manuel L
Quezon, one that’s often overshadowed by his more famous political achievements

I also just learned that Quezon was a lawyer, and as a lawyer myself, it was fascinating to see how he was able to “play the game,” navigating from being a trial lawyer to eventually becoming the President of the Philippines
It added another layer of depth and respect for his intellect and political skill
Having just been to Bataan last week for a historical and heritage trip, I felt an even deeper connection to the story and the period it depicted
I was also fortunate enough to have seen Quezon’s Game a few years ago, and watching Quezon felt like seeing a grander, more expansive retelling of that same chapter in our history
The scope, emotion, and context were all heightened, giving a broader and richer perspective on Quezon’s legacy
Overall, Quezon might not rely on action or spectacle, but it delivers a story that deepens our understanding of one of the key figures in our nation’s history

sinaunang yaoi is crazy bruh The first thing that really came to mind when I was watching this movie was the stylistic choice it decided to take on
The story-telling was incredible, following the movies made by Nadia with some scenes being her movie, while others being "real life"
The way scenes were shot in "real life" in the style of a silent movie was genuinely so unique to me that it caught my eye
The merge of styles through out the entire movie all fit perfectly as well as contrasted each other well
Secondly, which is probably the most obvious, I enjoyed the perspective this movie gives towards not just Quezon but politics in general
I have heard the criticism about the fantasies this movie merges into what is the "truth", but I argue that is the point
The proper approach to movies like this is that after watching it, it should encourage you to research on your own
Be interested, be curious, and compare it to the life we live in
It brings Filipinos awareness back to the Philippines and our history
It may not all be true, but it sure is interesting
Of course, I have to mention the incredible acting of Jericho Rosales, Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Therese Malvar, and the rest of the amazing cast
They brought these characters to life
There was a lot of debate about whether or not Jericho Rosales was the right fit for Quezon, but he did astoundingly well
I admire his efforts to be as true to life as he could be, accent and all
I am extremely attached to the style this movie had
Its use of colors, cinematography, and even sound were foundational to the narrative
The final scene, with quezon's quote of "I am the Filipino People, I am the Philippines
" brought chills all over my body
The envy in his voice when he questions why Osmeña was blessed with a healthy body and him not made me also question the irony of their story
It reminds me that sins are also reflected in the body
Wonderful movie, it brings about questions that we may never get answers to, and thoughts we may never complete
A beautiful and extravagantly painted picture of the past, that now leaves an impression on our present and the actions for our future

The Questions of QuezonThroughout Jerold Tarog's trilogy, he raises important questions about heroism — and in Quezon (2025), he explores it not as an absolute truth but as a matter of perception
Sa dami ng na-trigger at nabuong kontrobersya, it begs the question: handa na nga ba tayo sa malayang diskusyon tungkol dito
” The very ideal that Quezon and his forerunners fought and died for is finally within reach — pero paano ito aabutin ng bagong magiging presidente
The film thrives in the space between conflicting morals, fitting for a morally obsessed country riddled with corruption
Alin nga ba ang mas epektibo
Idealismo or realidad
The film is generous in portraying the old man's charm, eloquence, and impeccable sense of style
But in true Tarog fashion, he wasn't safe from being questioned either
Beneath the charisma lies his vanity, a leader fully aware of his strength and uses it to advance his ambitions -- whether for his country or for himself, who knows
Tarog's meta approach, blending fiction and history is a tricky but effective device
Nadia's films-within-the-film reveal two sides of the story, the same way Tarog does throughout his trilogy
The film doesn’t just retell the past; it exposes how the narratives we accept as truth are constructed
Gaano nga ba kalaki ang papel ng media, pelikula, o ngayon, ng TikTok sa politika ng bansa
What remains unclear, however, is the role of the Americans in the narrative
I didn’t quite appreciate how Governor Wood sort of became a "father figure" to the away-bati childishness of Quezon and Osmeña
Wasn’t this separation engineered by the ’Kano themselves
In today's battle against fake news, sensationalism and historical accuracy, Quezon's creative licenses may be a double-edged sword
But honestly
To hell with it
It's a triumph of Filipino filmmaking
It provokes, divides, and gets us all talking
Quezon doesn’t claim to be the truth, but it forces us to question who gets to tell it
So really, what is there to lose
---------On a lighter note, as a tubong Quezon myself, I have to say — Echo nailed Quezon’s American English accent of that time, but not quite his Tayabasing Tagalog

Quezon provides an unbiased but contentious retelling of the titular character’s rise and fall in Philippine politics, his undeniable influence and charm, and his lasting impact in the country’s bid for independence
Despite the title, the film was not a glorification, but a critique on the character that is Manuel L
Quezon, the second president of the Philippines
Because while it was he who sought for Philippine independence, history tells us he might have done it in the not so cleanest of ways
While charming and influential, he was also brutal, unrelenting, and felt like he was Thanos or Darth Vader at times
The storytelling was great
Using film to backtrack the history of Quezon from his humble beginnings to his rise to presidency was really a good touch
It also really helped in presenting the exposition and Philippine history without it seeming like it was forced
It was like watching an educational film within a film

It was really paced well, too, as it divided chapters of Quezon’s life based on his political enemies at the time – it was like watching him go up the political ranks as he beat one adversary after another
Each scene felt intentional and it didn’t feel like 2 hours have passed
Like any other historical account, this film took some big creative liberties as well
While it could be really good for dramatic effect and inducing a reaction, it could also spark controversy and be misconstrued as the truth
With this, I thought some of the choices could’ve stuck to the truth and just exaggerated them a bit
But all in all, Quezon is a great film for both the casual audience and history buffs
It’s a good critique on the character of Manuel Quezon and as well as on all the political figures surrounding him at the time
At the same time, it’s also a good way to learn about the history of the Philippines, its political landscape, and its journey to independence

i really wanted to love this film, i was looking forward to it
i did enjoy watching it, both as a film and for its historical subject
the performances were really good, i can see that the actors really enjoyed playing their roles
the story was a bit meta as well which i liked
but the film had a lot going for it that really held it back
the production felt rushed
the actor for wood was wasted with so few scenes showing him
the story also spanned too wide a period, leaving no room for additional context as to what was happening in the film
i knew the historical context behind those scenes, but i doubt the same can be said of the general public
then there's the narrative itself
one issue that really bothers me with this trilogy is how they portray the americans as reasonable
that scene where wood was talking to some locals and how they exclaimed that independence was good enough to eat was icky
what exactly is that scene supposed to mean
it feels patronizing
and how they felt quezon even more so
that he was manipulative, shrewd, was already known
the director said he wanted to humanize him
but quezon had no redeeming qualities in the film
he had no arc
actually, if you look at all three movies, all the leading characters had no arcs
they lived and ended their films with nothing about them having changed, nor something interesting shown about them
luna was a hothead, goyo was a womanizer, and quezon was conniving
luna being this unwavering patriot didnt make sense to me
he ratted out on the katipunan at first, and only joined the revolution when it was finally against the americans

goyo felt too small a figure that even in his own film, the focus wasnt on him, it was on aguinaldo and mabini (granted, that the trilogy was more of aguinaldo's arc, than the figures important to his story)
and quezon, for all his and his colleagues' shrewdness, won ph independence from a country so reluctant to recognize it
that it played into their ambition shouldnt faze us from recognizing the monumental task ahead of them
these figures are not beyond reproach, nor are the films wrong from portraying them the way they were portrayed
there are just elements in these films, that quezon really amplify, that prevent them from reaching their potential
these movies have moved the discourse, both in history and in film far, but could not any further

It’s a masterfully crafted yet morally complex film that dares to strip a national hero of sanctity and reveal him as flawed, strategic, and deeply human
Visually stunning and bold in its storytelling, it reimagines Quezon not as a savior, but as the architect of the very system that made such saviors necessary
Jericho Rosales delivers a remarkable performance—his Quezon feels layered, seamlessly shifting from statesman to tactician with effortless charm
You can sense the performance behind the persona, the fragility behind the power
For me, Quezon isn’t really a takedown of a hero; it’s a mirror
It forces us to see how the leaders we admire, and even the systems we live in, are built by people as fragile and flawed as we are
And maybe that’s what makes it sting—because it feels true

Tarog’s bayaniverse trilogy ends in a more implicating interpretation of a hero than his two previous films
There is no ambiguity in Quezon’s machiavellian journey to power
Rosales treads close to a mere impersonation while Confiado shines through his restraint
Quezon’s portrayal is flat compared to Luna’s and Goyo’s because unlike the latter, the former is not portrayed as a human with flaws but simply a wretched opportunist fueled by greed and ego
Luna’s populist portrayal is balanced with his sincere desire to fight colonialism
Goyo’s naïveté is tempered by his youthful idealism
Quezon, on the other hand, shows no redeeming factor
All in all, the conclusion to the trilogy reiterates that meeting your heroes is less glamorous than it seems

What a wonderfully nasty piece of work that portrays things in such a devilishly entertaining way
It was fun watching the politics in this movie portrayed in such a darkly comedic, performative, and theatrical way (especially the first half)
The way everything seems so ultra rehearsed, the way they move, the way they’re blocked, etc
together with some lively camera work created for such a weirdly unserious yet engaging experience
Though its chronological sequencing was a bit confusing at the start, and it’s pretty easy to get lost in what point of time we’re in

It’s funny too because these people are determining the future and current state of the country, yet it’s just a game to them; a stupidly intricate, dangerous game for power on who yaps and complains the loudest, all while Americans meddle with everything (as they always have), so it was over when Quezon stated that he learned from them
The biggest compliment I’d give is how this movie lowkey had some balls
I did NOT expect it to paint characters the way they did
They imply a shocking amount of things, and just straight up show how disgusting and slimy people were, albeit really smart and strategic for the worse
The foundation of this country, and its current systems have always been stained by foreigners (particularly the Americans), and it continues to be
Deny it all you want, the worst country in the world has that much power because it convinced the world that it does
The same way the loudest people always have, or end up, with some level of power
That’s Philippine politics for y’all; a loud, nasty, slimy game where the occupiers are always somehow the winners despite what people want to believe
Where the nastiest ones always somehow win, and it’s because they know how to play this deranged, ugly game incredibly well
A game that sadly demands you surrender your morals for survival, and that survival turns into a disgusting lust for power
The worst guy you know won the game because the system favors them

It’s been a while since we’ve seen a political film that brings us back to our senses and challenges what it means to be patriotic
(Maybe Gomburza tho) Quezon is a fresh film that introspects on the evils in both society and ourselves, and how we even play our role in corruption
I loved that Quezon is humanized as someone who had to play the game against bigger evils
Props to the super creative use of storytelling devices and other details, like Joven (journalist), newspapers, and films (all seemingly inspired from Citizen Kane)
Much like Kane too, Quezon’s character reveals itself and his ambitions piece by piece, shifting our perception of him until his death
The film does quite have a spoonfed narrative though
The script tends to overexplain its themes and motivations
Great that it makes everything more digestible to the general public, but it also takes away some subtlety
The cast is solid and GOATEDD, and special shoutout to DOP Pong Ignacio
Lighting and cameras were crazy
The production design also makes everything feels so real
Excited for the next Bayaniverse
campy, total 180 of typical 'Bayani' films and serves as like a formal apology to Aguinaldo
This film was indeed a pandora's box as how Mr
Avancena worded it
I came into the movie theater full of enthusiasm to watch it, but I came out full of questions, undecided if I was to believe the narrative, and unsatisfied
Upon going home, I had to research the next days about the veracity of this film
The film juxtaposed several elements of different timeframes such as colorized and non-colorized cinema to show the antagonist Quezon and the underdog Osmena narrative
It showed how Quezon tried to politick the Filipinos and Osmena (the Americans included)just to gain the seat for President
This also portrayed that patronage politics might have started in Quezon's time
However, just like the other Bayaniverse series, it is for the viewer to discern which part of the film was true or not because the disclaimer was only put in the beginning of the film
Thus, the viewers nee to read and research further

After watching the film, I also had the thought that publishing a book might not do so much after the trending phase of this film because in the era of social media, a book would not reach the same level of viewers that the film would reach especially if this will be released on online streaming platforms
On my part, it would be better if I would be able to read the researched part even on a blog online
The cast played well on their roles as Osmena, Quezon, and Aguinaldo
Other made up characters like Nadia and Joven, complemented the storyline
There was even a point where Nadia herself made fun of Quezon's traits
The main characters copied even the intonation of the politicians
Overall, it was a good film, but for a full length film, it feels incomplete
For a film just to end with "I am the Philippines", it feels unnatural
Well and good, Quezon died in America so there was really no good ending
But given that this was a mix of fiction and history, I hope they showed at least a memory of Quezon's memorial
the way no one gaf when cong was on screen
hindi na bago sa pilipinas ang konsepto ng isang “bayani” na magbibigay ng katarungan at pagbabago sa bansang sinilangan

hindi na bago ang pagbibitiw ng mga mahalimuyak na mga salita na may pagkukulang naman sa esensya, para lang linlangin ang taumbayan na sumapi at maniwala na may solusyon pa sa crisis na kanilang hinaharap
katulad nalang ng pagbibitiw ni quezon sa mga salitang “independencia” at “demokrasya,” na pinangako niyang maikakamit ng taumbayan kung makukuha niya ang kapangyarihan na kanyang inaasam
ngunit, hindi ang mga politikang ito ang magbibigay sa’tin ng tunay na independencia at demokrasya— tayo, bilang taumbayan, ang tunay na makakapagsulong ng karapatan natin sa demokrasya’t kasarinlan
hanggang ngayon, ramdam pa rin natin ang bakas ng imperyalismo sa bansa

ngunit, walang pagkakataon ang ordinaryong pilipino na pagtuunan ng pansin ang mga bagay na iyan dahil tayo’y nakakulong sa isang sistemang neoliberalismo na hindi nanghihikayat ng malayang pagsasalita at pagpupuna sa mga taong nakaupo sa trono ng sakim at korap na kapangyarihan
power should always emanate from the people and not from the politicians who swore to serve us
even if these “great” heroes have contributed to some important things in our country, we must always remember to never glorify them for simply doing their responsibilities

true heroism consists not in holding such power but in selflessly using it for the welfare of the people (rightfully so), and it is upon us to remind these “heroes” that real greatness pertains to the Filipino people who continue to fight, hope, and demand a better nation
maybe when we get to that point, we will be able to comprehend the full realization of our democracy

I am leaving here my thoughts I made on my notepad, if it seems very essay-ish and inaccurate I am sorry I tried my best to write my thoughts 4 hours after watching the film
Here it is:“Hindi ka hari
”“Sigurado ka
”In this film we unravel the first President of the Philippines in a time where we never really knew what independence or being free meant
It was just simply a glittery word we acquainted with being free from Americans and establishing our own rule
As far as I am aware 1935 was an establishment of a commonwealth to transition to 1946 which was our genuine independence as a nation

We see this film through a sort of journalistic storytelling lenses of Joven Hernando (a fictional character), as he threads through what he went through prior to this film and the aftermath of Goyo towards the time he was reporting Quezon’s senatorial endeavors, his run for presidency, and unspooling the threads of who and what Quezon is
What is Politics
What is Patronage Politics
Politics has roots in Aristotle’s work, Politika, a Greek word which consequently means things concerning the polis (city)
It is the ability by which one can use power, or direct influences to an individual, group, community, or a nation that a person “doing politics” busy themselves with
This occurs at all levels of a society
Now what is patronage politics
Associations, positions, promotions, and contracts are based on personal connections and friendships rather than pure merit
This is also what we call the padrino system or clientelism
Why am I highlighting this
You may think of our so called Bayanis as the glorified images they were portrayed as and made up to be by textbooks, anecdotes, and so on
But, they are just as horrid and grotesque as any 21st century politician can be
As Quezon believed it, it was a game, and the trick was to cheat it
Noble LiesIn the movie we see Joven and Quezon have a short argument about truth, their difference, and why it matters when they’ve attained a victory for independence or freedom
They reference many classic texts and philosophical concepts from which Quezon mentioned “mentira noble”, Spanish for a noble lie
This is a concept derived from Plato’s ‘The Republic’ in which Plato discusses that societies are built on such lies
If the masses believe in something (independence), then there is something to fight for
(Krause, 2019) Which in the film he utilizes as a way to earn power and along the way do some good for those who have placed his trust on him

Joven’s dialogue and realizations in contrast to this throughout the film reflects the audience’s gradual disposition over what can we believe from Quezon or in contemporary times, those who claim to have the nation’s best interests
Are Filipinos that fucking stupid
The humor in the film is great

Satire doesn’t necessarily mean a quality of being funny but just the moments that are spread sporadically throughout the film makes you smile and chuckle while also grappling with how twisted the butt of the jokes are

There is this moment when Leonard Wood who went on a trip around the Philippines to survey whether the Filipinos were truly capable of independence asked a few townspeople along with his translator if they knew what independence meant, to which one replied that: “They become full (their stomach) from the thought of it,” I couldn’t help but laugh and overhear a chuckle from 1 other watcher besides me
(Albeit what I quoted is not direct as I am struggling remembering the exact line
)So the question is are Filipinos stupid
We believe the propagandas, the persuasive anecdotes, what others say, and what we say because we hope for nothing but the best for all of us
It is not our fault that those we place our trust in chooses to betray us—the same way Quezon did to Joven, the same way Quezon did to Aguinaldo, and the same way Aguinaldo did to Luna and Bonifacio
I cannot stress how we’re stuck in this perpetual loop and how deep-rooted such issue is
Alas, human nature and greed is a mystical thing, it surpasses all reasoning and thought
But, in this day and age, if you cannot use history and the information at your disposal to think rationally—you are a stupid Filipino
The WomenWhat is Aurora Quezon, Maria Agoncillo, and Carmen and Nadia Hernando’s role in all of this
Well, to show the intricacies and persistence of women who stand at the shadows of history
Aurora Quezon, behind the scenes is a woman who could stand her ground at the same level as Manuel Quezon
Maria Agoncillo, becomes Aguinaldo’s anchor as he goes through the loss and dirty tactics done by Quezon
Carmen and Nadia are smart women whose integrity and careers are supported by their husband in a time where women were otherwise discouraged
An article by the Lifestyle Inquirer goes into interviews with the respective actresses and provides valuable insight for these characters and how important they are
You can search for it
With that, I hope to soon see a movie about a female hero, as the director also hopes to do if given the chance
Quezon has a husband, OsmenaThey should get married, honestly
They bicker and make up like a husband and his wife would
The parallels run deep, friend or foe, tampuhan, the ancient and homosexual version of Bongbong and Sara
You will understand what I mean when you see the film, it sounds diabolical, I know
Their dynamic is like two academic rivals who do nothing but outdo each other and try to tolerate each other and when hurt make up for it

For instance, the Hare-Hawes-Cutting Act and the blatant copying of assignment but slightly changing the wording with the consequent Tydings-McDuffie Act all because Quezon wanted the credit when Hare-Hawes-Cutting was his idea
Finally…“Maybe it’s about proving what you can do, instead of proving what is right
” — Carmen HernandoShe’s right, at the end of the day why should these politicians never fulfill and serve their own interests
At this point it is an interplay of psychological warfare, scheming, power play, and gaining something out of their endeavors whether it be favors, money, or something to leverage themselves further
But how will we, as a country move on forward with confidence and trust towards those who govern us when betrayal is in the table
When the nation’s interests aren’t fulfilled
When they are the sole reason we can’t get ourselves out of this damning rut
Perhaps this 21st century we ask, if there is a 22nd century will the Filipinos then, be able to live a better life
Because I have seen enough to say that in my lifetime at least, it’s never going to get any better
Suffice to say, I loved this film
I availed of the ₱ 250
00 discount allowed for students and teachers, and I did not feel like I wasted money at all
If we talk about the technical aspects like: the direction, music, composition, casting, and wardrobe, they were all perfect
You’ll never think throughout watching that they chickened out with giving Quezon (2025) huge production value
In a time where corruption is rampant in Philippine politics, well in retrospect it has always been, this film could not be any more relevant and timely
I implore everyone to support Filipino film and cinema, as they are a treasure trove of bright and brimming ideas awaiting audiences to see them

A fitting conclusion to Tarog's trilogy attempting to define the Filipino hero: Quezon combines the heat of Heneral Luna and the introspection of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral
The film holds firm to the trilogy's assertion that our national heroes are not without fault, and that, perhaps, we regained our independence partly because of those faults
Manuel Quezon—like Luna and Del Pilar—feels flesh and blood here, capable of both heroism and monstrosities

Jerrold Tarog closes his Bayaniverse trilogy with Quezon, a sharp, ambitious political drama that trades the gunfire of Heneral Luna and Goyo for quieter battles fought through charm, rhetoric, and image
Jericho Rosales completely disappears into the role, giving a performance that’s both commanding and unsettling
He plays Quezon not as a spotless hero but as a man who understands how leadership relies on performance
The film doesn’t glorify him; it examines him
It shows how charisma can inspire and manipulate at the same time, and how power often hides behind elegance
The movie looks beautiful, with careful production design, steady pacing, and clean editing that keeps even long political exchanges engaging
Tarog’s direction is thoughtful and confident, peeling back Quezon’s myth not to tear it down but to reveal the man underneath that’s ambitious, flawed, and burdened by what it takes to lead

I believe in the artistic direction of the crew behind Quezon
Tarog’s willingness to treat a towering historical figure such as Manuel L
Quezon not as a flawless hero, but as a complex, ambitious individual, gives the film a bracingly fresh tone
The production design, pacing and cinematography all feel meticulously crafted, it’s clear the team sought to challenge the idea of grand national myth and instead expose the power-games behind it
In doing so, Quezon invites us to see how legacy is manufactured, and how leadership is as much performance as service
I found the portrayal compelling and the moral ambiguity rich, making the film more than just a biopic
It becomes a meditation on nationhood, ambition and compromise

The movie immediately brought to mind the political intrigue of the Netflix series House of Cards, but infused with the signature Tarog humor and quips
This is consistent with the entire "Bayaniverse" Trilogy
The deconstruction of our national heroes and figures is a perfect use of cinema in retelling history
By humanizing them into characters with their own beliefs, goals, egos, and flaws, the film makes them relatable
While creative and fictional liberties were certainly taken, the general gist, and hopefully the core message of the story will be received and resonate well with the audience
Also, on a final note: what the hell, Magsaysay next

"​The final lines of the film perfectly encapsulate the kind of person Manuel Luis Quezon was—a power-hungry, manipulative, all-knowing, chameleon king
​Tarog's portrayal of Quezon displayed him as a human being; a being with his own selfish greeds and desires

Books and documentaries would often portray Quezon as nothing but a "perfect president," so shedding light on him as a trapo will definitely have his relatives shaking their heads at the representation
​Heroes were often depicted as nothing but that—perfect, heroic, symbols of peace and protection
However, in Tarog's final installment of the Bayaniverse Trilogy, he portrayed Quezon under a different lens: he was portrayed as imperfect, flawed
Quezon was sick, twisted, and outwardly selfish—something that made him stand out from Goyo and Luna
(Btw, my memory could be serving me wrong
) Goyo and Luna were portrayed as these "sacrificial" heroes whose actions were driven by their patriotism and love for the country
Quezon, however, was not
His actions were driven by his need to have and stay in power
As mentioned, "Mauuna pang pumuti ang uwak kaysa mawalan ka ng kapangyarihan, Quezon" for he did anything and everything in his power to ensure that he was never in a position of no power
​Quezon was terrifying for how "real" he is in this day and time
He was able to manipulate the people by abusing the Filipino's belief of utang na loob—and he used that as ammunition in every political war, which ultimately led to his victory

Another factor was how Quezon curated his image of "perfection" by utilizing his connections to the fullest—even going as far as trampling over the livelihood and well-being of the people if it meant staying in power
He used people at his disposal, all the while maintaining a picture-perfect image to the media and the people
​Quezon is terrifying because while he may not have been fighting armies on the war zones, he was pulling the strings from the best seat in the house

Quezon is the final film from TBA's Bayniverse
It honestly feels like a satisfying conclusion to its said trilogy
I was never known to be interested in early Philippine history
I watched this because it's a film that's highly anticipated nationwide
I was really impressed by how the film goes from Manuel's early life through films, and how his life is in turmoil through the battle for independence
However, the film explores his desire for deception to gain much power to become the second president of the Philippines
Something so sinister that I understand that's how Jerrold interpreted it based on facts about Quezon's "game"
Every aspect in every scene resembles the reality we still have
We're still in a developed country, which is not surprising to say the least
We're humans playing by the rules and laws
But for our country, it's what we live for
I adored how the film opens, but then I get a bit overwhelmed afterward
Thankfully, I was able to connect the dots on what's happening
I was blown away by the visuals, production set, and its ensemble cast of this film
It's truly amazing to see those in a Philippine film
Although, the sound mixing and camera work felt they needed to fill up on some scenes
Almost to make this film perfect
Now, the film Quezon became a national debate, thanks to one of Quezon's descendants at the Q&A post-screening
He stated that the film affected him, claiming it's a satire rather than a biopic
And he's not the only one; a few of Quezon's families are also affected by the film afterward
Many hated, many defend
It is very common to see this happening in every biopic film ever made
Filmmakers create a film based on a real-life figure, followed by credible sources available
Despite that, you will never escape from any person who knows a real-life figure because they don't provide you with any consideration before the film was made
To respond to that fiasco, I dare to say that this film is worth watching for everybody who's not interested in or complains about it
The disclaimer says it all, and yet they roared for a boycott
But as long as Quezon tells you exactly what the director and writers had envisioned, the film is the representation of our struggle to handle our country due to lies and deception

Just watched Quezon
I want to start by saying I think Filipino films are not quite my jam, unfortunately
I wanted to like this
It had its moments, and I get the idea it wanted to convey
Quezon is a depiction of how Americans influenced Philippine politics into what it is today—for better or worse (mostly worse)
It was not a good painting of Manuel Quezon by any means
I grew up not really minding Philippine presidents
Quezon, for me, felt like a decent person, someone who was deeply connected with the US—President of the Commonwealth
The film depicted him as a sneaky politician who would do everything to stay in power
He was charismatic and had a way with his words and aura
Unfortunately, the whole time I felt like I missed much more nuance in him
I felt his characterization was too one-sided; it seemed like he was used as a plot point to get a point across
The film was actually confusing to follow at first due to the differing timelines
The problem with political films is that they tend to be biased from a certain point of view
This felt like one of those films
I wished I had seen a complex character—one who is a lion when he needs to be but perhaps also a person who genuinely believed in something
This was my first entry in the 'bayaniverse' by Tarog
Perhaps most of what was depicted was true, but I think it left out some of the important parts of what made Quezon a fascinating Filipino president
I did like the heart of what it wanted to depict
We live in a political regime where corporations are the boss and the leaders do things to stay in power—not for the people
The acting was not that good
They hired a 'for the money' American actor, and the leads did not feel authentically Filipino
Or maybe the writing was just mid
There's a sense of liberation in seeing heroes being portrayed in an unflattering light
It does not make them dislikeable per se, it makes them human, pulling them back to their core essence
Story is ok lang
I love the metaphors
It’s just not as fun as the past 2 films of sir tarog

I am the Philippines The third installment of Tarrogs' Bayaniverse explores on Manuel L Quezon as a four part film; The Hero, The Great Political Player, and the lobbyists towards the Philippines' Independence

Unlike the first two films which focus on the fight for a Revolutionary Government, Quezon, sets up a new story toward nation building translated to themes of power and play in the political arena(of which parallels to the existing political patterns of Philippine Politics)
The good points of the film would be the idea of a film within a film; how media was an excellent medium to portray the two sides of Quezon as the Hero and the Trapo(traditional politician)
Jericho Rosales did and excellent execution portraying someone who despite being narcissistic and intelligent gentleman you can't help but to love the guy
Another good point was the role Joven Hernando as the main protagonist guised as a side character which has been consistent on all three films
The role of Joven, a fictional character meant to symbolize the viewers but my interpretation would also be the youth who are seeking for truth
Joven meaning youth in Spanish is an excellent name for the character inviting the youth to critically think and discern for a more Independent Philippines
This last installment,while it stirs controversy on the portrayal of President Manuel L

Quezon, opens a fresh perspective how we can further improve our flawed system To quote the late President MLQ"I would rather have a government run like hell by Filipinos,than run like heaven by Americans, because no matter how bad a Filipino Government might be, we can always change it"

I know my fair share of Philippine history, but every time I watch a film about anything related to it, my knowledge expands and I get to explore new perspectives
To be honest, Manuel L
Quezon was the president that I never really got to learn deeply about, hence the reason why I watched this film
It was an eye opener
The film was divided into different sections, each about someone Quezon was associated with, making me able to understand all point of views
More than the moral dilemma of campaigns, Quezon was a deconstruction of our loyalists culture towards political actors, diverting us from their humane and flawed tendencies

And although it synthesizes fiction in narrating a political legacy, it continues to be a reflection of how the public has its influence on the politics we have today because of our blinded perception of the people we should only consider as public servants and not heroes

Quezon (b

Being an American Foreign-National (though coming from Philippine parentage) residing in the Philippines, I was amazed to have realized that I came into the movie with more than a rudimentary knowledge of modern Philippine History
This movie excelled in portraying President Quezon in a very "larger-than-life" person (who historically was very much so)

Yet, at the same time, the movie seems to convey the impression that many artistic liberties were taken to make the movie more entertaining rather than to be a more historic portrayal of the real Quezon
Notwithstanding, the movie does not shy away from asking ground-breaking questions such as "How far will one go to ensure the independence of a nation

There are different entry points on how to read Quezon

Perhaps the most urgent for me to look at, is its distribution and promotion — how its coining of "Bayaniverse" has transmuted to multiple efforts of sustaining its captured audience from Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018)
In these ongoing attempts of serving its captured audience, Quezon has both failed and served them at best
By constantly challenging and deconstructing our ideals of heroism, Quezon has to eventually hurt the Pinoy pride, which I personally found an achievement
Sometimes, to offend the audience is to serve them best

By structuring a film (or films) within the film, Quezon mirrors what many of us refuse to see and can't yet actively confront, that our eventual participation in the culture of patronage politics has built the Duterte - Marcosverse
Meanwhile, I couldn't help but realize that Goyo is actually my favorite of the 3
It renders a cinematic language mostly spoken in a spiritual context: deep diving in introspection of our personal and collective complexities

i’ve always loved history since elementary school
it was one of my favorite subjects because it was easy for me to memorize important details
but that’s also the problem
we were taught to memorize history, not to understand it
we remember the names, dates, and events, but we rarely think critically about what they actually mean
that’s why this movie was so refreshing to watch
it connected all those historical terms and lessons i used to memorize, making them finally make sense in context
it’s no longer just information i learned to pass an exam, but a deeper understanding of the story behind it all
it’s sad to think that our government hasn’t changed even a bit from before until now
the same dirty political tactics, corruption, maneuvering, and patronage politics still exist today
it’s truly disappointing that the philippines hasn’t progressed at all under this kind of politics
i just hope that in the near future, our country will no longer be filled with politicians, but with genuine public servants who truly care for the people
Jerrold Tarog’s Quezon is, quite frankly, a bold attempt to deconstruct a “national hero” long revered through the sanitized lens of our school textbooks
I appreciate its almost relentless flow of exposition, which, despite its weight, is presented with precision and clarity rather than coming off as tacky
Jericho Rosales’s portrayal of Manuel Quezon is, for the most part, spot-on and convincingly delivered—he truly understood the assignment

Moreover, regardless of any controversy the film may have sparked upon release (such as outrage among Quezon’s direct descendants), Tarog’s vision remains clear: to reveal what politicians are truly made of, how their facades unravel when stripped bare, and how they continue to pass down the same traits to future generations
No wonder Quezon's grandson's nepo baby ass was so angry (kinda funny, though)
Needless to say, the film highlights how crucial for us Filipinos to critically examine our leaders, their use of power, and political ambitions, especially during these trying times in our politics

Obviously this film says a lot about how politicians operate in the Philippines, something that I had very little insight of until recently
It neither condemns nor glorify Quezon
You get to ask yourself if the risks and compromises were worth it
As you see how the man slowly corrodes his ideals because he plays the game too well
I hope that when the time comes for me to vote in any upcoming election, I can see the game being played in front of my eyes
Also, when the Ramon Magsaysay post-credit scene dropped I shed multiple tears
I appreciate how this film challenges the notion of being a “Bayani” differently compared to Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018)
The film isn’t afraid to show that Manuel L
Quezon was a deeply flawed and problematic person despite all his achievements and contributions in helping the Philippines understand and reach independencia
(Random funny side note: It tickles my brain every time they say “independencia,” and when they curse in Filipino with their thick accents
)It’s necessary to have narratives like this every once in a while because people tend to put others on pedestals and perceive them as flawless and ideal individuals
This is dangerous because idolatry leads to leniency, leniency leads to conformity, and conformity leads to collapse

Everything breaks down when we put the weight and responsibility of an entire country on one person alone, instead of recognizing that it also takes an entire nation’s worth of people to create change

This story is socially relevant not only because of our current political landscape here in the Philippines, but also as a reminder of the importance of looking back on our history to ensure we never repeat the mistakes of the past
The film is also masterfully crafted on a technical level and is arguably the best in the Bayaniverse so far
The direction, cinematography, editing, staging, musical score, and performances from the entire cast
They all shine here
Every single department that worked on this film fired on all cylinders, and it shows
There is also a level of playfulness present here (Mostly because of the score, staging, and performances) in the film that I really appreciate
It’s like a new flavor being introduced for the Bayaniverse and I welcome it very much
It was exceptionally made and definitely one of my favorite films of 2025
I hope to see more films like this from TBA Studios

two words: revolutionary cinema

quezon, amidst multiple opinions stirred due to its ability to challenge main character norms of being picture-perfect or blatantly evil, has set the standard for philippine cinema to begin questioning the authenticity of our history and our roots

it obviously did a great job in personifying such a glorified figure like manuel quezon, who used to be seen as a national hero, but upon exiting the cinemas, its really got you asking what is real or not
is he really worth the praise he’s been receiving from the filipino nation

other than that, they successfully portrayed the flaws and beauty of philippine politics; how ugly it can get, and how it has always been up to the nation’s voices to determine whether or not they want to receive the treatment they deserve or not
it mirrors current reality without being too complex to understand, it embodies the philippines as a whole, kumbaga perfect fit talaga ang tagline ni quezon na “I am the Philippines
”jericho rosales was stellar, karylle was empathic, mon confiado was agitatingly pitiful, and jerrold tarog was superb
you can see the consistency of the arts in his craft, encapsulating every detail of quezon’s life into his bayaniverse vision that translates beautifully into the soul of philippine cinema
walang patumpik-tumpik in all movies of the bayaniverse, hence, the emergence of what i call revolutionary cinema
more films like this please
and more movie goers to encourage fellow filipinos to come see them
let’s utilize our homegrown talents to possibly bring upon the change our country needs

Of all the Bayaniverse movies, Quezon (2025) is arguably the most polarizing
I'll try my best to condense my thoughts, organizing them based on meta analysis, historical truth, and social commentary
In its most meta, Quezon (2025) stands to subvert audience expectations with its characterization of Manuel L
In Tarog's previous films, he sought to shed a more sympathetic light on misunderstood figures of Philippine history
Portraying Luna as a passionate and enlightened man, Goyo as misguided and young, and even Aguinaldo as complex and misunderstood
However, how could he showcase the story of a man who's well-beloved by a nation
It's in the best interest of many to concede that although polarizing, Quezon being characterized as the progenitor of patronage politics is on brand for Dir
Luna and Goyo were already established by key aspects of their stories, either by being hot-headed or accomplished and young
Jerrold Tarog's brand has been to take what the audience may know and provide a different perspective, thus explaining Quezon's diva tantrums and arrogance
However, the question remains—Is it historically accurate
From my understanding of the film, Tarog already sought to answer those questions within the film itself
Accuracy and truth is greatly influenced by the filmmaker, her patron, and even preexistent ideas of who a person is
History is not my career, thus I can't provide a professional opinion on its accuracy
What I can say, however, is that if Tarog's own opus is be trusted—he, the director, is merely a man
He is not infallible and thus, the truth as he knows it, may not entirely be what it is
Historical accuracy cannot simply be based on its costuming and subtle details in props, but also the integrity of the story itself
Lastly, the movie is obviously a very nail-on-the-head commentary on politicians whose personal ambitions are hid thinly behind a persona of nationalism
It feels like a jab against growing populist sentiments, but antagonizes the greedy who sought to reap its benefits with little sincerity
It explores how the formula for gaining power as an ambitious, dynastic politician has never really changed in the past century or so

Unless the people themselves are willing to start questioning the integrity of the people they sought to empower with their votes, for every disgraced politician another corrupt politician will take his place
Perhaps I'm reading too much into this, but Quezon (2025) feels like some sort of cinematic social experiment that Jerrold Tarog gave us

He's seen the power of Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, perhaps this is just him leaving a movie that's on-purposely polarizing so that the people can be forced to think about the credibility of everything they see
Even if not his intention, it's great to see this play out
The movie was enjoyable and the stylistic difference definitely ties into how we're in a brand new era of Philippine history
I'm hoping to see a similar thing be done with any of his future works

I'll be honest, I didn't know much about Manuel Quezon outside the fact that he's considered a national hero—and a bit about the questionable land acquisition practices in the establishment of his namesake city
And not being a huge fan of biopics, I was just hoping for a nuanced look at a national hero
But holy shit, this pulled no punches
Quezon is portrayed to have learned the worst of the political game from the Americans
Incredibly so
I had to pull up some recordings of him afterwards, Rosales absolutely nailed his cadence
The acting here was incredible
The cinematography some of the best I've seen from a Filipino movie
And best of all, it LOOKED like a movie
This was cinematic
And surprising for a political biopic, this was a blast
It was hilarious
It didn't take itself too seriously (or seriously at all, really)
Maybe those more familiar with the story will be annoyed by the heavy use of exposition, but I found it to be helpful
I'm not here to shit on anyone else's national heroes—I've got plenty of American historical figures I can do that to

But, this does do a great job of depicting how Quezon's style of politicking, and selling off his country's resources to the highest bidders, seems to have led to the rampant levels of corruption seen today, 100 years later

A scathing and surprisingly humorous indictment of Quezon and his supposedly scummy character, so much so that it enters caricature territory, but I'm reminded of Tarrog's overarching project of interrogating what a bayani means
This is supported further by the dimension that the film adds to Aguinaldo who was a clear villain in "Heneral Luna

" There's a dearth of (good) films about history and politics in mainstream contemporary Filipino film, so I was pleased to see some unconventional editing and cinematographic choices here that are more common in foreign biopics

The incorporation of the silent film was a clever device all around – a way to deepen the fictional Joven's story while beefing up the commentary on media as a tool of propaganda, a cost-cutting yet effective touch on the artificiality of celebrity politics, a self-aware reflection on how history is written by the victors
Rosales' transformation is a thrill to watch and a testament to the ripening of his craft but I was also really captivated by Sarmienta's performance
Sometimes the script sounds like it's lifted from a HEKASI textbook but it's forgivable for people like me who need the refresher course
With memorable performances from the cast, compelling storytelling, and masterful direction, Quezon (2025) deserves to stand and be praised on its own
Still it’s best viewed as the final installment to the Bayaniverse trilogy
In this lens, we really see Jerrold Tarog’s thesis throughout the series: “Ang pagkabayani, it’s all about perception
”Heneral Luna (2015) showed a hero with unrivaled passion and patriotism
John Arcilla’s Luna is a hero people wanted to rally behind and emulate
He was branded as a leader who could have saved the Philippines, if not for the infighting between the revolutionaries
Yes, he was a flawed character, but you wanted to root for him
Never mind that he never won a battle – his profound love of country made up for it
The timing of the film also couldn’t be more perfect — it was released during an intense rise in populism
The film arguably contributed to Rodrigo Duterte winning the 2016 presidential elections, but that’s another story
Goyo: The Boy General (2018) was more subdued
There was no way to replicate Luna’s fiery personality and Arcilla’s performance as a cussing, temperamental general, so it was only natural to take another approach
Paulo Avelino gave life to the young, inexperienced boy general
In history classes, Goyo was often described as a martyr who died for his beloved country
The film portrayed his conflict – was he really loyal to his country or only to Aguinaldo
Was his sacrifice heroism or blind servitude
Quezon depicted a trapo’s rise to power
Jericho Rosales’ Quezon showed ability to pull all the tricks in the book: propaganda, lying, self-serving alliances, politicking, patronage politics
He wasn’t the first to do them (and we know from our daily experiences now that he’s not the last), but he no doubt mastered them
Describing him as a chameleon was an understatement
Always performing and projecting what the other side wants him to be
More importantly, Quezon brought the trilogy’s thesis full circle
The film, like the two before it, argues that heroism is not black and white
“Ang pagkabayani, it’s all about perception
”The film within a film device effectively blurred the lines between reality and fiction

The switching between different Quezons (the old version, the young version, the fictionalized young version), the nonlinear storytelling and changing perspectives, further served to confuse the audience about objective history and revisionist recollection
But the film’s biggest and most-rewarding bet is making Joven Hernando (the audience surrogate) an active participant to the story
By showing that he can be swayed by narratives, blinded by his own biases, be bought, but ultimately speak truth to power, the challenge is flipped back to the viewer
How should we view heroes

When we know that they “get their hands dirty” with politics; they forge convenient alliances; they stage publicity stunts; they do everything not for the greater good, but to push their own ambitions
How should we question our leaders and speak truth to power when we can also benefit from them if only we played our cards right
Looking at the trilogy as a whole, it is clear that our heroes, despite their contributions to the nation, are flawed individuals
Despite their larger-than-life personas, they are just people too
Like us
The whole time we were focused on the titular characters, on supposed saviors we have preconceived perceptions on
But this conclusion just reminded us we ought to look at ourselves and our relationship with these heroes too

As someone who really enjoyed Araling Panlipunan in elementary and junior high school, and a huge Bayaniverse fan—watching this film was an absolute treat for me
(Not to mention the outstanding visuals, humor, and score in this film, absolute chef kiss
)I love how it went beyond the usual, surface-level lessons we get in school

I remember learning about the Tydings–McDuffie Act back in sixth grade and wishing we could explore it more deeply but was ultimately met with disappointment when we only touched on it briefly before moving on to another topic
That being said, hearing familiar names and events in this movie made me geek out so much
More than that, I truly appreciated how it gave a deeper look into Quezon’s life and not just his role in our history
I liked that the film showed his flaws and his “dark games,” making him feel more real and human
Without giving away any more spoilers, this film is both thought-provoking and relevant today
It leaves us with something important to reflect on: to question, to stay aware, and to take an active role in shaping our nation
The future is in our hands—we must act before it changes us

Concluding the Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon is a battle of wit and strategy, a game of outsmarting and outplaying in a race for political power that ultimately shaped the past, present, and future of the Philippines
I love how it incorporates a filmmaker’s perspective through Nadia, as well as the return of Joven, now older, and the reemergence of journalism at the forefront

This use of cinema itself as a device to propel the narrative forward makes it compelling, seamlessly blurring the lines between fact and fiction, much like how the main characters easily manipulate these concepts

Despite clearly steering away from the literal warfare of the previous two installments, the film still manages to grip audiences through a high-stakes chess match between the titular character and his rivals

I can’t deny that the reactions and condemnations expressed by some of Quezon’s descendants are valid
No matter which angle you look at it, the film portrayed a negative and unflattering image of Quezon during his lifetime
From his beginnings as a lawyer, to his time as governor of Tayabas, Senate President, and eventually as President — the movie showed how deeply rooted traditional politics was, even back then
Maybe they were the ones who started it; the methods may have changed over time, but the goal remained the same — to gain and keep power
It’s hard to accept that our own ancestors might have been the ones who taught us how to become monsters in the world of politics — corrupt and power-hungry
But hopefully, this film serves as an eye-opener for all of us — a reminder not to repeat the same history
May it inspire the next generation of public servants to have a genuine love for the country and to serve with true integrity and sincerity

“I got one more in me,” exclaimed Jerrold Tarrog as he laid the finishing touches of his 3rd film in this ironically-titled Bayaniverse
Wilfredo Garrido has this scathing accusation that Quezon in its entirety is a hackjob in itself
It's very easy to glean the bias from which his status update after watching the film errs on, and I feel the need to start from this note because by no means does the film really sit on the fence

In fact, and if I may declaratively highlight in all its fictional and non-fictional aspects, Quezon sits as one of Jerrold Tarog's best pieces for being able to angle this part of history in a way never really seen
The recurring clamor for a film that talks of the Philippine Commonwealth has been something desired of, and Quezon being able to position itself in this manner is a welcome one
At the end of the day, one is left sitting at Quezon and possibly thinking about how the Philippine government is fundamentally a government of demons of all shapes and sizes

If you come out of this film arguing that the film itself makes Aguinaldo look like a saint (someone on Twitter says this), you may want to rewatch Heneral Luna as the center of all this is a series of heroes who are profoundly individual at their core, espousing social values and claiming to be champions of the greater good
Addendun: Raymond Red during a talkback of his Bayani (1992) screening earlier recalls the uproar he faced from the academic community for being the first to depict Aguinaldo as a piece of shit
In a way, history corrects itself down the line and one could only glean that reception towards Quezon will face the same developments
I had the chance to experience watching this film in the Cinemas
Jericho Rosales as Quezon didn't disappoint, as well as the other actors

I love cinematic scene shown at first, the silent film theme one made by Nadia where he was portrayed as a good guy for his campaign, even though the contents of it are far from truth and how we're watching from Joven's perspective because the contents of the film revisiting Quezon before entering politics and during it is all in a film made by Nadia, a second version with more truth contrasting what she had made for his Ninong for Presidential Campaign
My thoughts on this film is that they executed the film really well
It showed their flaws, not just their good side
I like Joven Hernando's character, he's a fictional character but represent us really well
All of his lines really aligns with what the audience thinks when watching the film
From supporting and believing Quezon to questioning him and eventually criticizing him
It also reminded me of how Schools always teach and portrayed them as great heroes, but never really show what's behind the door
Osmeña's character is someone easily swayed with sweet words and Quezon took advantage of that, leading, swaying him with his words even though they've had their own disputes—rivalry turned allies
Roxas's character is like a child, easy to be pawn

Quezon's character was portrayed as someone good at playing a game at politics, he knows how to play his cards very well; using every tactic and opportunities just like how he used Patriotism and Independence as a Propaganda

They also showed Quezon's side being a Womanizer and portrayed him as someone always concerned with good image in the public—although his bad side was shown, it still wouldn't erase the great things he did but it's refreshing to see that this film didn't glorify anyone
It instead showed that even these people in the end of the day are Humans
They're not perfect or saints, they have their own flaws
You can also see how our government back then still mirrors our present government
Corruption isn't new, it has always been there

There's a lot of things that you can realize watching this film, I wouldn't really rely on it for accuracy, after all it's mixed with fiction, myths and certain rumours for humour, that's why it's still better to research thoroughly
Overall this is a great film, Jerold Tarog and Tba Studios never disappoint
We need more films like this, tackling our own History
Truth is a great ideal, but you can't always use it to rule
I'm the Philippines I will lead this nation to Prosperity
