Jerold Tarog's "Quezon" narrates a period of our history that mirrors the current state of politics in the country
Men in power takes advantage of the other men in the circle and, when its not convenient anymore, easily, casually dropping them dead
History, almost 100 years ago, is repeating itself
The dirty tricks, power-hunger, and betrayal that happened under the Commonwealth government employed by President Quezon are not new to me
My history lessons, albeit shallow, have taught me that while we recognize the efforts of our forefathers, they were after all human and susceptible to corruption
It is politics afterall
What surprised me tho is how this part of the country's history was presented through this film
The cinematography, sound production, and set designs, and of course the acting (especially Jericho Rosales) were beautifully blended considering the theme of politics and history
Should you watch it on a big screen
YES-- its a no-brainer
When Filipinos learn to accept that our politicians are not perfect, flawed, and should not be held in a higher regard than an ordinary person, then maybe we will see a true change in our society

After watching Quezon, I wondered: what was the director’s goal in this movie
While discussions suggest that the intention was to reveal the flawed person behind someone most people consider a hero, I can’t help but ask—then what
What did it aim to achieve after that
For me, it merely opened up a controversy without offering any resolution
It’s similar to hearing endless news about corruption in the country without actually seeing justice served
Has anyone even been jailed yet
After tarnishing Quezon’s name and linking him to the culture of political patronage and under-the-table negotiations, what was the movie really calling for
This is one of the things I find lacking in the film
I was also confused about Jericho’s acting choices and the director’s decisions regarding narration
I understand that comedy can be an effective way to deliver a message in a relatable manner, but to me, the message—still unclear—was blurred by the slapstick
Tarog's disclaimer at the beginning and his response to Quezon's grandchild also did not help in his attempt to convey his message
And really, is that an attempt to give redemption to Aguinaldo

Seeing what Tarog did with Quezon, I strongly think he would not have depicted Luna with earnestness had he known that in less than a year a strongman like Rodrigo R
Duterte would be elected as President
Wrapping up a trilogy about the Philippines' revolutionary past with a relatively uneventful political biopic about some unremarkably corrupt politician really is a bold and interesting choice
Moreover, Quezon really is a rejection of the two films that came before
By no fault of its own, Heneral Luna is one of the most misunderstood and bastardized cautionary tales about patriotism and masculinity I've seen in my lifetime
Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral is a bitter demolition of the mindless jingoism and fascism that Heneral Luna became synonymous with
Finally, Quezon is a eulogy to the Philippines' revolutionary hopes and idealism; a resignation to a pathetic country's inescapable doom under so-called Great Men and self-proclaimed patriots
Problem is, Quezon is also the weakest of the trilogy from a structural level
Its transition from a winking mockery of the cosmic joke that is Filipino government to the bleak demystification of Quezon's self-made myth isn't as smooth as it could've been
The film's dragging length is impossible to deny by the midway point, though it's understandable given how long Quezon's story is
Worst of all, a literal half of Quezon's dialogue is a preachy lecture told at the audience
More than once, characters stop everything to become mouthpieces for the ideologies they represent and the timely commentary they embody
None of this is diegetic, and it's as awkward as it sounds
I also don't really jive with how the film ends by blaming the Filipinos for things and bastards they can't control
I too am disillusioned, but come on now with this ivory tower shit

Then again, after seeing how Heneral Luna's point was deliberately ignored, used to prop up a murderous shithead, then basically losing a decade in the process, I'm not too surprised by Quezon treating Filipino viewers like a bunch of gullible idiots who need everything to be spoon-fed at least twice

2025 RankedTBA Studios RankedBACKGROUNDThis franchise is one of the most unique franchises out there by connecting Philippine historical films with each other into a singular cinematic universe, which is distinct from those that are fictional in nature
There are fictional elements in these films, but they are overall based on true events
It may not be as popular as other franchises that have existed for decades, but it does not have to be, considering that the number of movies are three so far
Regardless, it is still a franchise that I am going to look forward to for its next entry

POSITIVESThe gap between Quezon from the previous film, Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, is seven years, which could be a bit too long to wait, but it was worth it because I did not expect for the third installment to turn out to be the best in the franchise so far
The tone and style of filmmaking was different compared to its predecessors, which reflects how much Jerrold Tarog has grown as a filmmaker

The choice to use the early stages of film as a way to reflect and criticize him as a leader not only adds more creativity and style to the film but also reflects the phase of technology at the time, and how it can be used as a powerful tool to spread influence
The storytelling is not straightforward or linear, but it is organized into chapters based on who Manuel Quezon has to face or deal with in order to rise in power
It is an approach that I did not expect, but it is a success for being able to tell a cohesive story
Jericho Rosales's portrayal is one of the aspects that I was looking forward to seeing in the film, and he succeeded my expectations
He has so much command, control, and confidence in his performance
His enthusiasm and charisma match his goal to elevate his status by playing "mind games" with his opponents
This puts the audience in an unsettling position because it becomes clear the kind of leader Manuel Quezon was
There are moments that would make me feel the intensity and pressure as I am piecing out the next moves of each player and the events that could happen
The production design was impressive that made me wonder about how they were built or where they were located
I also admire the various use of cinematography like panning and tracking to make the film livelier and to set the tone
MIXEDI was really impressed by the editing of this film, but there is a particular scene where the editing did not work for me because I felt that it did not fit into its tone

This film has the most number of significant characters in the franchise and there are a lot of time jumps, which makes it a bit difficult to catch up with certain plotlines for me, but it is understandable because it reflects how complex and complicated the situations are
NEGATIVESDue to how plenty the characters are, some of them were not given enough depth
There are a few of lines of humor that did not work for me
CONCLUSIONIt is clear how the film wants Manuel Quezon to be portrayed, which they were able to accomplish

The tone and genre of this film may not be similar to the past films in the franchise like scenes involving gunshots, but its unique approach to the story makes it stand out from other Philippine historical films

Gets ko si Joven

When you sit down and watch the film as it starts, highly likely you will suddenly be reminded of how Heneral Luna and Goyo went—the first two movies of Bayaniverse—and your expectation would somehow be related to those two
But Tarog did a different approach in Quezon, where satire is ultimately obvious, as much as it is also intended to be taken seriously
The fast-pace approach, the quick-changing of scenes, the conversations which aren't dragging, and riddles exchanged between the characters
These same characters delivered well and Tarog made sure the comedic stance are appropriately placed where necessary
It's just that for the majority of the time, I have this moment where the scenes are already at its peak, only to be steered in a different direction since, clearly, this film wants to tell more
I guess 2 hours will never be enough
I've always admired how he interpreted Luna and Goyo in a way that is culturally and politically provoking, yet easy to grasp, relate to, and branches out even more questions
Looking back at the Quezon film, it’s hard not to realize how little we’ve actually progressed as a country
We never truly learned
We forget too easily, and us being gullible, though partly not our fault, continues to hold us back
That's why it's vital that a fictional character like Joven Hernando comes in as a storyteller
We need a narrator that subtly contributes to the narrative, yet obviously part of it
He witnessed three generations of it all, with his perspective changing and honing, and revolving with the three personalities - Luna, Goyo, and now, Quezon
We are Joven
And would you ever disagree with Joven knowing that to our core, he is the representation of us all
Joven proved that as a nation, we want change
But individually
We really just wanted to survive, to focus on our families, to build our career around the things we love doing the most
At the same time, we want to see our country thrive, see it receive its deserved peace and rightful independence
We believe it's ours to begin with and no one should take that away from us
That's how us, Filipinos
We struggle to keep moving as a progressive nation because our minds are cut in half—in many pieces for some—because we have a lot to think about
Sa dulo ng bawat araw, karamihan sa atin gusto lang umuwi, magpahinga, at siguraduhing kinabukasan ay may pagkaing nakahain sa lamesa
Kaya gets ko si Joven
Kung nalinlang man siya, kung napaniwala man siya nila Luna, Goyo, at Quezon, at kung kumapit man siya sa kakarampot na pag-asa mula dun sa tatlo, hindi niya naman talaga kasalanan
Gaya ng karamihan, nagtiwala lang din siya
Kasi sino bang aayaw sa pangakong kalayaan para sa isang bansang inaabuso at kumakalam ang sikmura

As film goers, audience, and product of PH education, our role is to scrutinize and be doubtful, along with enjoying the film, because at the end of the day, a film remains a form of art, and art supposedly have its interpretation by whoever is looking at it
Truthfully, this is where the film draws the line—it cannot show everything
It's up to the audience to make their own research and form their opinions

htmlThe war is over, and now the battle is set in the world of politics
Quezon takes us front and center into the seemingly heroic life of Manuel L
Quezon - a personality Filipinos look up to as a hero, a visionary, and one of the nation’s key founders

But much like its predecessors in the Bayaniverse franchise, the film tackles head-on the sheer humanity and fallibility of Quezon, questioning whether the ends justify the means in the battlefield of power and the making of a young nation
Manuel L
Quezon (Jericho Rosales) has just won the 1935 elections, becoming the first elected Filipino president and the second president of the Philippines
But the journey to win that coveted and historically significant seat wasn’t an easy one, and you don’t get to the top without getting your hands dirty and making a few enemies along the way

On its third outing, the Bayaniverse comes full circle by slowly shifting from the action-packed Heneral Luna to a somber drama in Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral and finally to a full blown political drama in Quezon
The literal battles here are replaced by heated confrontations between Quezon and his contemporaries, showing how he fought and negotiated his way through power by any means necessary
While we can’t say for sure if every revelation in the film is historically accurate, this is far from the textbook version of Quezon we grew up with
This is a human Manuel Quezon up front and center
One who is charming, cunning, and deeply flawed

The film hits hard, especially when viewed against the backdrop of today’s political landscape, reminding us that the people we idolize are often far more complicated than their public images suggests
The film’s chapter-based narrative structure was something we appreciated, breaking down Quezon’s political battles into distinct segments
However, the pacing felt uneven at times, with one chapter taking up a disproportionate part of the runtime
In terms of performances, though, everyone delivered
Mon Confiado stood out as a somber, grounded Emilio Aguinaldo, while Jericho Rosales embodied Quezon’s ambition and deceitful charm perfectly
We found ourselves surprisingly invested in Quezon, and by the time the credits rolled, it hit us hard much like the other Bayaniverse films
Like before, it left questioning whether the struggles we face today were shaped by the same heroes we’ve long revered
As a potential bookend to the franchise, Quezon closes the trilogy in the way we hoped it would which is powerful, reflective, and important for Filipinos

sayang it would have been better (more realistic) if it was tj trinidad who portrayed as MLQ kasi sila talaga ang magka doppelganger (and both mestizo pa) nonetheless, jericho rosales pulled it off naman
I think it's really best to now see all three films as one long project, all of it built around the deconstruction of the national hero
It is through that lens that the character of Joven finally makes sense, the trilogy's audience surrogate who attaches himself to these larger-than-life figures, only to witness their downfall
Joven believes in the Great Man: in the singular figures that will lead our nation out of the darkness
The film openly exposes that idea as foolhardy at best, because these Great Men are just people, too
And they're all deeply flawed individuals that just get their dirty laundry swept under the bed precisely because they feel like they could be our saviors
This third film is practically a farce, with Rosales' Manuel L
Quezon treating nationhood as a rigged game where only he can come out on top
He blatantly lies to his friends when it's convenient to do so, and accumulates power through every dirty trick in the politician's playbook
He is the Ur-TRAPO, basically creating the systems that would make TRAPOs an inescapable reality in the Philippines
Rosales is terrific here, his Quezon constantly performing for whoever's in front of him
He projects being a loyal ally, or a mentor, or a friend, or indeed the great savior of the Philippines

He plays that big, while in private moments Quezon is all vulnerability: a man who sees how delicate the house of cards he's built is, and worries about whether his health will allow him to see his dreams come to fruition
I do think the film has a tendency to overexplain, to have characters speaking the subtext out loud
But considering how some people took Heneral Luna, maybe this was always the tack to take
In any case, the film is unequivocal with how it wants us to see Quezon: he is what Chiz Escudero wants to be, and maybe what made Chiz Escudero possible
Welcome to our Sad Republic
Here's the guy that made it happen
One McGuffin in the film is a Philippine peso coin that Quezon offers Joven the first time they meet
Quezon tells Joven, “pasisikatin ko ang pangalan mo,” “I will make your name famous
” It is offered as a symbol of promise
Later in the film, we understand that Quezon is a businessman and how we sees his wits as he steers money into his electoral campaign
Quezon knows how to invest in the hearts of the people he influences
He fully understands the weakness of Filipinos when it comes to “utang na loob” or debt of gratitude
We see this coin move between Quezon and Joven
Joven, who later finds out Quezon’s dirty tricks, returns the coin
In the last act, the coin is returned, becoming a powerful metaphor for the cost Filipinos pay when voting for leaders who manipulate their perception
Quezon is intriguing, comical at times, but otherwise compelling in that you’re hypnotized and drawn to the flipping of Quezon’s coin, who is on one side a hero, and on the other a flawed human being
We see him as a player, incisive in his chess pieces in Philippine politics
But also a sociopath when he deals with his cards in a game of poker with his enemies
The dialogue in the film never lets up, with pacing that keeps you glued to your seat
The film makes you love-hate the man, and Jericho Rosales’ performance stands out, supported by an impressive powerhouse cast
Overall, the film is witty and entertaining
The political play may be on the nose, but should not alienate a regular Filipino moviegoer
And should be able to provide a proper dissection of the politicians we placed in their positions, and a wake-up call to vote better in the next elections

The Bayaniverse films have always been about showing how these heroes, whom we have put up on a pedestal, are in reality very flawed humans as well
With ‘Quezon’ we not only see a very flawed human, but one that could have possibly set up the many political systems in play today
Jericho Rosales who plays the titular chameleon ‘Quezon’ brings his A game to the role
You can see his range with Quezon’s cunning smiles, and explosive anger
The entire cast is a powerhouse one as well, bringing their own strengths to their characters
Technically, I was impressed by how the film was shot, employing black and white film work to mimic films from the 1930s
The production design was also on point with the props and costumes used, even the set pieces were impressive

The story itself shows how Quezon, who might be seen as a hero, has some skeletons in his own closet, and even had some strings pulled to help his rise to power, the reveal is a treat, and even though this is already history, there was a scene where I had to hold my breath
I had the privilege of watching “Quezon” last Sunday
The film in some way, gave me closure about what our politics are today—though not the good kind of closure
I remember during the last elections, one of my professors was kind enough to ask the whole class how we were holding up
Of course, we felt cheated, beaten
When I returned the question to him, he sighed and said, “Well, sanay na kami
”Watching Quezon, that statement makes even more sense
The film is a mirror—almost like a satire—protesting to our faces what we’ve been enduring for years
We’re all familiar with the Filipino game of politics (brought to life first by our colonizers, if I may add), but seeing it up close through this film is heartbreaking
We are being played by our politicians, and though we feel it deeply today, it’s something that has persisted for years
In this case, even in our very early days of democracy
“Quezon” premieres today in over 260 cinemas nationwide

aside from the surprising good performance of jericho rosales as the titular quezon — one who i suspect must have had significant work and training done, in the way he embodied this role — i have to sing praises for the women in this film

A pretty compelling dissection of the messiness of politics
Mind you there's some bits here I would have loved to have seen pared down-- some speeches here often read as plain and didactic as thesis statements and some visuals come across as painfully obvious

There's a lot of reiteration of the theme of games being played here in the pull for power, even down to, in one scene, a clear chessboard referenced in both dialogue and image in a moment of Quezon's play for power and assembly of political pieces
And to be honest, the whole idea of politics being a game is something that simply comes across as trite (I mean, there is already a biopic out there that exists called Quezon's Game)
At the same time, you have to admire the ambition of just implementing those ideas so clearly on levels of craft and storytelling
On the whole this is a sumptuously put together film that manages to make a whole lot of talking deeply delightful
This is especially remarkable considering that A
Dialogue-heavy films can easily bore if pulled off improperly and B
Quezon as a person is a character that, in actuality, should come across as deeply uncompelling due to how awful he actually is as a person-- which the film does not shy away from
To tackle the former, some truly astounding filmmaking is on full display here, really playfully swinging that camera and injecting a constant sense of energy through the movement of visuals
And for the latter, this is simply a sharp, wise, and surprisingly comedic script that really sells in its details
Manuel Quezon ultimately is a mess of a human being, but the film really has a lot of fun examining how this man claimed power instead of resigning to singing praises on who this powerful person is
It becomes truly engaging, even clever as a film that dissects a man who is gifted and unmatched at negotiation and talking but ultimately is still acknowledged as deeply problematic
Other than that, the performances here really do a lot of heavy-lifting as well
Rosales makes a full meal of the material, really exuding effortless and entertaining charm
Confiado controls the screen whenever he appears
Ultimately, this is simply a delight to watch through and through
Which is pretty astounding for a film that is essentially just about a bunch of politicians bickering

Quezon (Jerrold Tarog, 2025) culminates the Bayani Trilogy that started with Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral
The trilogy examines three historical (and controversial) figures who helped in fleshing out our concept of a nation under tyrannical colonial rule
In this film, Manuel L
Quezon comes alive as a fierce politician who would stop at nothing to fulfill his ambition which is not to serve but to lead
He destroyed reputations and livelihoods of opponents and critics and possible nurtured the budding seeds of patronage politics which is still practiced contemporaneously
He loved the limelight (at some point, even literally), thrived in public attention, and treated the people in his circle depending on how useful they would be for his advancement
Public service is immaterial as long as benefits come pouring in
Jericho Rosales played Quezon with such aplomb and vigor that you couldn't help but be irritated at his antics
He is good
I had initial reservations when he was cast but I realized he was a good fit and he played the role well
He owns the screen every time he is on which could be reminiscent of how the real Quezon chews the scenery whenever he could
The film is a good reminder of how devious politicians could be and how easily can we be blinded by adoration even if we should have known better
If anything, this film posits that politicians come and go but our country remains and therefore, our faith should be placed on people who would serve it the best
Rating: 4/5
I LOVE IT
The finale (or is it

) to Jerrold Tarog’s ongoing thesis on what it means to be a national hero cleverly frames the retelling of the titular character’s life as a film within a film, one that’s purposefully laden with creative license and narrative freedom — blending truth and fiction to get its themes across (or, depending on your politics, to serve as propaganda or a fluff piece)

It’s fitting, then, that the final confrontation between the real-life character and the fictional surrogate who’s been our audience stand-in since the start of this interconnected project takes place inside a movie theater — the very medium through which myths are made

The film — and its film-within-the-film (yes, it gets that meta) — traces Quezon’s journey from his beginnings as part of the revolutionary army, to his days as a lawyer of the people, to his rise from local town governor to the first president of an autonomous Philippine government, free from direct foreign control
Each retelling presents not so much the man himself, but how he wanted to be remembered: as a patriot, a reformist, a visionary — or perhaps just a man intoxicated by the idea of power

We see a Quezon who thirsts not only for independence but also for control — and at times, for affairs and questionable advances — justifying the bending of truths and the moral grayness of politics as necessary evils to “effect real change
” He preaches independence to a populace not yet aware of what it truly means, wielding the idea as a political tool
Even when confronted by findings that autonomy may have come too soon — that corruption and cronyism were inevitable — he presses on, clinging to power in the name of progress
The production design is remarkable, a clear step up in scale and ambition — grand, intricate, and indicative of a much higher budget

Tarog’s decision to divide the film into cinematic “chapters” gives it an epic sweep, though it also makes the storytelling feel jumpy at times, leaving certain emotional and narrative threads unresolved
The script leans a bit too heavily on exposition, and the occasional bursts of humor sometimes undercut the otherwise serious tone

Still, Quezon (2025) succeeds where it matters most: in driving home its central theme — that our so-called national heroes, for all their grandeur and idealism, were also deeply flawed, morally ambiguous men shaped by ambition and compromise
It leaves us with a haunting question that lingers long after the credits roll:Are our political leaders — past and present — truly heroes, or simply the kind of villains we’ve learned to celebrate
Script was too preachy, didactic, and Araling Panlipunan coded
Gwapo ni Jericho

Quezon closes the Bayaniverse trilogy with a dark third act leaving the viewers to ponder the lessons of history and how the game of politics is being played, realizing that the pursuit of power can corrupt and victimizes everyone
The mini Quezon campaign movie was a stroke of genius, and becomes a distinct factor deviating from the first two films (Luna and Goyo)
Jericho Rosales, Mon Confiado, Iain Glen and the whole cast deliver remarkable performances
Congrats to TBA studios and director Jerrold Tarrog for concluding this trilogy

I'm still not convinced that we need a film about Quezon because he is so bland as a greedy populist political figure that any attempt to explore him will be preachy and on-the-nose, relentlessly hammering the problem with the current zeitgeist with little catharsis

It entailed a perilous narrow line between portraying him as a brilliant charismatic political mastermind or a typical power hungry politician who reflect most public servant in the government today that they framed this story with journalists and filmmakers who would provide the commentary for the audience

It was looking at the eponymous protagonist from a distance, dissecting his essence and stripping him of all subjectivity, but it was also not presented objectively since they needed to ensure that the audience would not receive the wrong message, so more telegraphed commentary from the minor character
They should have simply written an informative paper discussion instead of making a film about the subject, because they had a lot to say but no compelling story to tell

It was so disorganized narratively that halfway through the film, it was difficult to tell where it was meant to go, and at least three elderly audience members were sleeping and snoring loudly from my theater
The visual language utilized in this movie is quite odd, most likely because they are unable to find a mean to convey the screenplay in a cinematic or visually appealing manner
It kept repeating the same shots and camera movements, which grew tedious at some point given the scale and time period it meant to communicate

There are too many tilt and boom shots, and the blocking tends to follow a formalism with a lot of symmetrical orientation that looked so theatrical with the camera slowly moving in, even though they desperately needed dynamic filmmaking to hide the limited production design

It relied on theatricality to pull this off, and even the performances adapt that theatrical mechanics where it devolved into actors yelling their dialogue, which was noticeable with the pitch of the sound, prompting me to be conscious with the sound system to see whether the problem was with the theater or the sound mixing itself

Not to nitpick the technical filmmaking further, but the way they filmed those propaganda short films looked too modern for the time period, and not because they were shot with a digital camera, which is totally understandable for budgetary purposes and accessibility of equipment, but they were edited and lit with a modern sensibility
Nonetheless, the intent of those short films narratively was rather intriguing since I'm pretty sure they were fictional and only used as a narrative device for the commentary
It was trying to offer that film within a film structure, peeling away the propaganda, but it just became too on-the-nose and a convenient excuse for their chosen narrative structure

They should have adopted a traditional narrative approach for this film since it would have been more compelling to show that point-of-view as Quezon rose and fell, with all of his hypocrisy and politicking, but doing so could have humanized the protagonist to the point that the audience would love him

It was a tricky film to make, and I appreciate that it did not humanize or glorify Quezon as an anti-hero at all, but it grew monotonous and painfully obvious when it could have been more mean-spirited and nuanced

I am so familiar with Quezon's political career that I was able to follow all of the political strife in the film, which made me upset since it seemed like I was reading my notes from my history class rather than following a cohesive narrative
However, I'm not sure what an audience unfamiliar with the subject matter can take away from this film, which moves from one battle after another with far too many expositions

It was bombastic and loaded with information, and without knowing the significance and relationship of each character, along with the political backdrop around the time, it will probably be alienating for others

It was still able to deliver some of the story in an innovative way, notably the Quezon versus Osmena fight, which is the most visually interesting, easy-to-follow and entertaining story throughout the film
It is actually impressive how it created a pace and tone that made sense for what it was trying to do narratively

Lastly, I want to discuss the Aguinaldo aspect, which was jarring since it nearly made him likable and probably the protagonist of this film, despite having a far worse reputation than most national heroes
It further claims that Quezon invented the beliefs that Aguinaldo killed Luna
It was strange since the film rehabilitated him with a title credit that celebrated how he is the last one to die among Quezon, Osmena and Roxas
Are we expected to feel bad for him
I don't know about that, and the way it was dramatized at the end makes it seem like we were wrong to hate him all along

Aside from being a nepo baby, I believe he tried to sold the Philippines revolution to the Spaniards in exchange for an exile in Hong Kong and allegedly 800,000 that is supposed to be handed in two parts, one of which were delivered but the other half was not, so he resumed the revolution
It almost feels like it was gaslighting the audience, but it was more likely illustrating that Quezon is beloved when he is actually worse
**Endnote: How dare them not to mention Pascual Racuyal, the bulakenyo mechanic who run for presidency every election from 1935 until the snap election during 1986

Quezon is yet again another substantive display of one of the Philippine's most important historical figures

Following Heneral Luna and Goyo, this is Jerrold Tarog's third attempt of this kind of historical drama that puts these historical figures on the spotlight in a way that provides discourse on the political state of the Philippines during their time; a discourse of which that's unfortunately relevant to this day
As opposed to both Antonio Luna and Gregorio Del Pilar, who were generals, this film focuses on Manuel L
Quezon, a prominent Filipino political figure in the early 20th century (the 2nd Philippine President, specifically)

While he's more known in the history books (or at least how I was taught in school) as someone who made changes in the Philippine government to make the nation more independent, the movie gives a transparent perspective of his rise to Presidency in both a positive light and negative light, the latter of which is shown in the misdeeds and manipulation he did behind the scenes in order to gain his power

It's come to the point where the interactions feel so Mean Girls-coded, in a sense where Filipino political affairs feel so parallel to high-school drama, where people try to one-up themselves over others in the political game of seeing whoever takes the highest form of power

It's funny to think about at first, but it's much more depressing if you really put your mind to it; Filipino politicians have never really gotten past this political game for power that it's still very much relevant to this day

Instead of addressing the actual issues in the country like the lack of education, proper infrastructure, and better living conditions for the lower class, you see Quezon do a lot of back-and-forth between his opponents and other people just to retain his position

And when he does interact with the lower class, he instills this fake hope in the independence of the Filipino nation, which sounds so good that even those who don't know what the word "independence" actually means were sold by his charismatic and inspiring words

Though Quezon has done a lot of good for the country, the film shows just how flawed he is, and how we shouldn't just take the positive impact he had, but also take in his wrongdoings as a view on the saddening reality of politics

There's a recurring motif of characters being tired of all the back-and-forth interactions that lead to nothing productive, which feels very reflective of how the director Jerrold Tarog feels about modern Filipino politics; he's tired of his more subtle approach in his two aforementioned films that he tackles the topic in this film in a more straightforward way
As a result, the film can get preachy and waaaaay too obvious in its approach to this topic, which throws subtlety out of the way

But I understand how this is done intentionally to really get the point across, especially to the young Filipino viewers who will be watching this and be urged by educators in doing so, especially through the student discounts (of which I got, because I'm still in college lol)

Normally, I'd be against this obvious approach in such an important topic, but seeing that it intends on educating the Filipino youth regarding the political state of the country, and seeing how poor the reading and art comprehension are of most Filipinos, I can forgive the film for this
It has a lot of good things to say, albeit there were some inaccuracies here and there, though they were done for a more cohesive narrative and theme throughout
Jericho Rosales gave a really good performance as the titular character, Iain Glenn was a standout to me, despite his considerably short appearance, and there weren't any bad actors in this at all

Tarog's direction was quite good, the pacing was always on point and never got boring, the cinematography was mostly great, and the production and set design were so insanely well done and there was a lot of attention to detail
Though the editing can sometimes be jarring and the music gets a bit overbearing at times, the film was still really good overall

Really hope that the students watching this film will take the good out of the film and be inspired to become the change that we need in the Philippines, especially since the future isn't looking so bright for our country

A sharp, smart, and playful deconstruction of The Life of a Showman
It's all for show
A call for Independence
A promising election campaign
A mythmaking agenda built on propaganda
That's the thing about politicians—they act, project, and perform for everyone
QUEZON is a timely & grim reminder that virtually nothing has changed over the last 100 years in our padrino & utang na loob ecosystem
In between political breakups and unnecessary theatrics, the country remains a farce governed by clowns
The film nudges the audience to see through the web of lies

What QUEZON also achieves brilliantly is turning political maneuverings into a compelling drama through a kinetic screenplay, smoothly switching from a frame story, to an analepsis, to its current timeline
Think Succession, but set in Malacañang
The newspaper montage works as an effective storytelling device, grounding its viewers to the historical context
It tends to overexplain and simplify its message but in an age where satire is a dying art, this may be the way to make its point crystal clear
The dynamic blocking, characters walking ahead or standing a tier higher, are used to convey fragile egos, shifting alliances, and subtle power plays
Jericho Rosales is simply terrific, inhabiting the role with such bold, infectious energy
Jerrold Tarog skillfully balances tone and themes, providing a fresh way to tackle a historical drama
The ensemble is stellar across the board, with everyone getting their moment
Karylle, with limited screentime, leaves a lasting impression
She’s often seated while Quezon towers above, until a full-circle moment where life throws a reminder that power, like fate and politics, always turns like a wheel
Entertaining & thought-provoking, QUEZON is a fitting conclusion to the Bayaniverse trilogy
Brush up with your high school history knowledge to achieve a richer experience
TBA Studios should be proud of this, especially with its grand production that’s 100% deserving of the big screen
See it to believe it
A scathing take down of the first president of the Commonwealth
Quezon is tagged as the pioneer of explicit patronage politics and the spoils of victory system where donors of the winning candidate get special deals and treatment as utang na loob
He did not invent the game but he normalized it from the highest position
This system hasn’t left us since, and has left us poor
From the victories of the power-hungry Quezon, of the power-hungry PLUS malevolent Marcos and Duterte families, our republic has a habit of losing
We keep falling for would be saviors—those that promise independence, a golden era, or crime-free streets
The film puts journalism on a pedestal but also admits how it can fall prey to misdirection, disinformation, planted stories
There’s a scene that depicts creepy trolls confronting Aguinaldo, a la Duterte propaganda networks poisoning our information ecosystem, trying to scare opponents and opposing opinions

It's funny how this movie, even with all its fictional creative freedom, perfectly mirrors the political realities of the Philippines today
Jerrold Tarog doesn't just present a history lesson, he offers a raw, unflinching look at the budding Philippine government in a way that contemporary audiences should study closely

The film makes it brutally clear that this country's foundation wasn't laid purely with high ideals and patriotism, but was instead built on a messy combination of greed, manipulation, betrayal, and the relentless pursuit of power

What truly stings was the realization that after decades upon decades of supposed journey toward claiming true independence and stability, we always seem to cycle back to the same messy politics, just in a different font and under new names
And at the center of this perpetually recurring drama, the film powerfully argues, is a key player silently pulling the strings, moving the local pawns for their own geopolitical gain: the Americans
The film's narrative highlights how foreign interests often shaped the domestic landscape, making us question who are our true allies and enemies
This is uncomfortably sad, but Quezon is beyond a mere entertainment affair

It’s not just a historical drama but rather an outcry of what we have become as a nation, especially how we form our opinions with blind idolatry in mind, just like how Quezon blindly idolizes himself of what he thought he was, and that in itself is alarming

Jerrold Tarog’s Quezon asks: what if nation-building was just really good stage direction
Gone are the bullets of Heneral Luna and the heartbreak of Goyo—here, the fiercest battles happen behind podiums and in front of cameras
Every handshake feels like a chess move, every line delivery a soft coup
I was genuinely fascinated by the sheer calculated brilliance of this version of Quezon—conniving, persuasive, and dangerously aware of his own myth
He doesn’t chase power; he curates it
I came expecting a history lesson
I stayed for the masterclass in manipulation
And I left wondering if Quezon’s real genius was knowing that legacy, like film, only needs the right edit
“Masyadong maraming politiko sa bansa
Kaunti lang ang lingkod bayan”I wish we all had a lens clear enough to see what truly drives every politician when they chase power
Watching how Quezon played with the emotions of those around him, with position and power, I couldn’t help but wonder: maybe deception has long been ingrained in what it means to be Filipino
Maybe we’ve always been “mabilis mabilog” and “magaling mambilog”
This is where the cycle started, and no doubt why it still continues
It’s a system like a game with set mechanics—only the players change, and the tricks evolve
The film itself is incredible
There’s a sense of power here that’s difficult to explain and an emotional pull so strong you can’t decide whose side you’re on, because each character’s truth unfolds with raw honesty
You see their flaws, their desires, and how their ideals clash for the same country
Oh and i love how Tarog uses cinema and journalism as tools of truth
The transitions, the way history is woven through reels of film, are brilliant
The color palette alone tells a story—Quezon bathed in rich, vivid hues, while Aguinaldo fades into muted tones
And the score
The circus-like and chaotic score is perfect reflection of the madness, the spectacle that politics has always been
Ang husay
The cast is insane, and I couldn’t be more proud because wow
such a powerful ensemble of artists
Jerrold Tarog is bold and fearless, and such a great storyteller
By the end of the film, I found myself asking: Will this game ever end
I hope one day, the mechanics will change
One day, may the rules will finally be rewritten
At para sa mga trapo sa henerasyong ‘to, nakita na namin ang mga laro ninyo
“HINDI KAMI KULANGOT, HUWAG N’YO KAMING BILUGIN

As the Bayaniverse comes to a close, we now see Joven Hernando for who he's always been: all of us
The quintessential Filipino everyman; blissfully hopeful yet willfully ignorant when it suits him
Someone so desperate for salvation they kneel before madmen, canonizing them as saints

And when this precarious house of cards that they—we—have helped build comes tumbling down, blame spreads like thick, choking smoke and we're left exposed, haunted by our own folly and the delusions we built our faith upon
Like the return of a Marcos to power, propped up by the despotic Duterte machinery, and the mess that ensued
But not all comebacks have to be so daunting
Take Jericho Rosales here for example, who plays MLQ with such clinical ostentation that it almost feels borderline icky
A rich portrayal of how principles and self-interests come into play in power politics

When Quezon declared, “I would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans,” I used to think it was just a hyperbolic quip—an impassioned cry from a man starved for independence
But now, it feels like a prophecy
A mirror held up to the nation we’ve become
Jerrold Tarog’s final installment in the Bayaniverse trilogy—Quezon—carried with it a weight of expectation
Just as Luna and Goyo startled a curious…
It blends humor, satire, truth, and explicitness
The cinematography is superb, and I like how unique it is compared to other local films across genres—especially how distinct it feels from Jerrold Tarog’s Bayaniverse

And like many other political films in the Philippines, it doesn’t necessarily offer something new, but it gave me a fresh perspective on the downside of hero worship—how we often forget that the heroes we idolize are still human, flawed, and capable of mistakes
“Hindi nakalaya ang mga Pilipino, hindi nakalaya ang ating bayan
At ang malupit na katotohanan: sa pagkakataong ito, wala nang bansang kailangang manakop upang ipagkait sa atin ang kalayaan—sapagkat tayong mga Pilipino mismo ang hindi marunong lumaya
Sa sarili nating paninikil, ganid, ang kulturang utang na loob at katapatan sa maling damo, at sa paulit-ulit na pagpili sa sarili kaysa sa bayan
Ilang henerasyon na nating binibihag ang ating mga sarili, ilang Quezon pa ba ang darating upang humingi ng independencia at gaya niya ay paulit-ulit na maligaw ng landas
Sapagkat sa bawat panahon, may Quezon sa ating lahat—ang hunyangong handang isuko ang katotohanan, basta’t manatiling nasa trono ng ilusyon
” (Excerpt from my reflection essay on [Quezon])
Tarog walks us through Quezon’s life like flipping through a well-worn autobiography, and honestly, it hits different when you realize how little has changed
The film’s a mirror held up to our current mess—politicians are still clowns, shape-shifting for applause and votes
What makes it work is how Quezon isn’t sanitized
He’s brilliant and messy, calculating yet genuinely burning for independence
A complicated guy in complicated times
The kind of biopic that teaches you something about today while looking at yesterday

It’s always a peculiar experience watching a Jerrold Tarog film
There’s a quiet unease that comes with it
Maybe it’s because I’ve followed his work long enough to know he never really plays it safe; every film feels like a balancing act between vision and vulnerability
I know he’s not flawless, and neither are his films, even the ones I hold close (Confessional, Senior Year, Bliss)
But there’s something about the way he tells stories that always feels searching and alive
He’s never been after polish (and sometimes that’s the most frustrating part of his cinema) but he’s always been after answers
New answers to the kind of questions only a history geek would ask in the shower
So whenever I enter a Direk Jerrold film, I brace, because I know it might reveal something I wasn’t ready to see about us, or about what we’ve become
Of all the BAYANIVerse films, QUEZON feels the most adventurous — not in scale, but in spirit
It’s Direk Jerrold’s boldest experiment in this saga: a film that knows it’s a film
He borrows from Mike de León’s Bayaning Third World, playing with the grammar of cinema itself: reenactments, reconstructions, meta-frames
The satire is there, but softer now, as if Direk Jerrold has accepted that to film history is to fictionalize it
Every frame of patriotism is, by nature, a kind of performance
What’s interesting is how Quezon almost feels like a return to where Direk Jerrold began: to the heart of his first feature Confessional
That film was all about guilt and exposure
It blurred the line between truth and performance, between what’s real and what’s edited for the camera
Quezon carries that same unease, only now the canvas is larger: not one man’s confession, but an entire nation’s
It’s still about projection; about editing who we say we are
In both films, Direk Jerrold wrestles with the same dilemma: that the story of the country, like the story of the self, is always partly fabricated
The distance between public myth and private truth isn’t new to him; it’s the ground he’s been standing on all along
The beginning, though, is difficult
It unfolds like an essay: brisk, detached, almost indifferent to its own characters
We’re given on-screen identifiers to remember names, but no real reason to care about them yet
It’s matter-of-fact to the point of numbness
And while I understand the intention — that deliberate coldness, that resistance to sentimentality — it keeps me at a distance
Maybe that’s the point: that our first encounter with history is always sterile, a list of names before they become people
But it’s still a hard place to start for a film that ultimately depends on emotional investment
If the audience doesn’t feel invited in, the ideas risk floating above the story, detached from the very humanity they’re trying to illuminate
It’s a fascinating gamble: to alienate first, and hope empathy arrives later
Eventually, it warms
Theory turns into theater: infidelity, betrayal, the exhausting pettiness of ambition
The shift happens quietly, and suddenly, these figures in textbooks begin to ache, to resent, to want
The sarcasm becomes sorrow

Direk Jerrold lets Quezon’s charisma clash with his contradictions, and the film begins to reveal what the trilogy has been circling all along: that our heroes were never saints, just men rehearsing greatness for a stage called history
Still, Quezon is uneven in texture
It moves between stylization and realism so freely that the seams sometimes show
One moment it looks painterly, the next like something out of a morning kiddie show
Some transitions feel deliberate; others feel like accidents
At times I even caught myself wondering — is this stylized, or a little off
But at some point, the film begins to carry those inconsistencies as part of its design
The tone itself becomes a kind of argument: that history, like cinema, is never seamless

Its rough edges start to feel less like errors and more like evidence: that the story of a nation is always told through competing frames, through sincerity and performance, myth and memory all bleeding into one another
It’s also the most intimate of the trilogy, and paradoxically, the smallest
The 1935 election feels less like a historical event and more like a town contest, the scale reduced to smoke-filled rooms, small plaza gatherings, and even smaller street marches
But maybe that’s where politics truly happens: not on the battlefield, but in the room where stories are shaped or in those short walks in between campaign speeches
The Philippines, Direk Jerrold seems to say, wasn’t born in fire but in fog — not through heroism, but through negotiation
He shrinks the myth to scale, and somehow that feels truer
Jericho Rosales is remarkable
His Quezon is a performer to his bones: charming, strategic, aware that every gesture is part of a show
It’s a portrayal that understands leadership as theater
But it’s Karylle as Aurora Quezon and Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmeña who give the film its soul probably because I believe they are able to play characters that are also written better
They play the roles history often edits out — the ones who absorb power’s aftershocks
Their warmth gives the film the emotional gravity that its cleverness sometimes withholds
And the film is funny
Not that it’s a surprise, since the trailers already gave that away
But what’s interesting is how the humor works; it never feels forced
In all the politics of it all, the humor really lands
You laugh, but it’s the kind of laughter that feels like recognition — the ache of realizing how cyclical our myths have become
Watching Quezon today, it’s hard not to see the reflection: new leaders, same spectacle, the same applause for the illusion of change
The crowd has changed, but the choreography hasn’t
Politics has always been performance; we’ve just upgraded the stage lights
[SPOILER ALERT]What makes Quezon linger though isn’t how it ends, but how it fades
In a quiet mid-credits scene, a radio hums with “Mambo Magsaysay
” It sounds harmless at first, even nostalgic, until it sinks in
The trilogy that began with men dying for freedom ends with a jingle: a hero reborn not through valor, but through publicity
The revolution has learned rhythm; the myth, melody
What began in blood and fire now survives through broadcast
Heroism no longer dies; it loops endlessly on air, selling itself back to a nation that keeps forgetting
Maybe that’s Direk Jerrold’s quiet brilliance
Heneral Luna was about rage — the passion that builds nations
Goyo was about disillusionment — how conviction collapses once heroism becomes habit
Quezon is about myth — how belief turns into image, and image into machinery
It’s not just the end of a trilogy; it’s the moment when the revolution becomes a system

Because Quezon, for all his brilliance, also built the architecture of the politics we still live in: the patronage, the alliances, the transactional warmth that makes power feel personal but never equal
The birth of democracy was also the birth of dependency
And if the hinted Magsaysay film ever comes, then it will tell the story of how that system learned to sing
Because Magsaysay was the first modern president sold like an idea — a leader branded through music, charisma, and American approval
His legacy marks the shift from politics as negotiation to politics as emotion

If Luna died for the nation, and Quezon built it, then Magsaysay would show how the nation learned to perform itself — how conviction turned into choreography, leadership into branding, and the state into a stage where power thrives not by being just, but by looking relatable
The question now isn’t “Who is the hero
” but “Who’s holding the camera — and for which story, for whose gain, and at what cost to the truth

The long-awaited final chapter in the Bayaniverse trilogy brilliantly shifts gears from the battlefield to the backroom, immersing us in the ruthless political game that defined the early Philippine Commonwealth
If nothing else, it shows that 100 years ago marumi na ang pulitika sa Pilipinas
The story is eerily reminiscent of the current political landscape na kung sinabi mo sakin na last month lang sinulat at ginawa to, pwedeng maniwala ako
Director Jerrold Tarog, once again, doesn't offer a statue but a scalpel, dissecting the myth of Manuel L
This film is a compelling, dialogue-driven epic that strips away the heroic luster to reveal the manipulative acumen, charm, and sheer ambition required to forge a nation
It’s a messy portrait that feels urgently relevant, proving that the high drama of power politics can be as engrossing as any war epic
For me, the performances elevate the entire experience
Jericho Rosales is genuinely great in the titular role; he captures the former President's fire and charisma while still managing to hint at the deep contradictions beneath the tailored suits
However, this is truly an ensemble piece, and Romnick Sarmenta (as Sergio Osmeña) and Mon Confiado (reprising Aguinaldo) also shine, providing compelling foils and complexity
They make the political chess feel weighty and personal

Game of Thrones alum Iain Glen is a welcome and commanding presence, though I have to admit, his very distinct British accent occasionally pulls me out of the moment because he’s playing an American character - but maybe that’s just me being picky
I genuinely admire and respect the approach that Jerrold Tarog and team chose for this movie
A simpler but probably more boring version of this would be a straight up biopic that mythologizes Quezon
That being said, I sincerely hope our audiences are truly ready for a treatment of a national subject such as this, one that so meticulously deconstructs the idea of a great man
It requires a level of critical historical consumption that can sometimes be lacking
This film isn't just a history lesson; it's a call for discernment, and I hope Pinoys are able to understand and grapple with the deeper message it provides

My worst fear, and what keeps me thinking about the film's potential impact, is for people to come out of this movie with a shallow understanding—with the notion that all politicians are fundamentally flawed, so it's okay to support the corrupt ones they are currently "fans" of
I have this suspicion that when some people saw Heneral Luna, ang takeaway nila ay “Kita mo na
Kaya okay lang yung matapang tsaka palamura e” rather than the bigger and more important lessons that the movie tried to impart about nationalism
Quezon shows complexity, not blanket moral equivalence
It shows a flawed man achieving monumental goals, but critically examines the cost
It is a brilliant and challenging piece of filmmaking with terrific performances from the cast
It should be watched, discussed, and debated for years to come

I’ve always loved antihero narratives, and Quezon fits that mold perfectly
The film illustrates how populism can bring one to power
It skirted on a single word, "independence", and forces you to ask what it has ever truly meant
After all, the government we have now is the same one we’ve always had, merely dressed in different fashions for each generation
But where the film stumbles is in telling historical facts
Too much of its narrative hinges on the fictional character Joven Hernando and his descent into Quezon’s pitfall of populism and cronyism
This might have worked if Quezon were intended as historical fiction
But it's not
It focused too much on Joven’s disillusionment and Quezon’s perspective that it glossed over factual events a historical film should have covered
Overall, the film was both compelling and timely
I only hope we finally learn not to mistake charisma with integrity
Lies and manipulations, however noble the cause, are always self-serving
In a nation built on lies, speaking the truth is the greatest act of defiance
When will we ever learn
Only history can tell
But one thing is certain: every strongman, liar and fascist cult leader is destined for downfall

It's odd that a film so much about a man who campaigned on national independence, whose supposed saving grace is that he ultimately did bring it about, says so little about what that independence even meant
This film adds nothing to the discourse of national independence
This is another glossy entry to Jerrold Tarog’s “Bayani-verse” series of films, which some have described as an attempt to deconstruct the Philippine national hero
It's the most fictionalized of the three*
And it's another one that gets worse the more you think about it
Hopefully it’s the last, as they say, for I have no interest in seeing another one of these movies about Ramon Magsaysay
My biggest issue with this film in particular is that it subsists so much on the surface of its subject matter that it fails to say anything interesting about the context in which its events occur
What does it actually say about the 50-year American occupation of the Philippines
What does it actually say about Manuel Quezon as a president
As a leader of the country
What does it say about how everyday Filipinos experienced his rule
Does it say anything at all
It's mostly about Manuel Quezon as a politician, or more so, how he performs politics
It's about his two-facedness, his scrupulousness, his constant need to one-up his political opponents at any chance he gets
The film successfully contextualizes the absurd spectacle of 21st century politics by telling us that its roots go back to the very inception of our political independence nearly a century ago
But this is also where the film's issues lie
The film appears to critique Quezon for how he participated in and fine-tuned the garish spectacle of modern political campaigning, of setting the stage for our present day election cycles
But despite the film’s acknowledgment of the shallowness of these tactics, it still chooses to disproportionately focus on them
It reduces the American occupation of the Philippines to a series of interpersonal squabbles, as opposed to focusing on the actual impact of Quezon’s rule over the Filipinos at the time
Based on what we see in the film, the legacy of Manuel Quezon is in how he engaged with politics, as opposed to the impact of his actions on everyday people
But what was the actual situation of Filipinos back then
One of the only times we hear the perspective of a farmer is to highlight their ignorance of the word “independence
” A few scenes later we hear Osmeña and Quezon agree with Leonard Wood that the Filipinos just aren't ready for independence yet
But why
The film doesn't explore it further

And in the latter half of the film, some of the more intriguing critiques of Quezon’s political impact on the country are undermined by the fact that they’re coming out of the mouth of Emilio Aguinaldo, the Bayani-verse’s primary villain
There's just no inkling at all in the film of what life was like for the average Filipino under American occupation or the Quezon-led Commonwealth
We need to be looking past myopic personalizations of the past
We need to think about the actual situations of the Filipino people
We need to think about what independence actually means and what form of "independence" we actually got, both in 1935 and 1946
We don't need more Great Man biopics
Does the film have anything to say about independence at all
We hear the word constantly bandied around like a slogan, as if saying it out loud is enough to signal what the country needs
But the filmmakers don't bother to unpack it
Perhaps the real-life Quezon also didn't explain what was meant by this in the 1920s and 1930s, but that shouldn't excuse our filmmakers today
Unless they genuinely believe that all independence entails is a democracy to vote for our leaders
Perhaps a good question to ask is the opposite
How did Quezon continue the structures of colonial dominance during his rule

What the film seems to try to say is that our first president embodied a lot of the best and worst qualities of many politicians today, but ultimately, it can perhaps be justified because it was for something greater — it was for our independence

But it doesn't bother to explore what this proposed independence even means; it doesn't bother to distinguish political and economic independence; it doesn't even offer any useful corollaries to thinking about these issues today
So why was this film even made
*What makes it so much more fictionalized than the previous two films is the huge prominence of the narrative conceit of telling the film through the perspectives of Joven Hernando and his daughter
The closing down of Hernando’s Alerta publication and the idea of a young female director shooting short films to publicize Quezon’s campaign are totally fictional
There was some suppression of the press, for sure, during Quezon’s time, but Alerta doesn’t have any direct correlates
Perhaps it’s more to symbolize the shut down of ABS-CBN during Rodrigo Duterte’s term
And I could be wrong, but I don’t think Quezon had films made about himself to promote his campaign
Ferdinand Marcos definitely did though
**Very briefly towards the end of the film we get a 30-second critique of Quezon's impact on patronage politics and the disbursement of spoils (pork barrel)
That's good
But I don't think it makes up for the other 130 minutes or so of the film that takes more seriously as an issue scandals such as whether he had a first wife or not
And that closes the Bayaniverse

Eternally grateful for Jerrold Tarog for the Bayani trilogy/Bayaniverse
The series may have ended, but our fight continues
MANUEL L QUEZON
The third film in the Bayaniverse series, Quezon, finally arrives a decade after Heneral Luna
Once again, Jerrold Tarog proves himself as an icon of Philippine cinema
As the film’s writer, director, editor, composer, and producer, Tarog demonstrates complete creative freedom
His distinct artistic voice resonates throughout the film
Tarog doesn’t shy away from drawing parallels between the political struggles of the past and the issues plaguing the Philippines today
It’s disheartening, as a Filipino, to realize how history continues to repeat itself, where those in power remain driven by greed and ambition
The film also challenges how we view Manuel L
Was he truly a hero
Have we been blinded by the glorified version of our history, knowing only the good side of his leadership
These questions lingered with me long after the credits rolled
Visually, Quezon excels
The production design beautifully transports viewers to the past, recreating the era with meticulous detail
I was especially excited to see Iain Glen, though I admit I was a bit disappointed by how limited his screen time was
Jericho Rosales, on the other hand, delivers a refreshing performance, showing a side of him we haven’t seen before
Still, I felt the film could have explored more, particularly Quezon’s pivotal role as the “Father of the National Language
” That historical thread seemed missing and could have added more depth to his character and legacy
Overall, I genuinely liked Quezon
While Heneral Luna remains my favorite, this film stands strong in its own right
It’s thought-provoking, relevant, and undeniably crafted with passion
Perhaps it could have benefitted from more time in production, considering it was shot earlier this year, but its brilliance still shines through
Rating:  (4
5/5) — A brilliant and insightful look into our past that continues to speak to the present
The shining stars of QUEZON are the charismatic performances, intricate impartiality and visceral storytelling
Its place in the Bayaniverse and the entire trilogy itself acts as a strong reminder of the country's implications of its actions and choices
Perspective is the game in the politics of this time - Quezon exploits it to his advantage; a businessman in essence, a fiery public speaker, a charismatic strategist, thus leading him to power
Rosales captures the eponymous character with such gusto, power and dynamicism
One could say he indeed was Quezon in the flesh
But, this is still the Bayaniverse
Through journalist Joven Hernando, plus his filmmaker daughter Nadia in this film, provide an impartial lens where the modern audience is their envoy
Hernando's arc through the trilogy has satisfyingly gone full circle
Powerful for a fictional character in this context
Quezon brought this game - these political tricks, to light
Then us, the current generation, young and old, can still feel its heat
But at this point, it's a sprawling fire, unable to control
Is the future actually equipped enough to take it down
Ultimately, that's for us to decide
This film leaves viewers in deep critical thinking, as what this trilogy has gone out to do, and they've done it triumphantly
Between the humor, lightheartedness and cinematics, the questions confidently linger through, lasting long after the credits roll
If you haven't watched the first two movies of the Bayani series, I suggest you should
Although it did not affect the understanding for this movie, you'll have a better grasp of the other important character's background

The movie Quezon shows how patronage politics started in the Philippines
It’s a plea for people to always be critical because not everything is as it seems, especially when power and politics are involved
Dakila ang paglilingkod, but we can’t deny that even the brightest minds, no matter how noble their intent, have their own interests to protect, whether it’s power, greed, or pride
The film also leans into the idea of politics as performance, where charisma and public image often overshadow truth
It blurs the line between sincerity and spectacle, showing how easily stories can be staged, not just on screen, but in history itself
Beyond its message, this film feels like a love letter to the older forms of cinema now rendered obsolete by technology
In a world full of unfinished or half-hearted stories, it's admirable that Quezon made it to the screen despite all the odds
The more I think about the state of film today, the more I realize how fragile the whole industry is
The infrastructure is massive, and if one part of it falls, whether it’s funding, distribution, or technological support, the whole system would crumble
Watching Quezon in theaters felt like joining a fight to keep cinema alive
But it also made me realize that in a world where storytelling is changing rapidly, staying critical of what we consume is more important than ever
As technology brings new voices and narratives, we must stay aware of how stories are shaped
Quezon shows how the politics behind a film can influence its message, reminding us to be conscious of the contradictions in storytelling, especially with complex topics like politics

Quezon did not have the action and angst of its co-Bayaniverse film Heneral Luna nor it did not have the suspense and romanticization of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral but what it did have is a very intentional unraveling of a revered historical figure
This third Bayaniverse film is probably the best and my most favorite

From the very beginning of the film it captures you with its unique treatment of blending in a non-linear narrative with the meta-ness of using silent films as a medium to tell the story while it being contained in its own film
I admit at first there was some confusion in terms of the timeline and the determination of what is reality in the case of the film but as I patiently watched, it all meshed together really well
The end product was so good
I was waiting on moments where I could point out "show-don't-tell" moments but the expositions and explanations of what happened were really visualized and conveyed in such creative manners
Was it info overload
Well, if you didn't have any background/knowledge on Philippine History, it will be
But still, it's not a reason for someone to not watch it cause it will make you understand
Jericho Rosales, Karylle, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado really stood out
Manuel Quezon was personified through Jericho Rosales' effortless and magnetic performance
He embodied the late president so flawlessly
Karylle's Aurora Quezon was so specific and precise with her portrayal
Her eyes spoke a thousand words and she made us gravitate towards her in every scene she was in
Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmeña was a crowd-favorite
The eventual first Visayan President was performed with charm and likeability
Even sometimes stealing the scene away from Quezon
But my favorite performance in the film was Mon Confiado's Emilio Aguinaldo

I don't know if I'm being biased because my great grandfather was one of his secretaries but the way Emilio Aguinaldo was written and performed in this film is so complete and really bookends his character arc since he was first seen on Heneral Luna
What I love most about this film is that it vilifies no one but at the same time it does not champion anyone as well
Yes, Quezon was a really influential and well-loved president
Dare I say, the first true performative-male
And in a country where celebrity and politics win the votes of the people, he really, admittedly, played a good game
If he was in Game of Thrones he could've sat on the Iron Throne
It did not smear Quezon's name in any way, yet, it revealed to us who he really was and how he played the game
I keep going back to "game" cause this was basically the main theme of the film
A poker-playing politician who always aim to one-up his foes, and even friends
He played the game right but at what cost
People being stuck between colonialism and independence, propaganda against the heroes who fought for our freedom, and a never-ending cycle of patronage politics that was mentioned in the film
I'm so glad I watched this film and I learned about this
And what's funny is that the silliness that happened during their time is still the same silliness happening in our politics up to this date
Senators and congressmen further delaying our countries progress, pork barrels and nepobabies, the "utang na loob" culture in politics, all of these are still happening today
Now it gets me questioning whether the fight they fought was really a success or are we just in a new hell created by being collateral damage from their wars

I guess to end this on a positive note, at least now we have people waking up, we have strong journalist and filmmakers ready to be the voice of truth, and the Filipinos are now desperate for a change
may this film be one of the flames that will truly ignite our fight for a better life and TRUE INDEPENDENCE here in our country

Good movie that is carried by its excellent performances and undeniable timeliness
It does a good job of paying reverence to the Quezon’s legitimate political savviness while also depicting the back and forth of the political game as something childish and worthy of contempt
The movie is at its best when Jericho Rosales fires on all cylinders by being as abrasive and forceful as possible

Its these scenes, where Quezon seems deathly close to crashing out without actually doing it, where you can’t help but be mystified by his character, while simultaneously growing increasingly tired of him
The biggest problem with the movie is the problem with all the Bayaniverse movies, and a lot of movies in general nowadays, which is that it cannot help but over-explain

I get it, Manuel Quezon doesn’t exactly have the most well-known biography, but I feel like there’s a bit of projection that the audience won’t be able to understand the story without all the narrative cues, or the themes without the use of Joven as a narrator
Perhaps im more optimistic about Filipino literacy than i should be, but at some point, Jerrold Tarrog just needs to trust the audience
Joven is an incredibly lazy storytelling device that he has used as a crutch for three movies now, and made this movie twenty minutes longer than it should’ve been
I don’t need him to tell me what the movie is trying to say, and we can’t train audiences to be more literate if he keeps telling them

If Joven still somehow shows up in the next movie despite ostensibly being over a century old by then, please either end the cinematic universe as a whole or reveal that he was Juan Ponce Enrile the whole time

Jerrold Tarog's Quezon isn't just a historical biopic; it's a masterclass in political drama and the long-awaited final word in the Bayaniverse trilogy
This film brilliantly connects the trilogy, giving us the clearest and most satisfying explanation yet for the complex state of Philippine politics and leadership
At the heart of this engrossing narrative is Jericho Rosales' magnetic performance as Manuel L
Rosales embodies the former president as a charismatic, cunning, and fiercely intelligent political operator

He portrays the energy, oratorical flair, and sheer force of will that defined Quezon, making it clear why this complicated, flawed man was able to navigate the brutal political game and change the course of history
It's a powerhouse portrayal that anchors the entire film
The fear in a dialogue-heavy historical film is a dragging pace, but Quezon defies it
The film moves with precision and purpose, making its runtime feel taut and engaging
You'll find your eyes peeled and attention held by the intense political maneuvering
This is history not as a dusty textbook, but as a live, urgent confrontation with power, compromise, and charisma
It confirms that the greatest battles for the nation were not just fought on the battlefield, but in the corridors of power
love the political drama & hint of wes anderson influence

Hindi ako kulangot, wag mo akong binibilog
This film is or at least tries to be everything: a biopic, period drama, political satire, hays code era slapstick, old man yaoi, telenovela etc
Despite the seemingly conflicting tones, Jerrold Tarog and the creative team was able to juggle with grace and precision the different facets of Manuel Quezon and a nation's coming of age
Jericho Rosales is a revelation in his portrayal of the titular role

He spoke Tagalog in a slightly high-pitched almost-comical voice, and would switch to English in the accent of a timog-katagalugan everyman combined with the transatlantic cadence of a prohibition era radio personality
Equal parts charming and ruthless, hysterical and terrifying, he treated the character of Quezon as a ringmaster, and the Philippine Legislature his three-ring circus

As with the two other entries in Bayaniverse, Quezon holds a cinema screen-sized mirror to its audience as it peels away the layers of the man who planted the seeds of trapo culture in the Philippines

This is as much a character study of Quezon as it is of Joven, the makabayan surrogate character present in all three films, as he realizes in a full circle moment that even he and his uncompromising ideals of the Philippines' independence are susceptible to propaganda
Jerrold Tarog made a bold creative choice to cast deeper doubts on the conspiracies surrounding the murders of Andres Bonifacio and General Luna
He asks us viewers to look beyond the historical narratives we accept as facts, and to make wiser decisions on who we should put on the pedestal next as a hero of the nation

But the accompanying track also somehow fasttracks certain transitions that make the flow of the story a little disorienting at times

Quezon isn’t just another film
It’s a bridge between the raw, emotional grit of indie cinema and the accessibility of mainstream storytelling
At its core, it’s a story about a protagonist who feels more like an anti-hero
Quezon could easily fit the mold of a Marvel villain, his intentions are clear and rooted in conviction, but he’ll do whatever it takes to achieve them
It’s all about perception, really, and how morality can shift depending on where you stand
Di siya masamang tao
Pero willing siya gawin ang lahat
Para sa kanya or para sa bayan niya
On the technical side, the film shines
The use of parallelism, the sharp direction of Jerrold Tarog, and the deliberate framing from Pong’s cinematography all reflect a meticulous attention to detail
As an aspiring filmmaker and cinephile, you’ll find yourself appreciating every choice they made; nothing feels accidental
The performances are equally impressive
Every actor fully embodies their role, responding naturally to one another
There’s no unnecessary showboating, no scene-stealing, just grounded, organic acting that serves the story
Emotionally, Quezon hits hard
It’s not an easy watch, but it’s a necessary one
The film mirrors the pain and complexity of the times we live in
It feels like an origin story for where we are as a nation today
As a frustrated creative from the Philippines, this is the kind of film that makes you proud
Quezon is proof that we can create something deeply cinematic, intelligent, and emotionally resonant, something that can stand proudly on the international stage
