"Bayan o sarili, pumili ka

"The Bayaniverse may have ultimately been a series of movies that are (if not for the same cast members/ completely standalone, but the bigger picture it paints is asking us the same question John Arcilla's Heneral Antonio Luna once asked a decade ago: "Bayan o sarili
""Heneral Luna" is about a man who is dedicated to giving the country its rightfully earned freedom, no matter who he has to piss off to get it
"Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral" is about a man who ultimately takes the fight, despite his selfish and somewhat childish nature
"Quezon" is about a man who is nothing but a slimy and greedy politician who uses the country's independence as a bargaining chip so he can gain power and keep it for as long as he lives
The movie tells us outright that Quezon is not a good man, nor is he the hero of this story
He is a villain who uses every dirty trick in the book to remain one step ahead
It paints a picture of Quezon that is all too familiar to the everyday Filipino: a politician who plays dirty games to gain sympathy so they can climb higher into power
I love how Joven Hernando, who has always been the audience surrogate, has become a more active participant in the story
He becomes one of Quezon's pawns, another piece he could use to further his agenda
And once Joven reverts to his roots and once again becomes an observer, that's when the rug is pulled from under him
Joven is human
He is just like the "heroes" we've followed throughout the trilogy, flawed

Quezon brings the Bayaniverse into a solid finish, bringing back everything that came from Luna and Goyo all so it can ultimately tell the big punchline: Aguinaldo outlived every single one of the people we've followed in this trilogy
The Bayaniverse doesn't treat each and every single one of its focus as a holier-than-thou hero, but rather, humans who are just as flawed as everyone else
And in this landscape where every other biopic in the Philippines is treated like a glorified Wikipedia list, it's a breath of fresh air
Now, nobody knows what happens after this movie, after Bayaniverse
Who knows, maybe the Magsaysay tease could lead into a new trilogy that once again examines the Philippines and how we've become who we are today
Whether that happens or not, I'm glad we got to see these three movies come to life, the long way round
And if this does lead to another trilogy of movies, you know where I'll be

I can never forget the optional reading given to us in Kasaysayan 1 class by Prof
Karl Poblador
It was Alfred McCoy’s paper “Quezon's Commonwealth: The Emergence of Philippine Authoritarianism”
I was shocked at first at how absurd the title seemed
Quezon being the blueprint of dictators like Ferdinand Marcos Sr
and Rodrigo Duterte seemed like a stretch
The common Filipino mostly associates Manuel L
Quezon with positive things
The Father of Philippine Independence
The face on the P20 bill
Ama ng Wikang Pambansa
Namesake of the most populous (maybe even the best) city in the country
Strangely though, historical films about the struggle for Philippine independence rarely focus on the life of the first President of the Commonwealth
There are countless cinematic imaginations of figures like Jose Rizal, Andres Bonifacio, and Emilio Aguinaldo
But I can only remember one film about Quezon, the very bland Schindler’s List knock off Quezon’s Game
Quezon is portrayed as a stoic hero, allowing Jewish people to seek refuge as Nazis and World War II circle in on the country
After reading McCoy and watching Jerrold Tarog’s film, that film even looks worse
Tarog’s Quezon is what exactly the country needs right now
A repudiation of the myth of a “Great Man” and his legacy
A stark reminder of the illusion of Philippine independence and the role of native elites in perpetuating the very system the foreign colonizers used for subjugation
The election race between Aguinaldo and Quezon, framed as a battle between the old and the new, even resembles the upcoming 2028 presidential race between the Marcos and the Duterte dynasties
A choice between two evils

The screenplay is impressive in its weaving of multiple timelines in Quezon’s political career, examining the key relationships (Sergio Osmeña, Emilio Aguinaldo, Leonard Wood, the fictional Joven Hernando) that defined it
It reminds me of The Social Network and Oppenheimer in its nonlinearity, an always welcome structure compared to the dominant cradle to grave biopic structure
Black and white 1930-style sequences, featuring the best looking shots of an otherwise blandly photographed and colored film, frame the entire narrative
And it is here where Tarrog’s screenplay surprises in its examination of the role of cinema in political propaganda and collective imagination
Joven, the Bayaniverse’s audience surrogate, finally becomes a compelling character, as he wrestles with supporting Quezon’s presidency

The humorous tone is another welcome approach, playing up the ironies of Quezon’s political decisions from being a collectivist ideologue to supporting the working class to slightly changing an independents act to take credit away from Osmeña
The tone is a good contrast to the rather dull self seriousness of the preceding Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral
Quezon is a comical figure: a petty, narcissistic, scheming con artist
A far cry from the image of a noble patriot many have
Jericho Rosales radiates an almost DiCaprio-like energy and charisma; the loudness of Rosales’s Quezon, in his verbal sparring and speeches, masks the shallowness of his intentions for independence
Tarrog’s screenplay does flounder with the theme of the hollowness of Philippine independence
“Do you know what independence means
”, asks Governor-General Wood to peasant Filipino farmers
The scene seems to be played for laughs at the expense of Filipinos who are portrayed as having a simplistic understanding of the meaning of freedom
Rather than further visualize the plight of working class Filipinos, the film does relegate them to the margins
The formation of Quezon City, the planned home for Manila’s laborers, is a pivotal moment in Quezon’s political career and the country’s history
And yet, the film omits or does not tackle what would have been a perfect illustration of Quezon’s contradictions
But, to the film’s credit, it is long enough already
Perhaps it’s best discussed by another film
Quezon is a rare biopic in this country
We’ve had cinematic deconstructions of Filipino heroes like Rizal and Aguinaldo already

But never has there been a film that demystifies a supposed hero as nothing more than an egotistical opportunist — not unlike the greedy and insincere politicians at the center of the ongoing DPWH flood control investigation
Even if the film has flaws in its bland cinematography and visualizing the struggle of working class Filipinos, it’s hard for me to not be riled up after watching Tarrog’s Quezon
That’s great enough for me
The movie, “Quezon” by Jerrold Tarog completes the so-called BAYANIverse trilogy that also includes “Heneral Luna” and “Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral”

The trilogy (post-credit suggests a fourth biopic) was designed to deconstruct the myth surrounding Philippine national heroes by portraying them as flawed and complex human beings rather than perfect heroes we place on pedestals
This is an enjoyable, brisk, and highly opinionated biopic on Quezon

Making a film about history in an entertaining manner is always a challenge but Tarog and co-screenwriter Rody Vera passed with flying colors with a screenplay that intricately weaves historical facts with cinematic storytelling
They did this with the masterful insertion of fictional characters Joven Hernando and his daughter Nadia Hernando
They also avoided the pitfall biopics usually fall into—pointlessly following a chronological order and trying to present everything
Here, they used Quezon's political skirmishes with Leonard Wood, Sergio Osmeña and Emilio Aguinaldo to tell the story of the consummate politician
Kudos to Jericho Rosales for his portrayal of Quezon: temperamental, mercurial, and unpredictable
I had my doubts if he could pull it off when I saw the trailer but happy to have been proven wrong
He is at his best when attempting to charm his way out of a predicament and outwitting his adversaries
Quezon is undoubtedly a compelling and complex individual

“Elastic, electric”; “one of the world’s supplest and hardest-boiled practical politician”; these were some of the words used by John Gunther in an article for January 1939 issue of The Atlantic Monthly
But such reading of the man who became President of the Philippine Commonwealth, Gunther noted, was “only a fraction of the complex, composite truth”
The movie portrays Quezon as Machiavellian—scheming, manipulative, and self-interested
He bossed legislators using the largesse at his disposal, and by threatening them with political ostracism
He valued the loyalty and gratitude of those around him
He would reward those who helped and followed him with jobs and pensions
This is clearly portrayed in his relationship with Emilio Aguinaldo, whose farm and pension he took away when the latter dared to run against him in the country’s first ever elections
But Quezon was also “a genuine revolutionary” as Gunther noted, “the history of the Philippine Islands in the twentieth century and the biography of Manuel Quezon are indissolubly one”
He was also loved by the masses because of his support for the marginalized
He was the one who set minimum wages for government laborers, established an eight-hour working day, and slapped higher taxes on the rich
I had to rewatch Heneral Luna and Goyo before watching Quezon
I think the trilogy succeeded in reimagining these three heroes revealing more intricate, conflicted human beings
But I also hoped that the trilogy could have focused more on nation-building rather than personalities

I understand the need to focus on heroic personalities in these biopics but I hope viewers came out of cinemas not just thinking about heroes as history but also this: the road to nationhood and statehood is complicated
It is still unraveling today
It is still complicated
Saying that the Filipinos united against colonizers to fight for freedom and become one nation is naive
To be fair, Tarog hinted at this in Heneral Luna and Goyo by depicting the regional differences of the revolutionaries and how it contributed to Aguinaldo’s defeat
But can we blame the Ilocanos or the Kapampangans
The revolutionaries from the different regions were fighting for a nation that wasn't there yet
This was Jose Rizal’s obsession during his time—the lack of a national consciousness
He spent, and offered, his life to lay the groundwork for a collective national identity, a shared sense of being a nation
Quezon was more pragmatic in his approach
He said, “In statecraft the most important thing is the goal
” In other words, the end justifies the means
Quezon, of course, would never publicly admit that the goal of independence from the United States is intrinsically tied to ambition
To his mind, what hurt would it do if the national goal and his interest align
One of the most powerful moments in the film was when Joven was pontificating in front of Quezon, berating him for his greed and scheming ways
Quezon then turned the tables around telling Joven that he was in fact an accomplice because he also benefitted from Quezon
The US role in all these should not be diminished
By organizing local elections they essentially empowered local warlords to acquire power setting the stage for their capture of central government
There were instances when the movie relied too much on commentaries rather than storytelling
I really appreciate movies, especially those with political and social messages, that exercise restraint—when it does not tell us how to feel and what to think
Rather than spoon-feeding us it is more important to give us the opportunity to decide for ourselves

It is the same game in a new mask—the same battle in a different battlefield
It has always caught my interest that the Bayani-verse shows the humanity in figures revered by their good actions in the past
It grounds the character to a playing field in which we can analyze their actions and flaws as if they are not above us at all
It gives the audience space to ponder the differences between the praises given on history books and the reality of the human experience
Film is always such an amazing platform for storytelling in ways that capture essence and displays an overarching sense of humor in our lives even in serious moments
Quezon concludes the first battle by showing us that in war or in the pursuit of independence, politics has always been the same
It is rooted in tactics and is played out as a game

“Mauuna pa atang pumuti ang uwak kaysa bitawan mo ‘yang kapangyarihan mo
”Unlike the first two installments of the Bayaniverse, Quezon throws all subtlety out the window and says everything straight to your face
I took an elective on the History of the Philippine Presidency last semester, and we spent almost half of it just talking about Quezon
Watching the film felt exactly like that — a two-hour lecture where all the facts are dumped on you
Maybe that's not entirely a bad thing
Maybe it's better that there's no room for misinterpretation or assumptions of what the film wants to say
Maybe that's what we need as a nation: to be told, directly and unapologetically, what needs to be done for us to become better
Quezon feels painfully familiar because everything in it mirrors our current news cycle — a political shitshow where those in power do everything to hold on to it
At first, it’s laughable
But eventually, it stops being funny, and we’re just left angry
We deserve better than someone like Quezon
We deserve better than leaders obsessed with themselves but blind to the people they’re supposed to serve
We deserve better than naming cities after them or printing their faces on our money
We need to stop turning flawed men into untouchable icons and start being honest about what their legacies should look like
Tarog’s meta-commentary in this third installment is interesting, but the constant switching between the younger and older versions of the characters can get confusing
I get what he’s trying to do
He wants us to remind that history can be reconstructed or reinterpreted, but sometimes it pulls the story away from having emotional or narrative depth
That said, the ensemble was great, but Karylle was especially exceptional
The unsure, restrained, and quiet glances she gives when the camera lingers on her say so much about a woman’s place in our nation’s fight for independence: sidelined and often overlooked
As her character tells his husband, “Naniniwala akong naniniwala kang tama ‘yang pinaglalaban mo
”With Tarog’s Bayaniverse coming to a close (or is it
), it feels like the fight that should’ve started long ago is only just beginning
Saying “we should fight” can get tiring and repetitive, but then again, maybe that’s why films like this still matter
Because we still see leaders like Quezon today
But those people aren’t the Philippines
We are

Manuel Luis Quezon (Benjamin Alves as the younger version) inside the prison cell at the beginning of the film submits to a calling he himself invokes,an act of total surrender to the shining light of messianic delusion: he as a vanguard of freedom,a savior of the nation
This scene lays down the very blueprint of the man, and the DNA of the third film of Jerrold Tarog's Bayaniverse shown at such a time as this
Tarrog's deconstruction of Manuel Quezon easily reveals a pattern, the four chapters proving how the Commonwealth figure wields power
The film depicts Joven Hernando (Aaron Villaflor/Cris Villanueva) as the conflicted source of truth and keeper of lies, he being witness to the former and he being made to hide the latter
Quezon ought to strip Hernando of his journalistic freedom lest he (Hernando) destroy the masses' perception of the politician
Cassey, as the Americans call Quezon,orders silence as a tool that the film also uses to depict politics as a performance where Cassey plays the main part and masters it to perfection
Cassey's political campaign by way of showing silent films visualizes the performative act
A man plays someone he is not,living the dream so long as he has the power, so long as he is able to craft perception and accord himself the grandeur

His bouts against Sergio Osmeña (Romnick Sarmienta), Leonard Wood (Iain Glenn), and Emilio Aguinaldo (Mon Confiado) easily reflect what we see today: politics as a game, interests at the center, power as the ultimate goal

The scene where Quezon walks back to his seat after his speech while Aguinaldo walks towards the podium projects a duel reflective of the political motion that haunts our nation: each going a different direction but aiming for the same peak of dominance
The score is aptly dramatic and haunting, giving the scene the verve that seals what we make of our politicians--if we haven't settled that yet
Jericho Rosales brilliantly plays Manuel Quezon as the Senate President and the President of the Commonwealth by consistently creating the identity of the man who cannot be caught defeated
His performance naturally shows Quezon as a larger-than-life figure, the center around which everything revolves
That the film depicts him in this magnitude makes everyone else small, especially the masses whom he declares he works for
But not only are they rendered small; they are also voiceless and invisible
When a poor man defines independence as food, the film unmistakably captures power and its fuel

It rightfully pictures the masses being the ultimate victims of the fraud that is politics, the victims of the insatiable dreams of the narcissists where they (masses) are subconsciously the empaths that support their (narcissists) fantasy
And so we laugh because the film is a farce as much as it is a political drama whose emotional interjection comes at the far end of the spectacle
It comes as a silent wave of heartbreak and desperation
For ourselves
For our nation
How else should the film show Quezon at the end but the way the film does
Did his dreams come true
At a point where he no longer has influence,what are the words that matter
The film serves the closure we deserve from a man we've come to know from the very beginning,the consistency Quezon can never make himself to break because his nature will never allow it
His last words affirm his fantasy
Saying "I am the Philippines" can never be more delusional
To this day, we continue to see this delusion
And it harms us more than ever

Film Review: Quezon (dir
Jerrold Tarog, 2025)When I was young, Manuel Quezon was a romanticized figure, hailed as the one who earned the Philippines its independence, and also the “Father of the National Language
” Aside from that, I really know nothing about that guy
Several years later, I came across a copy of Ambeth Ocampo’s “Quezon’s Sukiyaki,” a collection of essays about several historical figures in Filipino history
It contained some interesting notes on Quezon’s boisterous nature
Further readings unraveled Quezon’s more devious side as a politician, which was the main theme of Jerrold Tarog’s newest film
“Quezon” chronicled the rise of the titular character from a veteran of the Filipino-American War to the president of the Philippine Commonwealth
The movie deviated from the typical depictions of the former president
Here we saw Quezon at his most unscrupulous, a true political chameleon
Whatever glazed images I had of the man evaporated after watching this movie
Suffice to say, Quezon was the original trapo
While it can be said that he genuinely cared about independence, he surely had his hands dirty, and his priority was after all, his own interests
Jericho Rosales was phenomenal in his role- adapting Quezon’s speech patterns and mannerisms
I was a bit skeptical when he was announced to be the lead, but Echo was a great actor after all and he surely proved it
Mon Confiado’s performance in this movie as Aguinaldo was a stark contrast from the other Bayaniverse films: the Aguinaldo in “Quezon” was more mellow, seemingly remorseful, softened by age
It was amazing of Mon to portray the same character in three different ways
The performance of the actors in this film was phenomenal, and I think everyone pulled their weight
I must specifically praise Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmeña
His bickering with Quezon was one of the film's highlights
I think “Quezon” was the most creative in all Bayaniverse films
I particularly liked the silent film snippets
It showed us the importance of media arts in shaping political opinions
I also appreciated the use of the rondalla as the main musical force of the movie: it made the movie sound more like a Filipino political comedy, compared to its militaristic predecessors
Compared to “Heneral Luna” and “Goyo” there were barely any action scenes in the movies
The battles were fought through verbal sparring, scheming, and persuasion
It was a unique Bayaniverse movie
I don't have many criticisms against this movie, although a certain cameo mildly soured my viewing experience
Also, I wish we saw more of the Japanese occupation, to see a different side of Quezon
I must say though, that the ending was hauntingly good
A great film, nonetheless

TANGINA ANG GALING NI JERICHOThe third and final installment of Tarog’s Bayaniverse trilogy is the best out of all of them in my opinion
Growing up, I have had this infallible—almost immaculate image of former President Quezon in my mind
He was always dubbed as the “Father of the Filipino Language” and it didn’t help that he was my Grandpa’s favorite president ever
All I heard about Manuel was good things
This film shocked me, as the once perfect image I had of this “great” man (and I put quotation marks on that word because iykyk) was systematically debunked by the exposition of all his flaws
Direct Tarog succeeded in humanizing this man
Jericho really disappeared in this role, as I was convinced that he was a direct 1:1 copy of Mr
Quezon himself
The mannerisms, the intensity, the accent; he nailed it and really captured the swagger of this “great” man (again, iykyk)
Mon Confiado is Mon Confiado, Rominick was great and very adorable as Osmeña, Iain Glen was excellent also, despite only appearing briefly
I loved the music, the occasional slapstick comedy, and the silent film parts
Could have been 5 stars but I found some scenes a little confusing and if it weren’t for that CongTV cameo lol

Simply an amazing film to end Tarog’s Bayani Trilogy
Quezon harnessed the strengths of its predecessors Heneral Luna and Goyo, producing a film with strong storytelling, great actors, and awesome cinematography
Although he did not physically look like the mestizo Casey, Jericho Rosales delivered an enigmatic performance well-deserving of acting awards

But among its merits, perhaps my favorite thing about Quezon is its pointed delivery of political critique not only towards the current administration but to the long history of corrupted, patronizing, and self-serving Philippine politics
I know for sure that it is not only me who feared that Quezon would end up sanitizing the former president’s image, as films about politicians and heroes tended to do so

But alas, Quezon was not usual biopic that mythologized the man — instead, it demystified him, reintroducing the former President that plastered his and his wife’s name all over his home province and the biggest city in Metro Manila
It was able to effectively deliver Manuel Luis Quezon as the cunning politician, borderline dictator that he is

Alongside his intelligent spiels and populist rhetoric, the film revealed the unapologetic and manipulative character of the 2nd President of the Philippine Republic — the man who laid the formula of political maneuvering for the politicians and would-be presidents after him, proving Alfred McCoy’s view that Quezon’s Commonwealth paved the way for Philippine authoritarianism
I do hope that Tarog continues to develop new historical fiction films in the future
More than ever, we need more films that tackle and communicate our history in interesting ways that provoke the audience to revisit our past and reexamine our stances on our ‘great’ men

This film was able to give the audience a stronger sense of discernment of Quezon’s politics and character through Joven, in ways that I had hoped was done through Heneral Luna
I need a rewatch of GOYO and HL
Quezon closes out Jerrold Tarog's Bayaniverse as a farcical deconstruction of the idea that one "Great Man" can lead a nation to prosperity
With Joven as the audience surrogate of the trilogy, Tarog makes sure that this myth is shattered
We see Joven slowly but surely become disillusioned as he realizes the dangers of putting a face to a political movement
Gone are the days where he puts these strong and charismatic men on a pedestal
This film feels the most pointed of the trilogy
Tarog's screenplay feels quite self-conscious as it sometimes overexplains itself
This film really wants to make a point amidst today's political turmoil
Politics is a game
It paints Quezon as a charismatic yet narcissistic manipulator who knew how to play it so well that he may just be the showman who invented political chess
He's basically a glorified "trapo" who's tidied up by our history books with titles like "Ama ng Wikang Pambansa
" His methods are the reason why Filipinos today are so swept up by populist and charismatic leaders
Whether we like it or not, his methods paved the way for the dominance of "trapos" in our Senate today
On the other hand, I feel like the lack of subtlety did remove the nuances and gray areas that I was looking for in a take like this
It does become just a fight between good and evil in some parts
For one, I did not understand the choice of glazing over Aguinaldo in this when even he lead a regime built upon manipulation
Felt like Tarog retracted from his stance against Aguinaldo in Heneral Luna where he was heavily villainized (deservedly so) in that third act
I also wanted more nuance with its take on Quezon himself
He was quite the showman who shifted his principles and narratives when it's convenient for him
I guess I just wanted more moments of self awareness and reckoning from him
Him being an egotistical maniac just felt a bit too clean and clear cut
Loved how Jericho Rosales just threw himself into this role though
Even if he is over the top, you really buy the charms and sales talking that he does in the film
Despite my gripes with it, I do think this is a refreshing historical biopic and I like how it played with its structure
It wants to make a point and it delivers with clarity and conviction
I ultimately do think this is a national hero biopic that we deserve right now as a nation
Something that will serve as a caveat and hopefully, an antidote to our deep fanaticisms with populists and demagogues

Tarrog’s most scathing work on a historical figure yet
At times, it can border into the saccharine, but that can be forgiven in consideration of the necessity for its themes to be communicated to the widest possible audience
However, much less forgivable is that in establishing Quezon’s manipulative and underhanded methods in politics, it may have presented his contemporaries, even the Americans, in a less critical light
Quezon becomes so comically evil towards the end that he makes everyone else look like saints
And yet, even as you grow to despise Quezon more and more, Jericho Rosales’ performance transfixes and commands attention
It should be praised that a portrayal that slimy and morally despicable continues to compel and leave you hanging on his every word
If not for the historical accuracy, a criteria I can’t attest to, watch this one for Rosales’ performance alone

The color grading was unexpected for a film that tackled the Philippine Commonwealth
It felt off, almost too modern for the time period it was supposed to capture
The play on jazz tried to reflect how playful and full of tricks Quezon was, but it ended up feeling out of place rather than symbolic
Watching it with the expectation that it would have the same weight or sharpness as Goyo or General Luna, medyo wala siyang dating
It lacked the same power, emotion, and impact those films delivered
The storyline and its modern approach made a few interesting points, but overall, it felt just okay
The movie leaned in on how the Philippine press was going against the idea of too much “idealism” and not enough on honesty

The Philippines has always had issues with its government, and the film, while trying to shed light on a heroic act, missed the chance to question the systems and attitudes that kept those issues alive
Since the beginning, it’s always been about finding leaders who are good enough—but sometimes, films like this forget that good enough isn’t the same as good

Quezon is Jerrold Tarog’s most refined film in his historical trilogy
It’s amazing to see how far his cinematography and editing has sharpened compared with the relatively low budget Heneral Luna
I hope he lives long enough to make movies about Marcos and Duterte
Quezon is probably the most politically relevant film right now in the Philippines
It's an indictment of the so-called "trapo" system that has caused cancer to our society, and how a man like Manuel Quezon set a dangerous precedent in the political game
The film made it clear that this was the root cause
It's impressive that they managed to make this biopic without full reverence to the subject matter
This also feels like the best potential of a Filipino historical biopic
Everything feels lush, and the scope feels big, and yet it's a personal and intimate story about an event that will have prolonged effects in the future to come
The entire cast was great, especially Jericho Rosales, Mon Confiado, and Romnick Sarmenta
The ending was sublime
The film reminds us that we're long overdue for a political reform
The characters that we saw here are pretty much like the ones that we're seeing in the current political space
It is an in-your-face message, but a needed one today

This is by far the weakest installment in Tarog's Bayaniverse, and yet a strong start for an "experimental screenplay" by the director
Tarog isn’t just known for his heroic-themed films but also for horror works like Shake, Rattle & Roll
This time, however, it's different
He used plenty of comedic acts—so much that I almost forgot the film was a drama—which made it feel very unconventional and rare for him to explore such an approach
Still, he was clever and creative for going unorthodox, especially since the film revolves around sheer politics
It was dense with overwhelming dialogue
Perhaps he decided to use comedy to maintain the audience’s attentiveness, as casual moviegoers tend to have short attention spans and might easily doze off
I think it was intentional, and he just saved his cinema from a bland, dull, and boring screenplay
As for the main character, Jericho Rosales did excellently in this film
He gave an astounding performance as Quezon—enough to provoke the audience’s emotions
The mannerisms, gestures, and expressions were on point
However, I believe there might still be another actor who could’ve portrayed Quezon better, as there were scenes where the acting felt somewhat unnatural, as if he was "acting an acting
" On the side of fiction, Joven’s monologue never disappoints
From Luna to Goyo to Quezon, the consistency is just commendable

In addition, I really loved Tarog's uniqueness with his cinematic strategies on how he delivered the story of Quezon, plus the coin as an allegory, which is something I couldn’t explain in detail because it’s better if you watch it on the big screen
I still have a lot in mind, but I wish I were that diligent to write it all down
Anyway, this film is rated as a standalone piece, not part of the trilogy when the first two are taken into account
Overall, the film was entertaining, and the production was, as always, all-out
If you can, please watch it in cinemas
It’s worth watching

Sa panulat at direksiyon ni Jerrold Tarog, isa itong historical drama na tumatalakay sa buhay ng kinikilalang ikalawalang pangulo ng bansa na si Manuel Luis Quezon (Jericho Rosales) at kung paano niya nilaro ang politika
Ito ang pangatlo sa Bayaniverse ng nasabing direktor, una ang "Heneral Luna" (2015) at ikalawa ang "Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral" (2018)
Sa higit na dalawang oras na takbo ng pelikula na puro diyalogo, napanatili nito ang aking interes dahil sa kakaibang direksiyon nito

Bukod sa paglalagay kay Joven Hernando (Cris Villanueva at Aaron Villaflor), nakatulong dito ang satirikong tono nito sa halip na isalaysay lamang ito nang tuwiran na makikita sa naunang dalawang pelikula
Nakatatawa na nga ang mga eksena, malalaman at maiuugnay mo pa ang mga patutsada sa kasalukuyang lagay ng politika sa bansa o sa sinumang politiko
Hindi naman kataka-taka na maitatagpi ito sa kalagayan ng pamahalaan ngayon
Ang may mas dating para sa akin ay ang gampanin ng mamamahayag sa lipunan

Ayon nga sa nalaman ko sa nadaluhang online seminar workshop para sa mga mag-aaral na mamamahayag at tagapayo ng pahayagang pampaaralan, walang obhetibo sa pamamahayag dahil may pinipiling anggulo ang tagapagbalita kaya mahalaga na maging mapanagutan at mapanuri sa isisiwalat tungo sa paghulma ng isipan at boses ng sambayanan

Kung patuloy na mas nagbibigay ng atensiyon ang mainstream na midya sa mga walang kawawaang paandar ng ilang opisyal, bago man o beterano, kaysa sa mga napapanahong isyu at adbokasiya, hindi na nakagugulat kapag nanalo ang mga ito kung sakaling tumakbo ito sa mas mataas na posisyon
Kitang-kita ito sa pelikula sa tulong ni Joven Hernando at ng kaniyang anak na si Nadya
Sumunod, kapuri-puri at kapani-paniwala ang pagganap ng mga artista
Noong una na nasa post-credit scene ng Goyo si Benjamin Alves bilang Manuel Quezon, nakakasabik dahil kamukha niya ito
Nang binago ito at naging si Jericho Rosales, nagtaka ako pero namangha pa rin kasi kamukha rin
Ngayong napanood ko sila pareho, palagay ko na tama na si Rosales ang gumanap dito
Kitang-kita sa kilos at pananalita at iisipin mo na si Quezon ang kaharap mo
Bukod dito, nag-iwan din ng impak ang ni Romnick Sarmenta bilang Sergio Osmeña at muling pagganap ni Mon Confiado bilang Hen
Emilio Aguinaldo
Hindi rin nagpahuli sina Karylle bilang asawa ni Quezon at Angeli Bayani bilang asawa ni Aguinaldo
Panghuli, nakatulong din ang disenyong pamproduksiyon upang maging kapani-paniwala hindi lamang ang pagganap ng mga tauhan pati na rin ang tagpuan ng pelikula
Nakapag-ambag din ang musika at tunog sa tono nito

Sa kabuuan, nagkaroon ako ng kawili-wiling karanasan sa panonood nito dahil sa bagong direksiyon, kapuri-puring pagganap, kapani-paniwalang disenyong pamproduksiyon, at angkop na musika at tunog sa pang-uuyam nito
Batid nga natin na may kanser sa ating lipunan ngunit bakit ba natin pinipili pa rin ang mga trapo
Dahil sila at sila pa rin naman ang tatakbo
Dahil kilala ang apelyido nila at may malawak na makinarya sa pangangampanya kaya naniniwala tayo na sila ang magpapaunlad sa atin
O dahil naging kuntento na lamang tayo sa paniniwala na kurakot naman silang lahat
Hindi man namamalayan ng karamihan ngunit may paniniwala na may ambag ang "Heneral Luna" sa kaisipan na ayos lamang na may palamurang pinuno
Sa "Quezon", nangangamba ako na baka ang mapulot lamang ng karamihan ay iboto na lang ang kahit na sino dahil tiwali rin naman silang lahat

Quezon es una épica de historia que prácticamente se desenvuelve como una versión Filipina y claramente contextualizada de House of Cards

Tomando el panorama de la política del siglo XIX y utilizándolo para desarrollar una narrativa llena de una energía muy clara y el muy firme propósito de crear un paralelo con el sentir social contemporáneo
Enfocándose en una lucha política sin cuartel y dividida en capítulos que abarcan décadas de movimientos sociales filipinos

Manteniendo un tono eficiente, que le permite ser divertida en un sentido irónico y lleno de ligereza pero que no le resta seriedad a las implicaciones morales de los movimientos de sus protagonistas y sus adversarios

Llenando la narrativa entera de personajes con moralidades grises, llenos de culpas y virtudes y enfrentándolos en una lucha política que encuentra la forma de resultar divertida y trabajar con una narrativa no lineal

quezon: the emancipation of patronage politics

‘Quezon’ challenges its viewers to step back and critically re-examine their views on heroism, nationalism, and leadership from a moral compass by projecting a character that once stood at the cusp of burgeoning pressure for independence by opposing Filipino revolutionary and American imperialist fronts

Although the film still embodies the overarching themes of its predecessors, Quezon’s most notable feature was finally cementing Joven into the “bayaniverse” (or more accurately, the “Aguinaldo Trilogy”) not just as a mere spectator or narrator, but as a key and active player in Tarrog’s world — a powerful symbol resembling the Filipinos’ evolving compromises and complicity amid the turbulent socio-political landscape of the time
An essential spin on a familiar trope, Quezon is by far the most comprehensive de-construction of “what makes a hero” in Tarrog’s roster of historical epics
A must watch for the incredible performances, especially from Echo and Mon

If it's not yet apparent by now, Jerrold Tarog is on a mission to strip our heroes of their reverence and enigma, and in the third installment of the "Bayaniverse," he focuses on a war of a different kind --- a war waged not with bullets and bayonets but words and propaganda
As a political drama, "Quezon" is a nailbiter
There is enough history lesson here to make one revisit old textbooks, and some of the issues surrounding the larger-than-life Manuel Luis Quezon are brought to light
My only gripe with this is that the script does very little to nothing with the issues presented
The film is only concerned with exposing MLQ as a flawed man --- perhaps as a reflection of the current Filipino politician who will do whatever it takes to amass power
I also found the portrayal of Aurora Quezon (Karylle) a little jarring

While there was an intention to highlight the immense potential of women to shape society (as with Therese Malvar's fimmaker character), Aurora on the other hand is given almost nothing to do but be a sounding to board to her husband (Jericho Rosales)
In one climactic scene, where Quezon's secrets are thretatened to be exposed, the camera cuts to Aurora for a reaction shot --- and then nothing

The issue would no longer be discussed for the remainder of the film, and we never really see how Aurora views her husband in light of his duties as a husband, a father, a politician, and as a leader of a nation
The film also commits several sins of omission, including the portrayal of Leonard Wood as a mere bureaucrat, completely neglecting his involvement in the Bud Dajo Massacre in 1906

Nevertheless, the ensemble piece features several noteworthy performances, led, of course by Rosales as Quezon, Benjamin Alves as the younger Quezon, Mon Confiado, who will forever be associated with the Emilio Aguinaldo role, Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmeña, Cris Villanueva as an older Joven Hernando (a fictional character used to bridge the three films) and Iain Glen as Leonard Wood
Of the films in this trilogy, Aguinaldo gets the most interesting story arc in "Quezon," as do Joven
The humor, too is at par with the best bits from "Heneral Luna," which is fitting I guess because what is politics in the Philippines but a big farcical extravaganza
Something to commend here as well is the film's use of the silent film era to portray Quezon's rise to power, leveraging the power of images to form (or better yet, manipulate) public opinion

As "Quezon" takes place during the rise of cinematic consciousness around the world, it is nice to hear Murnau, Fritz Lang, Nepomuceno, and Harris and Tait mentioned in the same breath as the country's exodus towards independence from American rule
One thing I missed here was Epy Quizon's calming voice of reason as Apolinario Mabini, but by this timeline, Mabini is already dead (he died in 1903)
Perhaps a voiceiver from the dead
Perhaps not
In closing, is "Quezon" a perfect film
Like the person it portrays, it is far from perfection
But is it provocative
Does it invite dialogue and introspection into our complicated history with truth, idolatry, and the persistence of patronage politics

written and directed with precision by tarrog, quezon is an entertaining and smart depiction of history's manchilds and the "heroic" games they play for the "independence" of the nation
its double-edged sword, however, is its effectivity in critiquing and being propaganda

while it critiques film as the very medium for this ideological and calculated systemic myth-making (we are rooting for comrade nadia), it also falls under this trap by centering narratives on the humanity of history's people with less attention to the bigger powers in play that hold the strings to these figures

by focusing on quezon’s child's play hiding over his performed wit and individual brilliance, the film risks personalizing what is, at its core, a systemic issue: that philippine politics has always been a performance crafted under the watchful eye of american imperialism

politicians will choose their ideological stance based on available choices, independence is highlighted as the goal of the masses who is alienated by its very language, and in every six years, we will be given choices for leaders who will never trully represent us
the film eventually reveals this control, but the critique is softened, overshadowed by the dramatized rivalry between the opportunist quezon and leonard wood, and other names in history
the bigger villain, the structure that rewards political ego and molds philippine politics and elections to all be a game, remains unscathed
it is named
but it seems like right now, like quezon, we end up turning toward the nearest villains — within reach, within us

there is this sort of doomed faith that the audience harbor, only to get disappointed with the characters’ actions, hence making it more humane
these people, despite being heroes, are fallible
as you get deeper into the film, you get to realize and understand why certain people act the way they do and how their brain works

if history were a movie, Quezon would be the scene where the lights stay on too long where the glamour fades and all that’s left is the politics, the pride, and the people pretending not to notice the cracks
i went in expecting something noble, something textbook
but what i got felt… human
painfully human
quezon (jericho rosales, absolutely magnetic) isn’t painted as a saint here he’s ambitious, clever, exhausted, and aware that being “good” doesn’t always win you the game
it’s that messy, moral middle ground where idealism meets ego, and somehow that felt more honest than any patriotic speech ever could
and then there’s aguinaldo
he’s not the villain not really
he’s just another man trying to keep his version of the world alive
it’s poetic in this haunting way that the movie reminds us: he was supposed to die early, yet outlived everyone
the whole lineup
and that irony
it stings
like history laughing quietly in the background
but what hit me hardest was how quezon shows corruption not as an event, but as a tradition
it’s not a scandal that shows up one day it’s baked into the foundation
this movie doesn’t even need to say it outright; you just feel it in every handshake, every campaign promise, every smile that lasts one second too long
by the end, i wasn’t just watching a historical biopic it felt like a loop
like we’ve been here before
same speeches, different microphones
same dreams, slightly more polished lies
Quezon isn’t perfect, but maybe that’s what makes it hit
it’s hopeful and heavy at the same time like loving a country that keeps breaking your heart but you can’t walk away because it’s yours
If there’s an alamat of the pagiging Pinoy TraPo, maybe this is it

"Masyadong maraming pulitiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan
"I hate history classes, but I love revisiting history through travel, museums, and movies
Quezon (2025) is exactly the kind of film that makes history come alive
even for those who never liked it
It’s funny, sharp, and feels like a political satire about the past that mirrors the present
The film follows former President Manuel L
Quezon’s political rise and how he played the game of politics brilliantly, but not always cleanly
If there’s an alamat of the Pinoy trapo, maybe this is it -- the origin story of politics as performance (just for show)
Jericho Rosales nailed the role of Manuel L
I’ve seen clips of the real Quezon before, and every time Rosales spoke, it felt like I was hearing the late president himself
They don’t even look alike, but he captured Quezon’s spirit perfectly
Benjamin Alves, who played the younger Quezon in the silent film sequences, also impressed me
Alves could easily carry the role in a full-length version too
Supporting actors also deserve credit
Romnick Sarmenta (as Osmeña) complements Rosales well
Karylle, as Aurora Quezon, was charming but underutilized, perhaps reflecting how women were sidelined back then
In contrast, Angeli Bayani, playing Aguinaldo’s wife, had limited screen time but left a strong impression
Mon Confiado’s take on Aguinaldo was refreshing, showing a more vulnerable side (though I still have to see the other movies in the Bayaniverse)
Arron Villaflor and Cris Agustin, as Joven Hernando, were remarkable too,you almost forget they’re fictional characters
Though a biopic, the movie plays like a satire
It’s unserious but smartly so funny, biting, and painfully familiar
The humor lands because the parallels with today’s politics are impossible to ignore
Everything feels like "pang front lang" and the nation’s welfare often comes second to pride and image
As I said, it might just be the origin story of the Pinoy trapos
Maybe Quezon didn’t invent dirty politics but as Joven Hernando puts it, he perfected the game
By the end, you’ll find yourself asking: What does independence (independencia) really mean
Are we truly free, or have we simply learned to believe we are
Maybe it’s like Plato’s “noble lie”, a story told to keep people hopeful, obedient, and proud
Tayong mga Pilipino, ika nga ni Romnick Sarmenta bilang si Osmeña, “hindi naman tayo kulangot, pero bakit tayo binibilog
”Maybe it’s because we love beautiful stories, stories that let us escape, even when they blur the line between truth and illusion

A decade ago, Jerrold Tarog asked the Filipino audience what it really meant to be a hero
With his Bayaniverse, he aimed to deconstruct the heroes that we've come to know during our history lessons as kids
In Heneral Luna (2015), he showed us the fiery and passionate patriotism that is willing to do anything to protect our freedom

It introduces the idea of mythmaking, as it positions the entire Philippine–American War into the hands of its protagonist, and by killing off the only person who could have led us to victory, the government simply proved that our biggest enemy was not the Americans but our own Filipino countrymen—ourselves

Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018) breaks this down further, showing us that the hero we glorified all this time was nothing more than a blind fanatic who died a futile death out of his arrogance and lack of experience—all this time, all he had to offer was this confidence and loyalty to his president, and nothing more
Then came 2025's Quezon
As he states in the film:"Ang pagkabayani—it's all about perception" (Being a hero—it's all about perception)
Becoming the hero means you get to decide whose story gets to be told and how it is told
In this third and final installment of Tarog's Bayaniverse, we follow the life of Manuel L
Quezon (Jericho Rosales), who would go on and become the first Filipino elected to head a government of the entire Philippines after 34 years of being governed by American governor generals

All throughout the film, we see him in different stages of his life through different chapters, depicting how he manipulates his way from the bottom to the top, including his conflicted relationships with Sergio Osmeña (Romnick Sarmenta), governor-general Leonard Wood (Iain Glen), and even his former president, Emilio F
Aguinaldo (Mon Confiado)
Penned by Tarog and Rody Vera, this concluding chapter of the Bayaniverse trilogy is a fun, engaging, yet biting and farcical take on its titular character's meteoric rise and eventual downfall

Intending to portray the historical figures in the film series often regarded as national heroes as "flawed characters," the film, while showing the achievements they accomplished, also shows their cunning and manipulative tactics to get where they wanted to be

The best comparison I could come up with for Quezon is Orson Welles' 1941 film, Citizen Kane, which also features the rise and fall of its main protagonist (Quezon even opens with a series of silent films, similar to how Citizen Kane introduces its main character through a series of newsreels)
It's structured similarly too, told in a nonlinear narrative

Unlike Heneral Luna and Goyo, Quezon is divided into several chapters, with each of these beginning with Quezon headbutting with someone to achieve his goal, highlighting how he played many political games to secure his survival and to maintain his power

Another departure for the film is its setting—while the first two films are set during the Philippine-American War, this latest film explores the period of American political supervision that followed, eventually leading to the founding of the Philippine Commonwealth
It doesn't have the big battle scenes of his first two predecessors and instead focuses on the war they fought within their offices and desks

Unlike its predecessor, whose battles occur in sweeping landscapes and terrains complete with all the explosions and gunfights, Quezon is mostly confined in enclosed spaces and is more dialogue-driven
It's also the most visually imaginative film in the trilogy, as it incorporates a series of silent films to create the myth behind Quezon's heroism

The film creates different tones to emphasize the varying timeline and mood for several sequences: black-and-white color grading for the silent film sequences, a vintage palette look to depict the time of the young Quezon (played by Benjamin Alves), realistic and vibrant three-strip Technicolor for the old Quezon, and a dull and dreary tone for Aguinaldo

This also highlights the difference between the way the public embraced Quezon and Aguinaldo's candidacy—one with color and life, while the other was marred by the death of Andres Bonifacio and Heneral Luna
The film's production design managed to stay true to its milieu too, beautifully captured on camera by Pong Ignacio, who returns from the last two films
Most importantly, the film depicts the evolution of two of the trilogy's most important characters: Joven Hernando and Emilio Aguinaldo
In the film, Joven is played by Arron Villaflor as the young version, while Cris Villanueva is the older one
Unlike in the first two films, where he is depicted as merely an observer for the two titular heroes, here in the third film, he becomes an active participant in the story
However, he is no longer the reliable narrator that he once was, as we realize that he himself has turned a blind eye to Quezon's flaws as an individual and as a politician

On the other hand, the film looks at Aguinaldo with a gentler and softer view, portraying him as this weakened veteran who tries to fight against the giant that Quezon eventually turns out to be in the film, falling victim to his propaganda
And this is where the film's strength lies: with its powerful cast

Mon Confiado delivers a more nuanced turn here as the veteran Emilio Aguinaldo, perfectly complemented by an equally restrained yet compelling performance from Angeli Bayani playing his wife, Maria Agoncillo-Aguinaldo
Arron Villaflor is brilliant as always portraying Joven Hernando, but Cris Villanueva adds another layer of depth to his character

Benjamin Alves also has an interesting part in the film, as he portrays the young Manuel Quezon but also as the actor portraying Quezon within the silent film world, existing on two separate planes and blurring the lines between fiction and reality and between the revised history and actual memory
Of course, Scottish actor Iain Glen deserves a special shoutout for his portrayal of Governor-General Leonard Wood
Karylle also deserves some praise for her understated yet exquisite performance as Aurora Quezon
Romnick Sarmenta also impresses as Sergio Osmeña
But the one who really carries the film from start to finish is none other than Jericho Rosales, with his committed performance as the titular Quezon
Honestly, I was expecting Manuel L
Quezon to have a somewhat full and deep voice, but when I saw the videos of his actual speeches, Rosales nailed his pitch and tone
It's fun to see Rosales as Quezon manipulates his way through politics using one trick after another
He dazzles with his stirring and dedicated turn as the late president, warts and all
Rosales perfectly captures the cunning nature of his character—a two-faced Janus head who uses deception and whispers sweet nothings to charm and manipulate everyone around him like chess pieces
With Quezon, Tarog delivers his ultimate thesis statement: that heroism isn't black or white
We have to understand the grey areas in between
The heroes depicted in his trilogy did a lot of good things that led them to be celebrated as the heroes they are known as now
But like any other human being, they also did some pretty bad things—and Quezon, sadly, did a lot
He inadvertently paved the way for patronage politics, or the spoils system, to take over our government—one that is still prevalent today
His intentions started out as noble—he wants to give the Philippines the independence it has sought after for so many years
But along the way, he realizes that he has to play by the rules, bend some promises, and ultimately lie for what he believes is good for the country
Sadly, the things that he did led him to crave and hold on to his power for as long as he could
Later, Quezon exclaims:"I am the Filipino people
I am the Philippines
" He spent the entire film creating this image of him as the only person who could bring independence to this country—by hook or by crook
But as we see his final image in the film, we all come to the very conclusion that Quezon is nothing but a megalomaniac
He is not the savior he thinks he is
He is but a man
I always had a keen interest in history

I think this started with my likes to learn about what happened before and knowing all these famous people that the cartoons and shows I watched as a kid that keep on referencing, such as Thomas Jerferson, Benjamin Franklin, etc
This was further cemented by the social studies classes we had that focused on historical events of the world and the like
Philippine history was one and this led me to be more appreciative of what we went through as a nation

Naturally, this pushed me to more interested with movies that portrayed this events, even tho they weren't as accurate to what they wanted to represented *Ahem* El Presidente *Ahem* Fast forward to the release of Heneral Luna and Goyo, I was blown by how the films tried to show these people with a degree of understanding that wasn't as seen in previous historical movies portraying Heroes
Luna and Goyo made me feel angry and surprised, respectively
And now with Quezon, rarely do I get to see Philippine cinema being continued like this
One that continues to show how the past can be a reflection of what we are today, especially when it comes to politics
Its dirty, bloody and downright a game to some
I was sceptical at first with the announcement of Jericho taking the role of Quezon
All those worries faded once he got lost into this performance as the convicing, and coniving, president
Past and new characters were also introduced, adding so much to the story and how they all relate to one another
They portrayed well the friendly banters, conversations, and even betrayals
This connectedness and being one in a shared universe is amazing and works well with this film and the films before, even if each one feels different and stands on their own
The Bayaniverse feels like a proper universe and one that I wish for more Filipino films
This is a culmination of trying to define and portray heroes in ways that don't treat them to be outright heroes
No, these are people who are both perpratrators and victims of their own aspirations, dreams, agendas, laurels and even mistakes
This further pushes us to question those who led us before, and even those who lead us in the present
I'm looking forward for more films like this
And judging from the movie, I have a good feeling that there will be more

Hindi kasing emotionally charged ng Heneral Luna, o kasing tahimik at mapanuri ng Goyo, ngunit may sariling bigat at diin ang Quezon
Dito, ang digmaan ay wala na sa larangan ng putukan; nasa entablado na ng pulitika
At gaya ng lahat ng magagandang palabas, bawat ngiti, bawat pakikipagkamay, at bawat pangako ay may kasamang pinag-ensayuhang pananalita
Jericho Rosales delivers one of his best performances yet: charming, makinis, pero mapanganib
Bilang Manuel L
Quezon, hindi siya ipininta bilang bayani kundi bilang isang politiko na marunong maglaro ng sistema
Hindi niya winawasak ang istruktura ng katiwalian; siya mismo ang bumuo nito
Ang trapo sa katauhan ni Quezon ay isang masalimuot na larawan ng kapangyarihan
Nakakatawa siya sa kanyang karisma ngunit nakakikilabot sa likod ng ngiti, kung saan namamayani ang tuso at mapanlinlang na pag-iisip
Ang direksyon ni Jerrold Tarog ay mas pulido at teatrikal kumpara sa unang dalawang pelikula
Halata ang diin sa blocking, sa staging ng mga eksena, at sa simbolismo
Parang chess match na bawat galaw ay may kapalit
Ang cinematography ay malinis, kulay-aristokratiko, at puno ng simetrya, na tila ipinapakita kung paanong ginawang perpektong entablado ang politika
Ang musical scoring naman ay naglalaro sa pagitan ng dalamhati at panunukso, na tila tugtugin ng isang entablado kung saan ang kapangyarihan ay ginagawang palabas
Hindi ito kasing-sakit ng Heneral Luna o kasing-lalim ng Goyo, ngunit mararamdaman mo ang maruming realidad ng politika
Naroon ang mga kasinungalingang nakabalot sa magarang retorika, at kung paanong ang kalayaan ay maaaring gamitin bilang produkto ng kampanya
Dito mo makikita kung saan nagsimula ang mga siklong hindi pa rin tapos hanggang ngayon: utang na loob, padrino system, at ang walang katapusang pagbilog sa ulo ng taumbayan
Tarog closes the Bayaniverse not with a scream or a whisper but with a smirk
Isang paalala na ang ating bansa ay itinayo hindi lang sa dugo ng mga bayani kundi sa galing ng mga manlalarong marunong tumaya
Sa dulo, hindi mo alam kung matatawa ka o maiiyak, dahil ang pelikulang ito ay parehong kasaysayan at salamin: mapanlinlang, maganda, at masakit tanggapin
Hindi ito aral tungkol sa kabayanihan; ito ay babala tungkol sa kapangyarihan
Sa pagtatapos ng Quezon, tila tayo ay nanonood ng salamin na bumabalik sa ating paningin
Dito natin nakikita na ang politika ay matagal nang pagtatanghal, at ang mga aktor ay nagpapalit lang ng kasuotan
Ang palabas ay nabago na ng panahon, ngunit ang manuskrito ay ganoon pa rin
Small kwento: We saw Mon Confiado before watching the film kasi may surprise talkback session siguro before our showtime
We asked for a photo, then ang sabi niya sa amin: “Please review the film
Bad or good, it’s okay
”I actually didn’t want to watch Quezon yet kasi gusto ko may talkback
I really wish every screening of Quezon had one
Somehow, it’s not enough that we just witnessed what happened on screen
It’s also important to have a discourse about it
I understand that would be difficult and probably impossible to do for every showing
But it's a nice to have
Jerrold and the cast spent months or even years researching these heroes, and it feels lacking if all that effort just ends in a two-hour movie
I’m sure there were stories cut short or ideas that couldn’t be fully explored
It would’ve been so nice to hear more about it directly from them
So we ended up dissecting the film among ourselves after watching
The first thing we all said was how Quezon made it so easy to understand Manuel Luis Quezon
The film is divided into chapters, and in each one, it’s clear who he’s up against and what they are fighting about
And in every chapter, he always comes out winning
Quezon is unafraid to exhaust all his resources and even resort to dirty tricks to gain the upper hand
He can come up with unorthodox ways to defeat his enemies, and sometimes, he even teams up with them to take down bigger and badder ones
Quezon is just good at what he does
But he also thinks so highly of himself as the savior of the Philippines that it eventually becomes his downfall
It’s all very interesting
Like Luna and Goyo, Quezon is deeply flawed
In our minds, he's a great president for bringing independence to the country
But we all agreed that we never really saw Quezon this way before
It’s also amazing how the old problems in the film mirror the issues we still see in Philippine politics today
Maybe even worse
I’d say Quezon is a must-watch
We had a blast watching it, and it’s even better when you get to talk about it afterward with friends or family

The third and final film in the Bayaniverse film series, Quezon is an eye opener for every Filipino that only know Manuel L
Quezon in the history books
The film showed Quezon's true color and the tricks and machineries he used to gain political power
If history can tell, mud slinging during the election campaign season has been a part of Philippine politics since time immemorial
It is ingrained in our culture and it will never be removed
Tarog and Vera's screenplay is also impressive
The Bayaniverse is now completed and I hope this does not ends here
Tarog and TBA Studios should continue telling the Philippine history post-World War II
The Bayaniverse is a true testament that Filipinos will spend their hard-earned money in movie theaters if a local film is executed well with great storytelling and screenplay

“The Philippine Assembly is yours—body and soul
”#QUEZON felt pretty much of a movie closer to our present day than did Heneral Luna and Goyo
I suppose it could be because of the timeline, but the events in this movie mirrored the present more harrowingly and realistically

I must say that my favorite scene in the film has to be the scene when a hauntingly troubled Aguinaldo was climbing up the stage in what pretty much seemed to be a miting de avance some time before the 1935 elections
When it was Aguinaldo’s turn to speak, he rose from his seat and walked towards the stage as the charming Quezon climbed down parallel to him
The background music intensified

The room did not know of the weight of the moment for Aguinaldo—only he and his Vice Presidential running mate Raymundo Melliza knew of what seemed to be their greatest leverage in the elections and against Quezon for all we know
The living evidence was there, present in that one corner—Quezon’s alleged first wife—a seemingly powerful instrument that could determine Quezon’s reputation
Aguinaldo had a smoking gun
Even I sat in the audience wondering, “Would he drop the ball

” Though Melliza was right in saying that they had no formal proof that the woman and Quezon were indeed married, the positive assertion could spark reasonable doubt on the perceived savior of the Philippines that is Quezon
The visibly horrified, pale-faced Quezon was standing aghast—would Aguinaldo get his own hands dirty as well

Perhaps, Aguinaldo’s option not to pursue the scheme significantly supported the image he had throughout the film: a noble, self-redeeming character in the nation’s struggle for independence who played the bigger man and refused to revenge out of spite
Another interesting point that made me leave the theater with more questions than answers was the re-introduction of Capt
Janolino, the man who made the first blow on Hen
Luna upon alleged orders from Aguinaldo some three decades ago
History tells us that Ka Miong purportedly sent four telegrams to the general, instructing the general to meet with him in Cabanatuan
Janolino sent the first attack, striking the general in the face while the others followed suit
In the film, Janolino was brought to Joven, the fictional figure, in order to clear his own conscience and finally become the man who lived to tell the tale
Janolino told Joven that his conscience no longer could contain the guilt, and that Aguinaldo indeed ordered the Luna massacre while handing Joven one of the four telegrams

History is not just about going back to the past, or connecting it to the present; it, too, is about questioning the narratives that we have long grown up believing, and more importantly, questioning what really was the truest truth about the motives of the people that shaped our history, yes, even forty, sixty, or ninety years apart
There is no question that Janolino was a blessing that came to Quezon’s lap at the right place and in the right time
We know the man
Quezon was too old of a hand in politics, or rather, in the craftsmanship of political manipulation
Quezon had Janolino as his final act of ragebait against Aguinaldo, leading to the latter’s eventual loss in the elections
But the question that left me mentally running in circles was, was Janolino really sincere in coming forward
Or was he yet another opportunist who took the chance to clear his name before anything happens to his life
Worst, was he yet another strategist who switched sides when it was most convenient to feast at the banquet of Quezon’s Senate as his Sergeant-at-Arms
We never know
We could only do so much as cast a doubt on true intentions, no matter how impractical, to really arrive at the truth
Was Janolino’s coming forward an altruistic move, or was it a plot to be thyself’s own saving grace
If you know the reference, good for you

Anyhow, despite the complicated cable spaghetti of neophyte Philippine politics, one can deduce but a single, unfortunate fact that not even Quezon, in a hypothetical redemption moment of his, could deny, and it is this: that corruption is as old as time, and that much of what we see today is utterly of little to no difference with what the country suffered before
It’s all a real déjà vu, only worse
“The Philippine Assembly is yours—body and soul

” If, before, the yours Quezon “sold” the people to are the Americans, now, the ones who sold the Filipino people and the yours these people are sold to are our fellow Filipinos: politicians who connive among themselves to lay bare the people as mere commodities
I am not so sure for everybody else but to me, that sounds like holding up a mirror in the face of Philippine history, except this time, the canon events seem more horrid
May the lessons of history cease to remain as lessons
May we make them cease to remain as lessons
Vote wisely
Think critically
Fight courageously
———PS: Props to Echo

“ Independence is good enough to eat “Quezon stands out from the bayaniverse movies that came before it — whereas Heneral Luna and Goyo had themes of war, Quezon portrayed political dramas, intellectual battles, and the performance of Manuel Quezon as a political leader
Quezon goes beyond its purpose of entertainment, it is a reminder of all the wrongdoings of our leaders due the mind games these leaders have instilled into our political system
The film is very timely for our political milieu, it shows how politics is like a game of chess — you take as much as you can from your opponent until they have nothing left
Politics aside, this film knows how to tell a story creatively
I enjoyed the “film within a film” aspect without it falling flat or cliché, I found it extremely satisfying
FUTANGINA ANG GANDA
Every scene feels so cohesive and proper, like a political debate of some sort
I loved the juxtaposition between Quezon and Aguinaldo’s scenes — the loud and blaring music and overbearing lighting for Quezon, and the almost quiet and dull lighting for Aguinaldo
Everything was so tight knit and well executed and truly added more to the story
This film is truly thought-provoking and is definitely a cinematic experience as a Filipino

The movie Quezon was really nice because it showed a different side of President Manuel L
Quezon that we don’t usually see in our history lessons
In school, we just learn that he was the first president of the Commonwealth and made Tagalog the national language
But in the film, he was shown as a kind and brave person who truly cared for people
One scene that touched me was when he helped the Jewish refugees during World War II
It showed how he wanted to save lives even if it was hard for him and his government
If I compare Quezon’s time to politics now, I feel like there’s a big difference
Quezon really cared about people, while some politicians today care more about fame and power
The way Quezon stood up for what was right reminded me that leaders should have strong values like honesty, courage, and compassion
The movie made me realize that our country needs leaders like Quezon—people who think about others before themselves
If we all had those values, maybe our society would be a better place

The press releases brand Quezon as the third in Jerrold Tarog's "BAYANIverse" trilogy, but it's quite clear early into the film that Manuel L
Quezon, the second President of the Philippines, doesn't quite live up to the term "bayani" or hero
Yes, he was instrumental in taking the country through its first steps into independence from its colonial masters, but the film also unabashedly shows him as manipulative, petty, and spiteful

Worst of all, particularly in the context of today's incendiary socio-political climate, the film explicitly blames him for laying the foundations for the patronage politics that has plagued the country for decades
It's certainly not stress-free viewing for those among us who are already anxious over our current national situation

If his highly skilled work on the gem Sana Dati and the first two entries in the BAYANIverse films, Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, did not manage to convince you that Tarrog is one of Pinoy cinema's most masterful directors, this film should
His direction of Quezon is superb
Sequences are creatively and tightly shot, producing a beautiful rhythm that belies the films runtime of over two hours

The [silent] film-within-a-film is a very nice touch, showcasing Tarrog's ability to balance pathos and humor, and also conveniently explaining why young Quezon is played by another actor (Benjamin Alves) in the first two films
Jericho Rosales is pitch-perfect as Quezon
His Quezon is cocky and assured, but also vulnerable and volatile

Cursory surveys of old video and audio clips of Quezon make it clear how well former matinee idol Rosales captures the Commonwealth President's vocal cadence, but the way he moves his body, a lot of which is presumably not visible in most existing videos, gives him ownership of the character
Rosales has proven his acting mettle in previous turns in both film and television, but this is probably the role that he was born to play
Among the supporting actors, the highlight is Mon Confiado as Emilio Aguinaldo, owning the role to the point that it's probably difficult to think of any other actor doing it as successfully
Confiado is often an uneven and divisive actor especially when it comes to loud, overtly physical characters, but here he shows how skilled he is with more quiet, introspective roles
The ever-reliable Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmena, Bodjie Pascua as Raymundo Melliza, and Angeli Bayani as Maria Agoncillo also give laudable turns
Meanwhile, Karylle, who is no slouch in acting, is barely given anything to do as First Lady Aurora Quezon, which is a shame because of Mrs
Quezon's stature in Philippine history
The technical details are admirable, particularly the editing and the production design, which provides a genuine period look and feel to the film

The black-and-white scenes give lenser Pong Ignacio room to play with light, but it's rather unfortunate that the makeup on the actors during those sequences makes them look like the ghouls from Herk Harvey's Carnival of Souls

The true standout, however, is the score (by Tarrog himself), which propels the film's pace with alternating whimsy and somberness, and it never feels out of place or overly used (which is very common in local films)
Quezon is a true cinematic achievement
For both its quality and its socio-political message, it is must-see Pinoy cinema

Sure, it takes liberties with historical accuracy (the filmmakers are quick to disabuse us of the notion that it's meant to be fully historically accurate), but it asks the right questions, just as Heneral Luna did (remember its iconic "Bayan o sarili
" challenge
Hopefully, the film's message does not fall on deaf ears and will further drive the social movement for true accountability and patriotism in governance

Growing up, I only knew few of his personal and political life from HEKASI and Sibika’t Kultura textbooks, so watching the film was full of surprises, every twist and turn caught my attention and kept me hooked
The reason why I love the Bayaniverse series is because it doesn’t just retell history, it shows the lives of our national heroes and questions what truly makes them a hero… or not
Take him, Quezon, for example
I found myself asking, Was he really a hero
Or could he also be a villain
Maybe Quezon was indeed a hero in governance and nationalism, but also a politician with many flaws
Through this film, we saw his strong will, pride, and even arrogance
Jericho Rosales, who played Quezon, did an amazing job
Honestly, if I had known that TJ Trinidad backed out of the role, I wouldn’t have thought of anyone else who could replace him
When it was announced that Echo would play Quezon, I was doubtful at first, mainly because they don’t look alike
But after watching the trailer and hearing him on Quezon’s accent, I said to myself, “Ayos 'to
” and I was right
His performance made Quezon feel real and relatable, showing not just the hero, but the man behind the title
His accent was consistent from start to finish, and the rest of the cast did great too, especially Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio
And for the first time, Joven Hernando’s role actually made sense to me, even though he doesn’t exist in real life
The music
I loved it
Just wow
It felt like a roller coaster of emotions, especially during the tense moments
Every background score matched perfectly with each shot
And the cinematography
Definitely a step up from Heneral Luna and Goyo
I didn’t expect the “film within a film” concept, but it worked beautifully
Overall, it was a great film, probably a fitting end to the Bayaniverse
Totally worth every peso spent and definitely a must watch Filipino historical film
And now, we’re all just waiting for the next multiverse to begin

”A timely end to the Bayaniverse trilogy
Quezon (2025) asks the question Tarog has been exploring since Heneral Luna and Goyo: what makes a hero
The film-within-a-film framing was clever, but it can create emotional distance
Also, when watching someone “perform” or “manipulate”, the audience may subconsciously hold back emotionally
So maybe that’s why I felt less connected to Quezon compared to Heneral Luna and Goyo
The film also has a tendency to over-explain things that could’ve been a subtext
It couldn’t have come at a better time, when people are holding leaders accountable and seeing through the spectacle
It’s a reminder that history repeats itself when we stop paying attention
TBA Studios deserves credit for keeping these stories alive
Filipinos need and want films that challenge, provoke, and remind us who we are
Watch this on the big screen and see for yourself how much has changed, or hasn’t

Jerrold Tarog delivers his third and final (maybe

) act of his Bayani-verse, and while it may not be the conventional trilogy that we expect where it gets bigger and more spectacular with each installment, Quezon is more gut-wrenching, diabolical and closely resembles the truth we have today in politics

It successfully and awkwardly shows us a mirror that continuously slaps us Filipinos in the face real hard with questions about fake independence and our failure as a nation, after Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2017)
Jericho Rosales played the role to the tee, an opportunity of a lifetime, with enough force and conviction
Other cast who stood out were Iain Glenn who played Leonard Wood and Mon Confiado's Emilio Aguinaldo
So entertaining to see Manuel L Quezon, Emilio Aguinaldo, Sergio Osmeña and Manuel Roxas, who I only used to see in paper bills, got brilliantly fleshed out on screen
Jose Rizal wrote Noli and Fili to provoke the nation para magalit, because anger signifies that we've had enough and that we need to take action
National Artists for Film Lino Brocka and Ishmael Bernal also did during Martial Law
Now Tarog, Jadaone, and other current film makers are raising the same flags so it is our duty to ask ourselves as a society
Many times I felt being pinched through the heart, kasi thats how its supposed to feel
Masakit marinig ang totoo, masakit aminin na kapwa Pilipino ang nagpapalubog sa kapwa Pilipino
Matagal na natin itong alam at naririnig, pero bakit paulit-ulit

That those movies supported the wrongheaded idea that all the Philippines needs is one strong leader to prosper

Jerrold Tarog is quite consistent
This film has both the faults and the strengths of its predecessors despite the change in tone and characters here

This trilogy sensationalizes these historical figures and is over-acted by much of its cast (although let's face it, that's a common issue within Philippine cinema), but it is also intentional in creating a narrative about the Bayani that makes a lot of sense when you look at the trilogy as a whole
Like the first two movies, this movie has so many odd creative choices where the intention is in full display but doesn't really serve the overall narrative

Case in point for this film, while the writing is funny at times, it feels so hollow because it's so evidently trying to get a laugh from its audience but fails in its purpose because it detracts from the story rather than enriches it
Many other such choices can be pointed out all across the trilogy
Overall though, I have to give Tarog his flowers
