Body and Soul
Finally got to witness the end of a saga that I can personally say I grew up on
As someone who loves history the “Bayaniverse” is franchise close to my heart
This time we got to do a character study on Manuel Luis Quezon
A man who is a prominent figure of our history
A political chameleon as to how others describe him
Heneral Luna was the “dagitab” that started it all, Goyo is fine film that dealt with the immediate aftermath of its predecessor and Quezon is this franchise’s final salvo
The pacing of the film is good
I liked how each scenes was able to give tension and stakes

My only nitpick was how the first hour of the film had a slower pace and then as we approach the end it felt rushed but maybe this was made so that it echoes Quezon’s desperate cling to power he built
Each scene felt like a game of chess and it is what kept me entertained
As a history fan I love it when I recognize people or events the people on the film talk about
Jericho Rosales as Manuel Quezon
How he speaks, his mannerisms, his quips were all spot-on
It was like I was really watching MLQ
Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio Osmeña shower how resolve and silence can both be a good and a bad thing
I wish JC Santos and Karylle had more screentime as I believe their performances were also so good
Mon Confiado as an older version of Emilio Aguinaldo was also a delight to watch
Ibang iba sa mga naunang Aguinaldo and I saw comments na they pity the old man but the way I saw it it, it was his karma that came to bite him
Quezon is a different film from the first two, it is not riddled with guns and canons, there is no physical war
Sabi nga ni Wood “We are fighting behind desks” and this political warfare is entertaining, riveting, and at most times fascinating
Nilatag sa atin kung paanong ang isang taong magaling sa manipulasyon at pamumulitika ay pinapaboran ng panahon
Ipinakita sa palabas kung hanggang saan ang kayang ibigay at kunin ng isang tao para sa kapangyarihan
Pero masayang panoorin ang mga ito dahil ito ay pelikula, nakakalungkot na ilang taon at pangulo na ang lumipas pero nakikita pa rin natin sa mundong ating ginagalawan ang mga pangyayaring ganito
Baka nga nasa Body and Soul na ng mga sisteman umiiral ang ganitong katotohanan

The most consistent thing about the Bayaniverse is that the series features some really good acting, and Quezon is quite possibly the most well-acted among the three

It features a huge ensemble of actors giving their best impression of the historical figures they are portraying, with Jericho Rosales and Romnicak Sarmenta lightening up the screens everytime they show
Sarmenta, in particular, is a complete scene stealer
Other than the acting and the pacing, Quezon is mostly lackluster in terms of storytelling
The film doesn’t have an interesting visual style, and its look doesn’t fit the ambition and tone it wants to achieve
The script, while commendable on its structure, features some really underwhelming dialogue that feels less punchy than its predecessors

Which is a shame, cause the dark comedy approach of Quezon gives the Bayaniverse another layer of intrigue: elections, in retrospect, are comedy puppet shows being run by puppet masters who are also attached to strings controlled by bigger masters

As the Bayaniverse trilogy comes to a close, Jerrold Tarrog delivers his best one yet
Simula pa nung una, ang ating gobyerno ay itinatag sa maliliit na pabor na lumaki bilang utang na loob
Utang na loob na di na mabayad-bayaran
Totoo bang nakamit na natin ang kalayaan
Ang independencia
O ipinahiram lang ito sa atin at balang araw ay babawiin ito kapalit ng tulong ng ibang bansa
Pinanood namin ng mga kaibigan ko ang Heneral Luna, Angelito, at Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral upang maalala ang mga pangyayari bago kami sumabak sa Quezon
Isa pang nangyari sa akin ay pinanood ko ang Pingkian: Isang Musikal na storya ni Emilio Jacinto haka noong siya ay nagdedeliryo sa tama ng baril noong panahon ng himagsikan
Isa sa unang linya ng musikal ay ang mga katagang,"Doon sa Biyak na Bato, pinatigil ang putukan
Isinuko ni Aguinaldo ang apoy ng himagsikan
" True to his style, ipinakita ni Direk Jerrold ang tao sa likod ng pagiging bayani
Na kahit isang matalinong heneral si Antonio, siya ay mainitin ang ulo at mapusok
Na kahit si Goyo ang paboritong Heneral ni Aguinaldo, siya ay nababalot ng takot kung ano ba talaga ang kanyang hinaharap, at bilang isang bata, hindi niya rin alam kung sino talaga siya
Sa dalawang pelikula ay makikilala mo rin si Aguinaldo, ang ating unang presidente, na nakadikit sa mga mayayamang miyembro ng kanyang gabinete
Unang tumatakbo pag parating na ang mga amerikano, at dala ang kanyang buong pamilya sa isang mahabang lakarin
May tatlong karakter akong hinihintay na makita; si Aguinaldo na kabado ako kung ano ang kanyang magiging storya
Siya ba ay bibigyan ng redemption arc
Si Quezon na tuso at naging batayan ng political warfare sa atin ngayon, At si Joven na tumanda na
Ginawa upang irepresent ang kabataan, ngunit ano na kaya ang kinahantungan niya ngayon

Quezon (2025): Jerrold Tarog At His Very Best
At its core, it positions the power of art and storytelling, both in good and in bad
Pure ragebait masterclass
Very entertaining
Almost blinding
With the gentlest reminder: History is dynamic
History permeates
Politics is just a gameQuezon strips away the textbook hero and shows Manuel Luis Quezon as a cunning, manipulative politician
He uses friends, secrets, and dirty tactics to rise to power, hiding ambition behind a public image of virtue
The film forces us to ask, if independence required deception, selfishness, and manipulation, is that the only way to achieve freedom
Should history be judged by outcomes, even if the means were morally gray
Politics, Quezon suggests, is a game — to win, one must be ruthless
To lose, one may remain virtuous
Quezon embodies both faces: public heroism and private ambition
He did what we think he will, but we didn't how he did it
He is not portrayed here as a hero, but a man playing the game of politics
We achieve what we dreamt but the price, corruption and power hunger is the payment
So Is it wrong to be selfish
Or is it right for independence
Quezon answered both

Quezon is a historical biopic of the Philippines’ 2nd President - Manuel Luis Quezon
Look what you can do with a big budget
Great cast
Jericho Rosales was a gem in portraying Quezon
Cris Villanueva did so well, with his very natural portrayal of his character, and of course - Mon Confiado as Hen
Emilio Aguinaldo, bravo
Jerrold Tarog’s direction and screenplay came out very strong and powerful in his 3rd “Bayaniverse” installment
Can’t wait for his fourth
This film, just like his previous ones - Heneral Luna and Goyo, mirrors the present through our past, showing how painful that we have not yet learned from the mistakes of the men of our history
This is a film that we should all watch
Every year, we should be able to tell this kind of story

Cast: Jericho Rosales, Benjamin Alves, Mon Confiado, Arron Villaflor, Cris Villanueva, Romnick Sarmenta, Iain Glen, Karylle, Jake MacapagalDirector: Jerrold TarogWriters: Jerrold Tarog, Rody VeraProduction Company: TBA Studios

Coming from the unbridled fury of Heneral Luna and the reflective nature of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, this installment takes us to the performance of nation-building, set not in battlefields but at podiums and facing cameras
Quezon, as the third larger-than-life figure, enjoys high production value as well, even if the centerpieces are explosive conversations and political machinations rather than fight scenes
Rosales as Quezon is a spectacle, with his high-pitched Tagalog-accented voice that mimics the gravitas of a transatlantic declamatory statesman
It matches, too, with the crux of his character being that of a man who learned from the Americans’ game of politics, and brought it back home

His performance and chemistry with the rest of the cast (namely his hilarious toxic yaoi push-and-pull with Sarmenta’s Osmeña and his dogged face-off with Confiado’s Aguinaldo) make a strong case for this film being the most entertaining of the three
Unfortunately, it may also be the one with the least heart in it
The senseless politicking and pandering to the promise of independence at any cost includes a pessimistic, self-referential plot point for the journalist character and his filmmaker daughter
The two fall prey to making propaganda for Quezon but ultimately can't make any definitive, concrete stand
It succeeds at holding up a mirror to the audience members watching, who decry corruption and bad governance, but cannot suggest or invoke any alternative
Quezon is a strong biopic and historical drama that satirizes politics through sensational slapstick moments starring some of the Philippines’ most known figures from the American period
For a dialogue-heavy film, it’s thrilling to follow thanks to its playful structure, making it stand out from its two predecessors which were mainly linear and battle-focused
What it didn’t really account for was the impact of Quezon’s actions
It only focused on the political spectacle that worsens the state of the nation and makes the dream of independence unreachable, even laughable
There’s a small scene where a farmer reveals that most people don’t understand what independence means

The film doesn’t explore beyond that — how the Filipino politicians and the American occupiers take advantage of this ignorance, what the average Filipino’s life is like, and why independence is such a pipe dream
Perhaps there we could have found the film’s heart

“utang na loob”a filipino value that still lingers the filipino society to this day, may it be in its smallest form or one that murks around the walls within our government: patronage politics

in the movie, it highlights how Manuel Quezon essentially gave birth to patronage politics in our nation’s government with how he deliberately moves around the walls of politics to set himself as the one with the most decorated achievements among his peers and foes
politics is a game for him
and in the end, he will use all his power to remain at the podium
all this to feed his ego
i believe that the release of this movie is relevant to the current issues Philippines is battling with today

just like Manuel Quezon, many politicians use “utang na loob” to their advantage, for their self-interest, which cost the lives of many ordinary Filipino people who are struggling everyday to make a living
moreso, this movie serves as a wake-up call to Filipinos that we must no longer be tolerant of how damaging patronage politics is to our society, especially on the topic of nepotism
i hope that one day, the concept of “utang na loob” will be redefined by generations to come
i hope that we open our eyes to see how this Filipino value has taken the route of submission to the one who has given you generosity
i hope that us, Filipinos, will one day, fully understand how “utang na loob” has impacted us in the grand scheme of things

As the Bayaniverse concludes with the film Quezon, we are left to ponder: Who are truly considered heroes
Does Heneral Luna—who, despite his temperamental and tactless nature, led his men to fight for the country at the cost of their own lives—fit the mold of a hero
How about the composed and charismatic Heneral del Pilar, known for his loyalty to President Emilio Aguinaldo
Or is it Manuel Luis Quezon, the first President of the Philippine Commonwealth, who relentlessly championed the nation’s independence
Unlike the tension-driven Heneral Luna or the meditative Goyo, Quezon leans toward diplomacy and vision—the making of a statesman rather than a soldier
Mon Confiado, reprising his role as El Presidente Aguinaldo, provides a strong emotional bridge across the trilogy
His nuanced performance ties the films together with quiet power—a fitting irony, given how Aguinaldo outlived these three who once served under him
Jericho Rosales, meanwhile, delivers a commanding portrayal of Quezon—a politician who knows how to play the game of politics, both as one of the chess pieces and as the one who moves them
This may well be the most compelling performance of Rosales’ career
Rosales and Romnick Sarmenta, who plays Sergio Osmeña, show an undeniable chemistry that is utterly entertaining
This dynamic between Quezon and Osmeña is refreshing to see, and is something that I just discovered from the film
While the cast performed well and Tarog's vaudeville-inspired storytelling was interesting, there was no singular standout in the film
The attempt to encapsulate Quezon's life after reading through 50 reference books made the narrative feel dense and uneven
The intent to inform and educate was there, but it came at the expense of smooth transitions and richer character development
A minor subtitle error ("kada buwan" translated as "per year") is forgivable, but the lack of emotional buildup for the audience was a missed opportunity
Many historical moments were highlighted, yet the film fell short in conveying their emotional and moral implications
Still, the complicated feelings I had after watching it are proof that the filmmakers succeeded in presenting a layered, complex figure in Quezon
In the end, the Bayaniverse is more than a trilogy of historical films—it is a mirror reflecting who we were, who we are, and who we hope to become as Filipinos
Through Luna's fury, Goyo's doubt, and Quezon's ambition, we are reminded that heroism is not born from perfection or victory, but from conviction and purpose

Perhaps instead of searching for a hero to emulate or a leader to inspire today's generation, it may be far better to embrace a collective effort—despite our differences—to build the change we have long yearned for across generations
Tarog's decade-long storytelling, with all its flaws and brilliance, draws us back to the past that shaped us and rekindles our desire to strive for a nation better than the one we inherited

The last of the Bayaniverse trilogy unfolds almost in tension with the first

While Heneral Luna (2015) almost glorifies nationalism and patriotism as the purest routes to independence, Quezon exposes a more unsettling truth: that nation-building, too, can be an enterprise of deception, politicking, and personal ambition
What struck me just as deeply was the film’s portrayal of the media
In the same way we inherited American politics and governance, we also inherited their media system
In the film, the two are almost indistinguishable
For Quezon, media is political machinery; politics, in turn, is media spectacle
To its credit, Quezon is an unforgiving dissection of a cunning man long revered in Philippine history as the architect of constitutional democracy
The film spares no illusions: it renders him not as a flawless hero, but as an American lackey who wielded independence as a political instrument for self-fulfillment
In the buildup to his presidential campaign, he is almost canonized as a saint, a portrayal that feels eerily symmetrical to the myth-making that defines our politics of today
I also think about Joven, how in Luna he was the youth whose fire needed to be fanned
Now, in Quezon, he was the people, blamed for falling victim to — and almost being complicit for having benefitted from — the very system of patronage
But the film offers more than this bobotante framing, as we observe Joven quite literally see through blind faith
Although the film had the tendency to slip into a romanticized treatment of Aguinaldo, it compels reflection on our country’s institutional memory
Why do we not know this Quezon: the ambitious, calculating politician beneath the marble statue
Why have patronage and our reverence for the West endured as the constants that anchor our political imagination
And why, almost a century later, do we find ourselves in the same predicament, still circling the same myths of power and nationhood
ON THE THIN LINE BETWEEN THE PLAYER AND THE GAME Politics—a word that replaced guns and ships in a war that’s been raging in our motherland, the Philippines, since the 19th century
This film explores it with uncolored lenses—free of romanticism, yet filled with quiet truth
Let’s dig into the visual cues Jerrold Tarog, the director, orchestrated with precision and purpose:  THE BLOCKINGTarog uses blocking as a mirror of Quezon’s state of mind
When he believes…

“I am the Philippines”The clashing philosophy is the undercurrent that carries this movie
It isn't explicitly delivered; it's not visible on the surface, but it is deeply embedded for those who look closely enough
We witness the vivid interpretation of the rise and fall of a truly great figure, supported by compelling storytelling
The cinematography is strong, the acting is excellent, and the production design is surely top-notch
However, I can recognize that the movie's portrayal was somewhat tempered
We move from a brutal Luna and the edginess of Goyo to a Quezon who feels more approachable, child friendly, fun, and bright
Perhaps this interpretation reflects an intentional focus on Quezon’s charisma, or maybe it’s simply how the filmmakers intended for us to view his specific burden
I deeply admire the film's message—the political philosophy—and how acutely it mirrors our current government
It forces us to confront the question of how we arrived at this point
The answer, the film suggests, is woven into our history; the seeds were planted long before we were born
This system is so profoundly rooted that it cannot be simply plucked out
This, right here, is absolute storytelling
The core concept isn't forcefully presented to the audience; instead, the film allows us to arrive at the message through our own contemplation
There is much more to discuss, but the direction and storytelling are what I loved most
I can confidently say that those who see this as the least installment in the trilogy are missing the point
Each movie is a unique and great piece on its own
But Quezon—it delivers a sense of euphoria, emerging as a brilliant work of art that demands appreciation

Quezon, in its very core, is a film that presents itself as satirical, perhaps offering a timely commentary on the Philippines’ current political landscape and the ongoing struggle with personality politics
Themes including power and ambition just resonate with contemporary issues in the Philippines, sparking important conversations about governance and nation-building
I do commend Quezon’s portrayal here, as if he were a challenged hero who is worshipped
Jericho Rosales’ portrayal of Quezon was commanding; he brought depth and nuance to the role, capturing the former president’s complexities and leadership style
His performance conveyed the character’s passion, conviction, charisma, and flaws, making Quezon relatable and human
In addition, Mon Confiado was quietly powerful as Aguinaldo
While the film doesn't glorify Quezon, it reveals the cracks and how ambition can stain even the purest intentions until history decides whether you're an ideal or a sinner
There is more to be discussed in the historical events depicted

I have nitpicks with this that I don’t know if it’s a good thing or a bad thing:1
The execution of this was disorienting at first
Because all of a sudden it was theatrical, vaudeville, and full-on period
But when the plot thickens, it suddenly makes sense — On how the politics at the time (let’s face it, until today), is just one big show and performance at stake of actual lives

And my most major thing with this:I BOTH LOVE AND HATE, I AM BOTH AMAZED AND DISAPPOINTED, ALL AT THE SAME TIME - On how this reflects to until today

Should we have taken more time to be colonized
No ill-intent in that question, it is purely a curious question

A thinktank, a conversation-igniter, which is how historical films should be
Especially in a country like the Philippines

On the critique that Quezon (the film) is vague in its idea of independence:That's exactly part of MLQ's politics: the wielding of power is being the origin or source of a great idea, the new republic as a goal only Cassey can achieve
That is how political campaigns are inspired
That's how devotion to political figures has taken its root
Whatever concept of freedom there is should appear like it's going to come directly from the politician

Independence being perceived as food conveys the idea that it's constantly asked, not fought for, by the masses that wait for 'ayuda' rather than the affirmation of their capacity to hold freedom in their hands
And why is 'independence' or 'new republic' mentioned in the film like a byword
It's because Quezon wears it like a badge
But it serves a more important purpose: It floats as a concept that's never really understood
It remains to be a hollow idea associated with patriotism
So it continues to be talked about because it's never truly experienced
Valid pa rin ang tanong na "What is a new republic
" hanggang ngayon
So it's odd to expect the film to define independence for us when what it does is actually more essential
We define it
I trust that we know how to
Sabi ni Cinemaster Nadz Amata:Simply an amazing film to end Tarog’s Bayani Trilogy
Quezon harnessed the strengths of its predecessors Heneral Luna and Goyo, producing a film with strong storytelling, great actors, and awesome cinematography
Although he did not physically look like the mestizo Casey, Jericho Rosales delivered an enigmatic performance well-deserving of acting awards

But among its merits, perhaps my favorite thing about Quezon is its pointed delivery of political critique not only towards the current administration but to the long history of corrupted, patronizing, and self-serving Philippine politics
I know for sure that it is not only me who feared that Quezon would end up sanitizing the former president’s image, as films about politicians and heroes tended to do so

But alas, Quezon was not usual biopic that mythologized the man — instead, it demystified him, reintroducing the former President that plastered his and his wife’s name all over his home province and the biggest city in Metro Manila
It was able to effectively deliver Manuel Luis Quezon as the cunning politician, borderline dictator that he is

Alongside his intelligent spiels and populist rhetoric, the film revealed the unapologetic and manipulative character of the 2nd President of the Philippine Republic — the man who laid the formula of political maneuvering for the politicians and would-be presidents after him, proving Alfred McCoy’s view that Quezon’s Commonwealth paved the way for Philippine authoritarianism
I do hope that Tarog continues to develop new historical fiction films in the future
More than ever, we need more films that tackle and communicate our history in interesting ways that provoke the audience to revisit our past and reexamine our stances on our ‘great’ men

jericho rosales
Another great interpretation of MLQ’s political life
It has a jumpy storyline, jumping from different timelines in Quezon’s life
Imo it’s not up to par with its prior bayaniverse movies (Heneral Luna goat), but the cinematography, theatrics, and plot delivery are surely Jerrold Tarog’s forte
The acting is also soooo good, Jericho nailed that accent
Hindi na ata talaga bago ang ang pagiging ganid sa kapangyarihan at pagiging kurakot ng mga pulitiko sa Pilipinas
Ika nga ay one politician after another — and nothing has changed
What a way to close out the Bayaniverse trilogy

From the ultraviolent chaos of Heneral Luna, to the somber introspection of Goyo, Quezon rounds things off as a psychological thriller-slash-political comedy-slash-drama that’s as ambitious as it is sharp
What I’ve always admired about Jerrold Tarog’s depiction of these historical figures is how human they are
There are no pure heroes here—only flawed men navigating ambition, ego, and nationhood
Quezon, played brilliantly by Jericho Rosales, is a political gamemaster: part statesman, part showman, and wholly cunning
I love that the film doesn’t dwell on textbook achievements, but rather on the intricate dance of manipulation, charm, and power that defined his leadership
Like the best Filipino historical films of recent memory, Quezon reflects its own era back at us—the politics of then echoing the politics of now, for better or worse
And while it’s billed as the end of the Bayaniverse, I hope this isn’t an exclamation point, but a comma—especially after that tantalizing post-credits tease

Here we begin with a shapeshifting exploiter on one hand and a docile, equally ambitious prowler on the other, juggled and brandished to trade barbs and heave vitriol at each other, both would later dismiss as mere politics to justify a much-needed partnership, then finding a common enemy in a chagrined former revolutionary leader and president
The ping-pong exchange of politicking and smear campaigns is its most coruscating part—electrifying to me, actually—a protracted look at our current politics' saddening origin

Quezon—now that there is no need for battle pieces, as that is not Tarog's turf—is the most polished in the entire trilogy, only slightly tarnished by its caricature bits and overreliance on fictional characters
The decision to minimize young Joven's speaking lines saves the entire cast's immaculate efforts from futility

It was so fascinating to see the things I've learned in history books be dramatized in film

What a time to be alive to witness a trilogy of films that tells a story of heroes, but also deconstruct them, showcase them as three-dimensional characters, as people and not as good guys up on pedestals
The change of tone from the seriousness and war setting of Heneral Luna and Goyo to the more modern setting of Quezon threw me off, but also had me engaged
Especially with the way they make a meta-commentary of the power of film and media to portray these stories
Jericho Rosales is wonderful to see on screen as MLQ, and Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio Osmeña showed a fun dynamic--almost like a romantic couple--between Quezon and Osmeña
The non-linear storytelling was also a change that I had to adjust after re-watching the first two in preparation for this
Thankfully, there are title cards and chapters that serve as good guide posts for the pacing of the story

Speaking of story, as this film spanned a longer timeframe compared to the two, it's written to showcase more vignette-type and montage-style of events rather than the more straightforward storytelling in Luna and Goyo
While it's not a bad thing, it can be difficult to keep track of while watching
Also, pacing is an issue as some parts dragged and other moments could've used more time to absorb its messaging
The showcase of Quezon's con artistry and showcasing him as a chameleon is done very well
This movie was really a battle of wits instead of arms--and it truly showcased the Filipino political culture
The production and set design were done incredibly well
A lot of effort was put to make this a period piece
While some seams and cracks can be seen here-and-there, those can be mostly ignored and do not hinder my enjoyment of the film
There isn't that much bloodshed and prosthetic wounds to be seen here, but more on CG buildings, vehicles, and recreation of period appropriate settings and props

---SPOILER THOUGHTS---I think they could've had a Mabini scene somewhere as having Aguinaldo, Joven, Rusca, and Janolino weren't enough connective tissue for me to fully connect this movie with the previous two
The Alerta storyline and Nadia filmmaking storyline could've been tighter as these were the parts that dragged the most

Though I do appreciate having this fictional plot point to give commentary on the importance of film, media, journalism, and media literacy--I do think this could be polished more and make less preachy
In the previous films, I didn't feel like I was being banged with the head with all of its messaging because of how beautiful the writing is and how its themes weave together with its characters
In here, that magic was kinda muddled a bit
But there were still some scenes and lines that made such a good impact on me
His abrupt death and shouting into the abyss, left me dissatisfied to be honest
Both Luna and Goyo's death were shown on-screen while here, it's just implied and presented to us through text
I would've loved to see him actually die in his sleep or something or maybe have Osmeña receive the news and take his place and then have the epilogue of the movie there
Lastly, all three films had some sort of subplot of the protagonist having some sort of affair
I think Aurora Quezon was underutilized here
Luna's affair with Isabel makes sense as the character was an amalgamation of various women in Luna's life
Goyo's love affairs with Felicidad and Dolores were the most poetic and beautifully done juxtaposed with the sacrifices of war
Quezon's love for Aurora and the affair with Ana Ricardo was so tense but not as strong as I would like it to be as both women were more plot device than actual characters
---END OF SPOILER THOUGHTS---Quezon is a great film and I am thankful to have watched it on the big screen
I think it is the weakest of the trilogy, but it still has its redeeming qualities

It can be frustrating in a negative sense with some of the complaints I have, but this film and the entire Bayani-verse trilogy of movies are frustrating in the positive sense--as ALL three were well-written to present themes, lessons, and events that are still relevant to this day

Jericho Rosales doesn't really look like Quezon, I was really hesitant at his casting first especially as the original Quezon TJ Trinidad (and even the younger Quezon Benjamin Alves as well as Apolinario Mabini actor from previous Bayaniverse films Epy Quizon) looks more similar to the real Quezon, but Jericho did really make up for his acting
I love how the political tactics and intrigue are made with comedic timing, keeping audiences interested in the screen
I thought Mon Confiado was really perfect as Quezon and Iain Glen's special appearance as Governor General Leonard Wood was fantastic

I thought Karylle's Aurora Quezon doesn't have much to do in the movie, but I was really impressed with her acting especially when she realized Quezon's first "wife" was in the same event as her and Quezon
The movie seems to be based strongly on facts, but I couldn't find from my research information about this so called first "wife" of Quezon before Aurora
But I do think she was used very well in the plot of this movie
The fictional characters Joven Hernando and his daughter Nadia are well used in this movie as well
They are intended to represent the audiences (especially Filipino audiences as their Filipino history shown in this movie is still relevant today)
Overall a great third movie in Jerrold Tarrog's Bayaniverse movie films (along with 2015's Heneral Luna and 2018's Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral)

“Maraming politiko sa bansa, ngunit kakaunti lamang ang tunay na lingkod-bayan
”This movie reveals the harsh reality behind politics in the Philippines—how cheating and greed have embedded into the country’s system, and how these practices have been normalized until now
It shows how our government fight for independence, only to end up imprisoning its own people under self-serving leadership
This film should also serves as an eye-opener to every Filipino— to remind that today’s news about our government is merely a repetition of what has already happened in the past
Ang tunay na kalayaan ay hindi natin makakamtan sa mga kamay ng dayuhan, kundi sa paglaya sa mga politikong patuloy na pinaiikot ang mga Pilipino sa bulok at madumi nilang sistema

maybe not my favorite out of the three in the bayaniverse, but i do believe it to be the most relevant as its closest to our present reality today
it very effectively punctures our lack of regard for some of the earliest developments of our current republic
it then became a great illustration of how the governance and systems we face today doesn’t fall far from the tree (unfortunately)
in that sense, the film is a lot less emotionally moving compared to its counterparts in the trilogy
instead, it was moreso unsettling: and maybe that’s the point
history is not merely the study of the past, but it is also how the present came to be and continues to evolve as we speak
moreover, heroes are but names we give to very much real people with a human capacity for malice and fault
much credit to jerrold tarog for the bayaniverse trilogy
had it not been for general luna, i’d not have gone on history deep dives in my free time (because unfortunately the last time we had proper philippine history as a class was in grade 6)

we’re often apprehensive to approach history as the mere thought of the many big names and events intimidate us — especially when we think that history is just dead people and shit that went down years ago
but what if we just don’t realize that history is actually, very much as well, the now
quezon (2025) is a great ender to the trilogy because it cements such idea
it’s chilling to think about how time has passed and how much has stayed the same
thinking about it all has made me unsettled (which, again, i think is the point)
a detail that im fixated on about this movie is quezon’s use of the word “independence”
he uses the idea of it as a bluff and it’s almost like a tell in his strategy for the game that people somehow fall for time and time again

it almost becomes a kind of semantic satiation, with the amount of times he promises it, it starts losing its meaning –said meaning already being completely misunderstood, or at least, understood without the weight and depths and nuances of it

another side of his promise for independence of the philippines is how the film rounds the statement up by the end with quezon screaming “i am the philippines” –the implication of his life’s work only being dedicated to a kind of independence for Himself and not for the country…

there are numerous reasons in which individuals desire to enter politics, but not everyone is really a public servant
you have to possess tremendous power to influence in order to become such a powerful individual
my opinion is that many who become so influential are not exercising this power for good governance, rather for personal interests
this thinking can bring about patronage politics, corruption, and insensitivity to the needs of the people(which is actually happening rn)
It's sad to see people put personal interest ahead of the common good

this film sheds some light on this aspect by depicting the shrewd personality of Manuel Quezon, our first president commonwealth president(that’s why andaming palang proposed constitution, and yung transition about tydings-mcduffie act hindi tinuro sa’min kung what was the real story behind those numerous revisions and amendments)
It depicts how his calculated and shrewd politics influenced the country's history, but at the same time points out the ambiguity between heroism and manipulation
the film instigates us to challenge our understanding of historical icons and what it actually means to be a hero
It gives us inspiration to think critically on leadership and governance, and to aim for a system where power is utilized for the common good, not for a chosen few
while reflecting on Quezon's legacy, we are reminded that genuine public servants are those who put the greater good first, not personal interests

Quezon, in terms of storytelling, is different from the approach of Heneral Luna and Goyo
Not that the previous films were set during the war for independence and Quezon was more about words, but Tarog’s treatment here was somewhat different
What I appreciate about this new approach is its new perspective

In this film, we see Quezon through the lens of Nadia’s works, portrayed as both a hero and a shrewd politician — a duality reflected by the people around him like Joven, who seem like spectators to his life
The storytelling feels more playful yet sharp, much like the mind games shown in the film, which perfectly capture his wit and sly character
I also liked the use of the title card inspired by the silent era in the sequence that introduces Quezon — a clever way to bridge the past and the present
The scenes of love-hate tension between him and Osmeña, his attempts to outsmart Leonard Wood, and his feud with Aguinaldo make us, as viewers, feel like spectators in this grand game of politics
Despite the seriousness of the subject, the humor and comedic tone remain, giving the film a lighter touch — something I truly appreciate
It also highlights the absurdity of politics, showing how politicians can sometimes be clowns themselves
Quezon is definitely a film worth watching in cinemas
I also appreciate its cinematography and sound design, which add so much to the overall narrative
Quezon is less about defining a hero and more about what a hero isn't
With no guns and battles this time, Tarog's final film in the trilogy relied on a well-written screenplay and a brilliant direction and editing
This felt polished and grand
Jericho Rosales plays Quezon masterfully with his unmatched charisma and mischievous persona
Every department of this production brought their A-game (except the makeup which was at times distracting)
The writing here is particularly good, in my opinion the best of the trilogy
Quite an experience going home from the cinema in a motorcycle, seeing his name in every corner of every street in this city named after him
His legacy indeed lived on
Scary to think that the unprincipled legacy of the people running this country today might live on too just like his

Quezon is not your typical biopic
It doesn’t simply glorify the titular figure, nor does it aim to reduce him to a villain
It’s a sharp, unsettling mirror
The cinematography is well-executed, every shot deliberate and meaningful
I loved how the film plays with style: the silent movie and noir sequences are such clever touches
There’s a bit of camp, even excess, but it works
Politics has always been a performance in the Philippines anyway, and this film leans right into that
It’s not afraid to show Quezon as both idealist and egotist, leader and manipulator
The movie calls out how he perfected the art of political spectacle, something we’re still drowning in today
At times, it gets too caught up in that same spectacle, focusing on power plays more than the people affected by them, but maybe that’s part of the point
What stings most is how familiar it all feels
The greed, the posturing, the foreign meddling: it’s the same game, just with new players
Quezon isn’t perfect, but it’s sharp, stylish, and painfully relevant
It doesn’t just revisit history; it forces us to realize we’ve never really left it
Give Jericho Rosales his well-deserved FAMAS now
that perforamance was spectacular
BANAL-BANALAN KANG BURAT KA
Nakakatuwang isipin na kahit medyo natagalan bago nasundan at dumaan sa maraming hamon, ngayon ay mapapanood na rin natin ang “final installment” ng Bayaniverse
This time, nakatutok ang pelikula kay Manuel L
Quezon, upang ipakita sa mga Pilipino kung ano nga ba ang tunay na kahulugan ng pagiging bayani
So, was it worth the wait
One thing’s very clear: this movie is made with passion and love
Every aspect, production design, costume, music, sound design, acting, and screenplay, everything feels precise and deliberate
Walang sayang
Busog ang mata mo, at napakasarap sa pandinig ng bawat linya at tugtugin
I also appreciate that the film didn’t contradict anything from the previous installments
There’s no unnecessary retcon, and even smaller roles were reprised by the same actors (except for Joross Gamboa as Eduardo Rusca, previously played by Archie Alemania)
Hindi ko nga agad napansin na siya pala iyon until I checked online, still, I appreciate his inclusion
What leaves me conflicted, however, is how the narrative perspective centers on Joven
He’s a good character, pero minsan nawawala ang connection natin kay Quezon
Unlike the first two films where we clearly see the world through the minds of Luna and Goyo, dito parang ikinukuwento lang sa atin ang nararamdaman ni Quezon
That sometimes creates a bit of emotional distance
I get that the film wants to show that our heroes are just as flawed and human as we are, and I love that message, but I wish we could’ve seen more of Quezon’s inner struggle
The non-linear structure works surprisingly well
Kahit medyo gimmicky, it adds flavor to the storytelling, especially since we already know where the story is headed
Jericho Rosales delivers a powerful and charismatic performance as Quezon
Mon Confiado also brings his A-game, while Cris Villanueva, Arron Villaflor, and Rominick Sarmenta shine in their respective roles
For Iain Glen, I honestly feel another actor could’ve played the part, but it’s still commendable that they brought in a respected Hollywood actor for the role
Overall, Quezon is a strong and passionate film
It may be overly ambitious at times, occasionally losing sight of its identity, but its heart is in the right place
The message remains powerful: kahit ilang taon na ang lumipas, tila hindi pa rin nagbabago ang mga Pilipino
And if ever this isn’t truly “the end,” I hope we still get to see more stories from the Bayaniverse, especially with that mid-credit scene tease

We are introduced to their games, how they operated, and how they think
Today, it might seem obvious
But to think that this has been happening long before our independence has me worried
I was sitting in the cinema literally not knowing exactly how I feel, other than discomfort
​Technically, I appreciated the writing
Despite being dialogue-heavy, the lines are witty and written with a style similar to the Bayaniverse
I also like the aesthetic; it reminds me of Wes Anderson (very subtle) and the likes with its use of symmetry, colors, and scores
​Ultimately, we are shown the humane side of our celebrated heroes
While we appreciate what they've done for our country, we should not be blind to consider them human—not idols, not kings, not gods

Director Jerrod Tarog delivers another masterpiece in the Bayaniverse with a showcase in filmmaking excellence in acting, cinematography, editing, production and costume design

I was initially thrown off by Jericho Rosales and Romnick Sarmienta's accents (never bothered to check if that's how Quezon and Osmena sounded in real life) but they're 2 of today's best actors that I eventually appreciated how they fully embodied their respective roles
Ditto Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, Karylle as Doña Aurora, JC Santos as Roxas, and even Cris Villanueva as fictional character journalist Joven Hernando
It was also nice to see Iain Glen (Jorah Mormont in Game of Thrones) play Governor-General Wood
Quezon's bantering/arguments with both Osmena and Wood were quite amusing/entertaining
Also commend the shift in tone which was like a breath of fresh air in telling a Pinoy historical drama (sort of reminded me of Mike de Leon's 'Bayaning 3rd World' which also starred Villanueva)

But if I were to nitpick, I'd note that if Luna and del Pilar were humanized in their respective biographical war dramas, Quezon was villainized here as the idealistic patriot fighting for Philippine independence turned scheming, power hungry politician
Yes, this film showed that the country has been (prodominantly) run by politicians, not public servants

YOU CAN’T LOSE WITH QUEZONAfter three watches, I can safely say one thing: I have so many thoughts about the Quezon movie, and yet so little words to convey it in
I wrote so many passages down in my notebooks
All of them half-finished or just me arguing with myself trying to make sense of what I was feeling
I’ll try my best to write them here
The Bayaniverse, one of my favorite Filipino movie series, has finally come to a close with (arguably) one of their best movies yet
Quezon veers away from the usual historical biopic formula and moves into the territory of being a social commentary
Instead of the “event A happened, so event B follows” format, Quezon asks us to sit with discomfort
Rather than simply glorifying its subject, the movie presents a national hero who reflects the leaders we have now
A visionary who fought for Filipino independence, yet, a calculating statesman who mastered the performance of politics
Charming when needed, ruthless when required, and deeply aware of optics

I see the movie as something that doesn’t necessarily paint Quezon in a necessarily evil nor corrupt light, but as a pragmatic who knew that idealism alone could not dismantle a colonial-imperialism system built on inequality
That pragmatism, however, is exactly what built the foundations of our current political structure
What does that say about our national heroes
What does that say about the kinds of people we choose to enshrine and remember
Most importantly, what does that say about us
The Quezon we see in the movie is not simply Quezon–he’s also the collective psyche of the nation that produced him and the time that he lived in
He lived under an imperialist, racist U
As the movie perfectly states, “Quezon may not have made the game, but he sure did play it
”I think Quezon challenges the comfort that we have in hero worship
It dares us to look at power
Not as a moral test or a path to self-actualization, but as a mirror to who we are as a nation going through growing pains
Is it worth acknowledging that building a road to greatness often comes with destroying whatever comes ahead
The real message of the Bayaniverse, in my opinion, is that the nation was not built by perfect saints
It was also built by people who have the tendency to be selfish, flawed, ambitious, and painfully human
The series tells us that our understanding of heroism must mature as we continue to mature as a nation
On a more personal note, I will never forget the feeling of watching it on the big screen

Citizen Quezon
painful irony of a nation striving for independence while simultaneously being undermined by internal disunity and dependence on external influence
the film offers a sharp critique of the deeply rooted filipino concept of utang na loob and exposes how it can distort the ideals of governance and public service
what once began as a moral virtue, a sign of respect and loyalty, becomes a political instrument that undermines integrity, opening the door to corruption, favoritism, and blind allegiance
it challenges viewers to reflect on how certain filipino values, while culturally meaningful, can be misused to sustain systems of power that work against true progress
at the same time, the film also confronts a difficult truth: it’s not easy to question or turn away from this cycle, especially when one is personally benefiting from those in power
comfort and convenience can blur one’s moral vision, making it hard to see the injustice hidden behind acts of generosity
it takes courage and self-awareness to break free from that dependence, to open one’s eyes and choose integrity over personal gain
It depicts how, even long before, politicians have always been performative when it comes to their propaganda just to appear pleasing to the people
Human as we are, Filipinos as we are, we tend to be easily blinded by whatever “truth” is presented to us, especially when it aligns with our values and principles

What struck me most (in the worst way possible) and I was genuinely flabbergasted was the case with his first wife and how he defended himself in court, saying something along the lines of, “Does this face really need to rape someone
” It shows how contradicting his principles already were
You cannot fight for your country if you are struggling to be humane yourself
Quezon took Filipinos as nothing but mere tools for him to gain power
In reality, isa pa rin siyang tuta ng mga Amerikano by adhering to the same vicious practices as those American people
“Independence is just a word
” – QuezonWhat really is independence
Have we truly achieved it if we remain enslaved by poor governance and corruption
After all, he said it himself that he would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by Americans
Perhaps Hobbes was right, man is selfish in nature, and he will do anything through voluntary acts if the object serves some good to himself
Is it the lesser evil for the Philippines to barely progress under Filipino rule, rather than to thrive under an American one
This isn’t to claim that the latter would be preferable, rather, it’s to assert that we deserve a government that upholds both, a competent leadership and a genuinely Filipino sense of governance

I entered the cinema expecting a crashcourse on history, yet I've been dished with a more nuanced understanding on our collective perception of history as a whole
The movie itself is the statement

Heneral Luna and Goyo have already fixed our expectation/s on how this will turn out: a valorous exhibit on the lives of "national heroes" that shaped Philippines as we know it; setting a preliminary idea that it will follow the same pattern about building Quezon as a major contributor of our independence
Yet, as it turns out, the movie stitches reflective points gauging on what these historical acts truly mean to us and the manner as to how these information precipitated through our minds
A magnified look into Quezon as an individual, almost overshadowing the historical context within them opens up a rare opportunity for critiqe against our national heroes
Oftentimes, we are trained to consume knowledge as quick as light, yet there is lesser existential emphasis that allow us to reject passivity in learning

I am too drowsy to add more (i will edit this soon tho), but I really enjoyed thinking about a lot of things such as the state of Philippine politics, statehood, and the lingering wonder as to what truly constitus a hero and power as recursive influence on the trajectory of history and how its viewed

How painful it is to see this film validate one of my biggest fears about trying to make it in this country: that the only real way to succeed is by taking advantage of an unjust and cruel system, one that requires you to bring down others to bring yourself up
It’s more than just “crab mentality”; it’s systemic and rooted deep within, right into this country’s body and soul
So when the character of Quezon, an ambitious man who benefitted from (and allegedly originated) the country’s rotten practices, shouted “I am the Philippines”, I was inclined to believe him
On a side note, I’ve always wanted to see more Filipino movies about politicking — which is why the feature scripts I’ve written tackle it extensively — and so this was such a feast for me
okay let's dissect how the movie is a depiction of how it was before and is now

The film’s most intriguing throughline lies in Manuel Quezon’s (Jericho Rosales) exchanges with Joven Hernando (Arron Villaflor as the young journalist, Cris Villanueva as the older one)
Joven, who once idolized Quezon, becomes his conscience and later his accuser, returning a coin once given to him as a symbol of principle
Their relationship encapsulates writer-director Jerrold Tarog’s grand question: can integrity survive intimacy with power
It’s through Joven’s eyes that we watch the statesman’s transformation into strongman, his lofty rhetoric curdling into patronage politics
When Quezon shuts down Joven’s newspaper for publishing an exposé, the betrayal stings not only as political allegory but as personal tragedy—the loss of faith in leadership itself

What I found most striking here (and which I strongly feel is the film’s strongest aspect) is how Tarog, through Joven’s eyes, frames Quezon as the unwitting architect of a system that still defines us
Joven suggests that while Quezon didn’t invent patronage politics, he definitely perfected its choreography: every favor disguised as friendship, every handshake turned into hierarchy
The film doesn’t condemn him outright for this; it simply watches how such pragmatism metastasizes into a national reflex that still nags at us today
In one exchange, Quezon insists that principle must bend to survival, a line that feels less like justification than prophecy
Tarog lets that sentiment resonate across the film like a curse
We see it in the way Quezon rewards loyalty with access, in the quiet humiliation of those who refuse to play along, and in the hollow triumph of independence negotiated rather than fought for
The movie’s politics are cyclical, almost fatalistic: power breeds corruption, corruption demands compromise, and compromise becomes governance
Tarog doesn’t spell this out; he lets it unfold in the pauses between alliances and betrayals, in the small intimate silences that follow Quezon’s public victories
Joven’s arc, meanwhile, becomes our moral compass—a journalist who believes truth can coexist with patronage, only to learn that one always consumes the other
His disillusionment is as national as it is personal
By the time he returns the coin Quezon once gave him, the gesture feels both intimate and historical, like a nation finally returning the debt of false ideals
Tarog’s “Bayaniverse” has always traced this erosion, but here it feels complete: Quezon may have built the country’s first Republic, but he also built the template for its recurring undoing
What the film ultimately suggests is that corruption in the Philippines isn’t an aberration—it’s an inheritance
Quezon’s genius wasn’t that he corrupted the system, but that he understood how to make corruption look like leadership
His brand of “opportunistic nationalism,” as historians have called it, didn’t die with him; it evolved, refined by each successor who learned the same survivalist grace
Tarog’s gaze isn’t accusatory, though
It’s almost elegiac, as if recognizing that Quezon’s contradictions—his brilliance, his vanity, his compromises—are also ours

As the final chapter of Jerrold Tarog’s Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon wraps things up in a way that’s both bold and refreshing
I went into this with zero expectations since it didn’t get much buzz, but honestly, it’s a must-watch even if you haven’t seen Heneral Luna or Goyo
It may not be as explosive or emotionally charged as Heneral Luna, nor as poetic as Goyo, but its quirky, satirical tone gives it a distinct identity that stands strong alongside the first two films
Seeing Quezon’s story unfold beyond the pages of history books is fascinating
Tarog leans into dark humor and sharp political satire, exposing the manipulative, chaotic world of power struggles — Quezon versus fellow politicians and the Americans
This isn’t your typical biopic; it’s a political farce where Jericho Rosales’ Quezon treats nationhood like a rigged game only he can win
He lies when needed, bends the truth to his advantage, and embodies both heroism and hypocrisy
What makes this film stand out is its honesty
It doesn’t glorify Quezon
it exposes his flaws, ambition, and contradictions
The inclusion of media’s role in shaping narratives adds another layer, reminding us that there are always two sides to every story
The line “heroism is just a perception” sums it up perfectly
Jericho Rosales is phenomenal here that you forget you’re watching him, he is Quezon
Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, and the actors portraying Osmeña and Roxas, all deliver sharp, grounded performances that complement the film’s tone
The ending hits hard with its satirical bite, when Quezon declares, “I am the Philippines
” Tarog leaves it open to interpretation, but to me, it’s a powerful commentary on power, ego, and politics — on how even noble intentions can rot when corrupted by greed
A hero proclaiming that he is the country becomes the same figure consumed by its flaws
It’s ironic, timely, and uncomfortably reflective of the state of our nation today
Quezon isn’t just a political film — it’s a mirror held up to our nation, to our leaders, and to ourselves
It’s raw, funny, unsettling, and deeply Filipino
A brilliant, unflinching finale to Tarog’s Bayaniverse

Easily one of my most favorite films of all time, not because of my personal bias towards the Bayaniverse films nor because of my views and opinions on MLQ, but because of how much impact this could make in shaping conversations about our "heroes
"Historical figures are all subject to the judgment of history
We cannot confine MLQ into being an exclusively great statesman, nor into a cunning chameleon of a politician
We've got to see the good, the bad, and the ugly
After all, his decisions are a product of the conditions of the Philippines during his time
Love him or hate him, MLQ made his mark in our history
Marks that should be studied and learned from, lest we repeat the mistakes of the past

I finally watched Quezon with my family after we got the time to see it in the cinema
It is the final and third film released after Goyo which was shown seven years ago
This film took several years into production which made me think if ever this will be finished since it would take a lot of money to make it and possibly got delayed because of the pandemic as well
When the cast and more details were announced, I am glad that it still pushed through despite some delays in production
However, what raised some eyebrows is the announcement of Jericho Rosales as Manuel L
Quezon since there was another actor that was supposed to portray an older version of him
I was surprised because Quezon is a mestizo while Rosales is a moreno actor
While I think this must be a miscast, I was intrigued whether he can pull this off since he is also a good actor too and has played lead roles in the past
Watched the movie, I was impressed by Rosales's portrayal of Quezon as an ambitious yet charismatic senator who wants to liberate the Philippines from the Americans
I had my doubts at first that Jerrold Tarog would make Quezon a good person yet what he did in this film he made him a morally grey character
It based Quezon on several historical documents and articles

While it didn't cover much about everything, it is clear that Quezon is what we call in a politics a " trapo" where he uses people to his advantage and perception in winning the elections and attaining power
Watching the film made me realize that everything is still relevant to what is happening today
Same people but different faces
The movie depicts how politics is game for the politicians where the masses are still considered pawns and the rich and elite still dictate everything and control the society
In this film, I didn't root for either Quezon or Aguinaldo
There is neither black and white nor good and bad
Overall, the film is great and entertaining to watch
The veteran and rising cast is great
I also think that Quezon and Osmeña here have chemistry as rivals turned to running mates
It's also an eye-opener to everyone especially when some of the issues in this film are still relevant to our country
Joven and his family represent our struggle in facing the reality of our country
Corruption is a systemic problem in our country and the film makes us think whether we are truly free
Even if we are independent, imperialism still exists in our country especially with how first world countries interfere with our affairs and also control our economy in other ways
The political system is still same but worse and I can still see Quezon in some politicians in the news

With Quezon showing in cinemas, I hope that more people will learn to discern and choose leaders carefully and see them in a lens where they don't vote them just because they're popular or owe them everything
Quezon is not perfect in terms of production and pacing, but it's a fun watch and has served its purpose for the general public
I'm optimistic that if more people will watch this type of films we might get more genres like them in the future
PS: Stay for the mid-credit scenes

It’s always about f* politics (getting in power) and never about the Filipino people
We are the Philippines—each and every one of us

Walang kapangyarihang ginagamit para sa sariling pakinabang

Oo, marami ang gutom
Gutom sa mabuting pamumuno at maayos na pamamalakad sa inang bayan
Oh, how we cry for the lives of Filipinos who yearn not just for good governance, but for a life worthy of the freedom we keep celebrating
Tayo ba ay tunay na malaya na

jericho delivered a layered performance so i’ll deliver a layered reviewat first, I thought the choice to tell the story from That POV was just a gimmicky choice, like form over substance, but as the film continued it felt like a very relevant meta commentary (idk for sure if that’s the intention)
(For added context for the succeeding parts of this review, Quezon’s grandson crashed out during a press tour as he claims there are gross inaccuracies in the film
)The way this film dealt about propaganda stuck with me
Choosing to tell the story in that POV further drives the point for me
Quezon’s grandson crashed out because of inaccuracies, but this film isn’t supposed to be seen as an historical account (as well as the previous films in this trilogy for that matter)
Telling the story from the perspective of the film reels for me feels like the director’s way of telling us that these films shouldn’t be read as historical accounts because they are just not
In fact it could even be interpreted as propaganda by some
But that is what the film means to me at least
When TJ Trinidad was recast, I was hesitant, mainly because TJ looked like a modern Manuel Quezon
But after seeing Jericho’s performance as the titular character, no one could’ve done a better job
The voice, the mannerisms, the small details, it’s so layered and I could watch it for hours on end
Everyone else in the cast did a fantastic job as well
(Fuck the CongTV cameo tho)I was shocked by how much they grounded Manuel Quezon back to reality and deconstructed the person
Quezon is one of my favorite presidents, but this made me look at him at a less fanatic perspective
Quezon was one smart mf, but that was also his flaw
He may be the our country’s best example of what a Machiavellian is
He played the cards he was dealt with yes, but he did so knowing the game was rigged while still benefiting from it, and even contributing to the rot
The way imperialism and independence is dealt with here has me conflicted, I still have no cohesive thoughts about how they discussed it, maybe on a rewatch
Politics is a game to those in power even if it shouldn’t be because our lives depend on it
ALSO the tension built in the Bagac Bataan scene IS SO
also i geeked tf out when they mentioned Murnau like hellooo (felt like the director just wanna flex his knowledge about filmmaking but still appreciated lol)anyways, I need to see it again
could be shortergets ko naman pag gamit ng peliks as medium as well as joven’s character but how i wish i just had more more quezon’s moments bc he’s one hell of a nuanced and complex character

Gagging from start to finish (for all the right and wrong reasons)
Trigger Warning: CongTV
Based on a true story in 2
25 hours
Filmed in 2025 in color
Celebrating 5 years on: October 31st, 2030
Quezon is a somewhat tacky drama that reduces the life and career of former Philippines president Manuel L
Quezon to a series of trite political battles
All the characters have shallow personalities
The dialogue and acting are often cringeworthy
If Tarog’s goal was to make history feel alive again, then he has succeeded—sometimes to the point of discomfort
As cinema, “Quezon” is impressive
As history, it’s provocative
And as myth, it’s necessary
